At times there's no way to be sure whether what's on screen is scripted or candid, a formal tension that keeps the film on its toes while also underscoring that it's more effective as an experiential mood piece than it is as a drama.
The subject matter may not lend itself to an overtly ambitious aesthetic, but a film about individuals who refuse to be silenced could stand to take a few more chances itself.
Coming of age in a broken home has rarely looked better than it does in Asia Argento's Misunderstood.
Strickland's skill is in how quickly he normalizes the proceedings, neither condescending to his characters nor using their inclinations for cheap laughs.
A cooly entertaining countdown narrative whose stakes rarely feel as life-and-death as they're meant to.
Free of studio meddling, Lee gets to wallow in the excessive violence and comedy typical of an old grindhouse film.
Uneven ...
Our glimpses of what's already occurred and what will soon come are vivid and impressionistic, prophetic warnings about which everyone seems powerless to do anything other than silently observe.
Eastwood's deceptively straightforward take on the life of decorated marksman Chris Kyle is more rife with this sort of quandary than it initially appears.

Anyone who's seen Errol Morris' expressionistic documentary on Hawking knows a conventional approach isn't ideal for the ALS-afflicted genius-which isn't to say James Marsh's new film doesn't succeed on its own more modest terms.
Katniss is treated as a pawn when she's clearly a queen, her image constantly co-opted by entities beyond her control trying to use it for their own ends. No wonder Lawrence plays her so well.
Unlike anything else you'll see this year.

Jones captures stark and disturbing moments with a matter-of-factness that's neither overstated nor flippantly casual. It's no revelation that this was a dangerous time and place, and he doesn't treat it as such.
None of this goes down with any real verve, though Kamiyama's wrinkled face is a small marvel of expressivity.
As with most epics, there are a lot of speeches and dead horses -- all in needless 3D -- but not enough genuine emotion to actually make any of it feel, well, epic.

There's finally a genuine sense of breathless urgency to the concluding chapter, which pits man against dwarf against elf against orc in an elegantly crafted, altogether glorious skirmish for supremacy over the Lonely Mountain
movie_title: The Hobbit: The Battle of the Five Armies (2014)

movie_review_blurb: That's an intriguing question about life and fate, albeit one this film - about a chance discovery setting off an old vendetta - doesn't fully see through.
Diaz roots his film in the quotidian so as to make it all the more noticeable when he reaches for the transcendent, a lofty goal he frequently achieves.

Sad family secrets abound on the secluded homestead in Jay Craven's adaptation of the novel by Frank Mosher, and though these mini-revelations go a long way ... it doesn't make their complicated dynamic much more involving.
Elegant and elliptical, Josephine Decker's psychodrama is a blurring of the line between waking and dream states.
LeBlanc and Larter carry the day with a spectrum of charm missing from too many entries in this shaky, persistent genre.

Macdonald is a fine captain himself, particularly when it comes to the more visceral thrills. But he could have stood to cut the screed against the fat cats who line their pockets with dollars earned by the workingman.
A deeply unsettling exploration of the links between personal and national trauma.
The vicarious thrills of getting lost in the cinematic wilderness have apparently yet to be exhausted.
They say that living well is the best revenge; in Unbroken, simply surviving is.
A uniquely riveting experience sure to inspire an array of reactions-speechlessness included.
DuVernay says she doesn't like typical historical dramas, and it shows.
The entire third act feels like a tacked-on verse that has no place in the finished song.
Broomfield takes all involved to task for their (mis)handling of the case in this dispiriting portrait of a cast-aside community.
Chandor charts the moral decline accompanying financial gain with weary-eyed aplomb.
The actual narrative may sometimes trudge along like a traveler braving a blizzard without snowshoes, but Ceylan makes the smallest of moments feel like apocalyptic harbingers.

A welcome return to the filmmaker's late '90s style; unlike his far grimmer recent output, here the occasionally overpraised writer-director is at his best counterbalancing the bleak with the bizarre.
The kind of movie film theorists could only dream about a century ago.

Action heroes are best when they are charming, winsome and witty. Bullock is inane, annoying and whiny.

movie_review_blurb: It's a long ride to a familiar destination.

It is a teen romantic comedy that largely fits the familiar template but is also fleshed out with atmosphere, a nice blend of broad goofiness and sophistication, and two appealing leads who bring it to life.
A mockumentary-thriller-broad-comedy-psychological-drama-sex-farce-insider-Hollywood satire that . . . wait for it . . . could use some focus.

Anchored by a fascinating score from Oscar winner A.R. Rahman, naturalistic performances and a wide cinematic palette, Delhi-6 is a fair introduction to Indian cinema for outsiders -- who will have no clue at times why the audience is laughing.

Despite the familiar themes, the movie maintains its originality through its specificity.
Ultimately, its most unforgivable sin is that it's simply not funny.

There's a charming restaurant scene, some nifty hand-to-hand combat and the cast is great looking. But pretty much all the things that made the original so original are filtered out of this un-original.

Perhaps they'll eventually make one called Spoof Movie, which would brilliantly parody the genre by being consistently funny.

Factory made, nothing new... and really funny.

Delightfully unpredictable.

The kids' mistakes make you cringe -- often with laughs of recognition -- and, during the film's most involving moments, makes you long to comfort them through their trials and cheer on their triumphs.

movie_review_blurb: It's photogenic people killing mutants before green screens; what more could you ask?

It appeals to kids while evoking genuine emotion without excessive sentimentality.

You've probably never seen anything like Big Man Japan.
There are terrible movies and there are loathsome movies. And then there's that rare breed so idiotic, exploitative and sickening one wishes they could be scrubbed from memory.
(500) Days of Summer is something seldom seen: an original romantic comedy.

Unlike so many sequels, [REC] 2 builds nicely on the ideas introduced first time around; in particular, the nature and history of the disease, only touched on in the original, are explored much more fully here to chilling effect.

movie_review_blurb: As a conversation starter ... it's an affable appetizer.

movie_title: The Immaculate Conception of Little Dizzle (2009)

Often-unwatchably dim.
Not only is Perry in tune with his audience as always, he's unquestionably growing as a cinematic artist.
movie_title: Why Did I Get Married Too (2010)

movie_review_blurb: It can't be a good sign for a vampire movie when its most memorable trait is how desperate Chrysler's product placement appears.

More disastrous than disaster movie.

movie_title: Shock to the System: A Donald Strachey Mystery (2006)

Slow, poetic exploration of memory, loss in sci-fi setting.

movie_review_blurb: If Four Brothers spent half as much energy making us feel something for its heroes as it spent making us feel nothing for their victims, it would be a far better, and far more engaging, film.

Is Spartan a perfect, or even a great, movie? Probably not. But in its prickly irascibility and deeply unsettling intelligence, it makes for a very, very good one.
Contrary to expectation, it's neither a movie about religion nor the coming together of enemies. What it is, at heart, is a movie about love.

movie_review_blurb: It more than surpasses the original.
Neither wholly cynical nor wholly romantic, Kaufman's story is a balance of smarts and sentiment.
movie_title: Eternal Sunshine Of The Spotless Mind (2004)

movie_review_blurb: Nosedive it does, abandoning all pretense of style and eccentricity for at-times laughable predictability.
The filmmaker drowns his trademark edgy stew of smutty humor, stiff acting and dime-store insight into human nature with a gravy of glutinous bathos, making for a singularly unpalatable dish.
Despite Koepp's control of suspense and Depp's fully fleshed, if fragmented, hero, this Window ultimately feels like one most of us have climbed through before.

Given the fact that the protagonist's smiling acquiescence to bondage comes uncomfortably close to a Stepin Fetchit caricature, James' Journey almost makes forced servitude seem like a jaunty lark.
Walking Tall actually underserves its star, who is better than schlocky material like this would lead you to believe.
Brooks's spare and reverberant film ... stands back from the actors and just lets them be with each other.
Comes across less as a fully realized work of storytelling than as a commercial for a corporation whose goal of entertainment has been replaced by that of making money.
A compelling, exquisitely acted drama about the shock waves emanating from -- and toward -- a single act of almost inexplicable violence.
The film's exploration of loss and the gulf of time and memory that separates us from our pasts is beautifully and subtly handled by Kore-eda.
In its innocence, sweet heart and abundant wit, it has more going for it, by my accounting, than a dozen more expensive-looking films.
Yes, it plays like a baldfaced, brazen insult, but it is a stunningly accomplished one.
Very, very funny, thanks to a lively first script by Mark O'Rowe, who has a good ear for earthy dialogue and a sense of life's absurd little synchronicities.
Well-meaning but amateurish drama.
Gooding once again embarrasses himself in public with a performance that knows no shame, a habit he's getting frighteningly at ease with these days.
A film whose effects are as hard to wash away as blood.
Isn't as bad as it looks.
movie_title: How to Lose a Guy in 10 Days (2003)

movie_review_blurb: Relatively innocuous but utterly unnecessary -- except from the standpoint of unbridled capitalism.
Perfectly satisfactory without being deeply satisfying.

A viewing of this epic is likely to leave all but the geekiest Civil War buffs feeling as itchy and as restless as if they themselves were wearing woolen underwear -- soggy, unwashed, vintage 1860s, government-issue woolen underwear.
Harrowing and compulsively watchable morality play.
It's a wonderful Piglet? Maybe not wonderful, but still pretty darn good.
So much for subtlety, not to mention sensitivity to stereotypes.
A two-hour pleasure cruise.
Not the sharpest political humor I've ever heard, but it gets my vote for the stupidest fun I've had in a long time.
Mistakes flash for cleverness.
What keeps Phone Booth going, despite its premise, is the acting and the writing, both of which are top-notch.
One of the funnier and, in an odd way, disturbing stand-up concert films in a long while.
Something of a noirish thriller, although Duvall's script drops the ball big time in this regard.
Deeply creepy and richly satisfying.
movie_title: He Loves Me, He Loves Me Not (2002)

movie_review_blurb: Much to my surprise and delight, the movie is nothing like its marketing.
Moves with the lightning speed, raw power and athletic grace of, well, a genetically mutated superhero.

A thoughtful and surprisingly affecting portrait of a screwed-up man who dared to mess with some powerful people, seen through the eyes of the idealistic kid who chooses to champion his ultimately losing cause.
Fascinating story from screenwriter- turned-director Menno Meyjes.
Has the stink of man-musk all over it.
Darkly operatic and brilliantly realized.
I hated every minute of it.
Wickedly funny, jarringly transgressive, obdurately unpigeonholeable and startlingly moving.

Unfortunately, the experience of actually watching the movie is less compelling than the circumstances of its making.
A poke in the adrenal gland.
Will only satisfy those who can't tell the difference between the good, the bad and the ugly.
Moves at a glacial pace.
Its one-sidedness ... flirts with propaganda.
Here, common sense flies out the window, along with the hail of bullets, none of which ever seem to hit Sascha.
Delivers, in spades, exactly what you should expect from a popcorn flick.
Filmmaking at its purest and most visceral.
Despite impeccable acting ... and a script that takes some rather unexpected (even, at times, preposterous) turns, Love is just too, too precious in the end.
movie_title: Love in the Time of Money (2002)

movie_review_blurb: Just because it's a good idea doesn't mean it's easy to do well.
Profoundly moving without dipping into mawkishness.

Shakes, rattles and rolls the house.
Little more than a bedtime story for 12-year-old girls.

What a long, strange saga it is.

Makes the fatal mistake of so much middlebrow satire: It becomes that which it mocks.
Enriched by a strong and unforced supporting cast.
[Carrey] is so gifted a physical comedian that even mediocre material shines in his talented hands.

A superb meditation on love, lust, life and death.
Functional but tiresome.
The stellar but misguided cast ... is simply painful to watch as the doomed vehicle it's trapped in comes whistling toward a fiery crash landing.
[Nicolas Cage] just makes you believe in him.

movie_review_blurb: A wondrous, funny and moving little film.

It's all too, too cute and too, too forced for words.
Both wry and sobering, if such a thing is possible.
The only real question in this flaccid narrative ... is when everybody will stop talking and start singing again.
Disturbing, darkly beautiful.
Never goes deeper than what you might get out of Dr. Phil on a bad day.
A simple but perfectly satisfying little story about a boy who wants to keep his dog.

A gorgeously morbid meditation on the interconnectivity of life (and death).

Highly watchable stuff.

Funny, if a bit broad.
Funny, smart and sexy, not to mention the best advertisement for the euro I've ever seen.
One heck of a tale of deliciously unladylike payback.
Not surprising that it's more tragicomedy than yukfest.
Does exactly what it's supposed to, which is to make the heart beat slightly faster.
A captivating and richly resonant aquatic fable, with characters whose gills and fins belie their deliciously human (that is, flawed) personalities.
A gift for those already in the fold, for those who get the joke and just want to savor it with other like-minded fans.
Shows more hopelessness than optimism but is never less than honest.
An ungodly hash of comedy, romantic drama, musical and mystery thriller.
It makes having brains cool.

A little, heartbreaking gem.

The movie is a clear-eyed and engrossing look at an important subject.
movie_title: Page One: Inside the New York Times (2011)

movie_review_blurb: I'm tempted to write 'I say it's spinach and I say the hell with it,' except that I actually like spinach, and I could barely keep this half-baked dish down.
Predictability gives way to touching drama.
movie_title: Vincent will Meer (Vincent Wants to Sea) (2011)

movie_review_blurb: The "Insidious" franchise, after three attempts to exorcise its real demons, still can't seem to shake what really haunts it: the ghost of B-movies past.

It's a kid's movie that grown-ups will like. As Marnie does on Anna, the movie casts a spell.
[Vikander's] performance is a subtle tour de force of feeling and restraint, made all the more remarkable by the whiplash highs and lows of this true but melodramatic tale.
More than a testament to the power of cinematic storytelling as food for the human spirit, "The Wolfpack" also is a portrait of a family that has had to rely on each other to survive.

Although this latest documentary is, in large part, simply more of the same stuff we saw in the earlier films, there's also a lot of background material here about Servin and Vamos that makes this outing a bit more interesting.
What "Polar Bear" really lacks is hindsight. It is a little girl's valentine to her father, without the benefit of bittersweet wisdom that comes with age.

"Max" gets its job done, which is to celebrate the sacrifices of military dogs, while warming the cockles of your heart. Sugary though it may be, the movie is a spirited return to the values of 1950s Hollywood.
There's little sour to temper the sweetness of this portrait.
movie_title: I Am Big Bird: The Caroll Spinney Story (2015)

movie_review_blurb: The suspense that Di Stefano generates in the film's final hour is genuine, and the action gripping.

Unexpectedly, it works.

"Batkid" is a feel-good film, in the sense that the people who made this wish come true seem to feel pretty good about themselves. They certainly have a right to be satisfied: What they pulled off is impressive.

Sure, there's an undeniable pleasure from watching Pacino and Hunter work the screen, but the syrupy, symbol-heavy script by first-time feature writer Paul Logan is weighed down further by cliches and false notes.

The characters in "Aloft" seem to float over their strong passions, like birds riding on columns of air, without ever alighting.
While the movie is best viewed as an examination of a specific place and time, it also can be seen as a celebration of a larger, more generic cultural phenomenon that one might call creative foment.

movie_review_blurb: Death has always hung like a shadow over Giger and his art, which has its passionate partisans, but is not for the faint of heart.
Even after watching the movie, I have no idea how scared I should be.

If you can hang on for close to two hours with almost no resolution, it's worth the ride.
As deadly as its funereal subject matter.
"Little Boy" is a as phony as a game of three-card monte.

For a feature film, this clearly partisan documentary about the Swift boat crew that served under John Kerry in Vietnam is pretty slight, but for a campaign commercial -- which is what it feels like -- it's pretty long.
The film suffers a bit for its slowness. But once you get used to the fact that this is not "World War Z," it has its small pleasures, which are both cerebral and emotional.

"Where Hope Grows" wears its heart on its sleeve, hawking its message of salvation through faith to anyone who's in the market for cheesy uplift and saccharine sentiment.

The "Mad Max" franchise was never for everyone, yet it clearly benefits from fresh blood, too. Propelled by Miller's nitro-burning aesthetic vision and an entertaining cast, this turbo-charged new model is a gas, gas, gas.
[A] meandering, deliberate and tearless - yet oddly moving - western vehicle, which is both slow and, as gunslinger movies tend to be, action packed.
There's a subtext to this love story that seems to say we're all islands, in one way or another.

I would call the movie a trainwreck, except it's really four or five separate trainwrecks.

The reverend may be girded with the "armor or light," as he puts it, quoting the Bible. But his opponents - or at least the ones shown in the film - have seemingly strapped metaphorical Kevlar around what appear to be permanently closed minds.

"How do you say 'no' to someone with cancer?" Jess wonders, when Milly starts pushing the boundaries. For some, it's just as hard to say no to a movie with cancer. I managed, but many of you will not.

"Macbeth" possesses a terrible beauty, evoking fear, sadness, awe and confusion. Presented with the aesthetic of a dark comic book, it's also a mournful masterpiece ...

There are a few laughs here and there.

As Finders Keepers gets weirder, it also gets better and deeper.
A film that feels horrifyingly urgent, even as it is, at times, nearly impossible to watch without squirming.
Lawrence acts as a genial and knowledgable guide to the film's true subject, and the source of its titular irony: the increasing militarization of law enforcement.

Spoiler alert: Happiness has to do with loving others and self-acceptance.

movie_review_blurb: If only I could figure out what all this was meant to stand for.

"Left Behind" takes the end of the world and turns it not into a nightmare, but a nice long nap.
For the uninitiated, it offers a demonstration of what is so mesmerizing about this performer, who is by, his own description, "a kind of ostentatious bastard."

The film's problems aren't limited to liberal cadging from comic books. In fact, that's precisely what's best about the film, which occasionally boasts gorgeous visuals. But the movie doesn't know when to stop stealing.
Despite the film's heavy-handed effort at vindication, Renner manages to deliver a performance that is complex and satisfyingly contradictory.
There's never really terribly much at stake here, except the success of one chubby nerd with dreams of nailing Puccini's "Nessun dorma." But maybe that dream is enough.
Watching "Addicted" is like eating Cheese Whiz straight from the jar. There's no nutritional value. It's kind of embarrassing. But it does satisfy a base craving for cheap, immediate sensation.

As a storyteller, Amalric is a master of manipulation, first leading the audience in one direction and then another.
"1,000 Times Good Night" has moments of both startling violence and breathtaking beauty.
A lovingly laid-back documentary about the charms, liquid and otherwise, of the traditional Irish watering hole.

Sure, "The Maze Runner" unravels a few mysteries, but it spins even more. Thomas, as it happens, isn't the only one dying of curiosity here. As the closing credits roll, you likely will be, too.

"Take Me to the River" includes just enough history of the civil rights era to lend it gravitas. The color-blind recording practices of studios like Stax were an anomaly at the time and are well worth noting.

It isn't terribly clear where the movie - or its hedonistic heroine - is going, but getting there is one wild ride.

Hoffman shines in a role that demands not showmanship, but a kind of complexity and contradiction that can be rendered only through the kind of dull character details that he excelled in, accumulating them from the inside out.

The movie, directed by Michael Rossato-Bennett, makes a powerful argument for the program.

Franco keeps you in your seat, mainly by harnessing the power of Haze ...
The final destination of "A Five Star Life" is well worth the wait, but the service is so slow that some viewers may check out early.
On camera, Jones acts as a sort of safari leader, hacking away at the thicket of thorny contradictions that surrounded Fela, in the hopes of shaping a coherent yet honest portrait of the man.
The film pays scant attention to [its] stated goal, relegating the discoveries achieved by Cameron's mission to a brief on-screen title at the very end of the film.
It's more deeply satisfying and complex than similar, Hollywood-produced fare - like fine wine compared with Kool-Aid.

movie_review_blurb: In numerous interviews that careen from profane braggadocio to tender reminiscence, the lustily bisexual Wojtowicz comes across as almost bizarrely self-satisfied.
When it comes down to fourth and goal, the movie is more about moving the pigskin than moving the audience.
"Rich Hill" doesn't just make you feel like you know these boys; it makes you care about them.
While certainly no love story, this dry-eyed tale feels achingly, maybe even exhilaratingly alive.
"Life of Crime" feels like a rambling car ride through the countryside with friends. The scenery is great, and the passengers are diverting, but you keep wondering where the driver is headed.
If this nonsense is the stuff of nightmares for most modern teenage girls, who seem genetically predisposed to roll their eyes at anything a parent or teacher does, I'd be very surprised.
Like figures in a funhouse that is both philosophical and phantasmagoric, the characters in "The One I Love" spook you, both inside your head and inside your heart.

The actors have an obvious rapport. It's deep enough to evoke the ties, entanglements and bloodletting of a real kinship. But Wiig and Hader's instincts as entertainers are keen enough to know when to stop cutting.
Ennis is an optimist at heart, and his belief that one person can make a difference is infectious, if naive.
To be sure, the movie has plenty of laughs, but like sunlight on the deceptively calm surface of the sea, its light humor dances fitfully over dark and dangerous undercurrents.
Heedless of purpose, "Horns" charges full speed ahead anyway, ramming its high-concept hooey down your throat until the only heat you feel is from indigestion.
The real appeal of "Big Hero 6" isn't its action. It's the central character's heart.
Ribeiro has an uncanny eye for the telling emotional gesture, and "The Way He Looks" is full of them.
The film's patina of richly textured grime lends the film a gloomy, claustrophobic beauty that serves its mood, as well as its satisfyingly misanthropic message ...
Like the rookie who knows that you have to make a few mistakes while following the master, the movie shrugs off its missteps with a wink and a smile that makes them easy to forgive.
If you have to ask yourself whether this film is for you, it isn't.
You've got to love a thing to skewer it as thoroughly as Taika Waititi and Jemaine Clement do in their delightfully silly vampire mockumentary "What We Do in the Shadows."
movie_title: What We Do In The Shadows (2015)

movie_review_blurb: The half-dozen chapters vary in length and subject matter, but not in style or the efficiency of their message.
It staggers, zombielike, from one jump-scare to another before petering out, a scant 83 minutes after rising from the slab.
Like Chappie, the movie seems human, but has a cold metal heart.
Enchants on every level: story, voice work, drawing and music.
This hybrid vehicle may take a unwise detour here and there - even hitting a mud-filled pothole or two - but in the end you just might find that it's been an entertaining ride.
As you watch the rest of Gabriel London's compelling film unfold, your opinion about the sanity of its titular subject may change, more than once.
movie_title: The Life And Mind Of Mark Defriest (2015)

movie_review_blurb: A little too silly to be taken seriously, yet also too heavy to get all the laughs it very clearly craves, "Queen and Country" at least shows where Boorman's schizoid, if less than wholly satisfying, sense of storytelling comes from.
The relationship between Alex and Eva is sweet, and it grounds the film, even if certain secrets about it are telegraphed by the script.
The movie is the cinematic equivalent of junk food. It satisfies the craving for the sensation of nihilism, without its substance.
"It Follows" is one of the scariest movies I've ever seen. It's also one of the most beautiful.
Although Woodley is adequate at emoting - Tris being something of a basket case of guilt, self-loathing and teenage hormones - many of the other characters here are, by definition, one-dimensional.
In the end, "An Honest Liar" becomes a far more layered tale than it starts out to be.
Weber's main point - that bullies are often victims of bullying themselves - gets lost in a tsunami of sorrow and sadism.

The film's brutality - which includes not only the murder of a dog but also a fetishization of torture that borders on porn - is so excessive, even if tongue-in-cheek, that it leaves a bad taste in the mouth.
There's little payoff in trying to make sense of the various plot threads. The logic holes in this film are several, and the more you dwell on them, the less fun you will have.
Without at least the tawdry pleasure of a little bodice ripping, the film moves along sluggishly, even though it is well acted and handsomely shot.
One of the most visually unattractive movies I've ever seen.
Perry's acerbic sense of the literary/academic lifestyle - which, oddly enough, involves less actual writing and teaching than drinking and "thinking" - is both exceptionally funny and deeply sad.
"Rosewater" doesn't hector, nor does it giggle about the issue of press freedom. It's an impressive and important piece of storytelling.
Its minor thrills come not from not knowing what will happen, but from watching the cagey choreography of two acrobatic minds.
It's a nature film with a very personal entry point. Two, really. The fate of these birds, which, the film tells us, could live into their 40s, becomes as engrossing as many a human drama.
A delightfully silly star turn for this quartet of absurd little birds, who operate as a team of commandos.
"Miss Julie" is a strangely clinical movie experience. It's a story that makes an impression without leaving a mark.
It is the simple glimpses of ordinary life in an extraordinary place that are the most stirring moments in the film.
The air inside the pyramid isn't the only thing that's stale in this ludicrous yet mildly likable horror film.
It's a movie about a young man with an unhealthy mother fixation, but if you go into it expecting something closer to "Mommie Dearest" than "Psycho," you'll probably have a much better time.
With its mixture of frights both literal and literary, "The Babadook" will, I suspect, satisfy horror's devotees as much as the genre's doubters.
Jackson's storytelling at this point is so driven by green-screen trickery and digital legerdemain that he seems to have forgotten about human emotion.
movie_title: The Hobbit: The Battle of the Five Armies (2014)

movie_review_blurb: Other than some stock establishing shots of London, the British setting is wasted, as are Ben Kingsley and Ricky Gervais, who, at times, seem almost embarrassed to be caught on camera.
movie_title: Night at the Museum: Secret of the Tomb (2014)

movie_review_blurb: The truest testament to the film's strength is the degree to which it all but achieves greatness.
Not quite documentary, yet by no means drama, "Inside the Mind of Leonardo" is what might be called poetic biography: maddeningly fragmentary and idiosyncratic, but 100 percent true.
It's a haunting story of love between two misfits who shouldn't be together.
movie_title: A Girl Walks Home Alone at Night (2014)

movie_review_blurb: "Uneasy lies the head that wears a crown," Shakespeare wrote. But is that true when the coronet is no more than a backward ballcap balancing a pair of wraparound shades?
At just over an hour, it's a surprisingly satisfying and tasty dish for anyone looking for something a bit less bland than the typical history documentary.
The characters in "Spare Parts" all go through changes that are true to many immigrants' decidedly mixed experiences in the American melting pot.
"Spanish Lake" offers an instructive look at the forces that have shaped a single troubled community - economically, racially and otherwise.
"The Purge: Anarchy" obeys a cardinal law of Hollywood: Shoot first and ask questions later.
Somewhere in here, there's a pretty decent movie.
"Monday at 11:01 a.m." would probably work well as a half-hour television episode or a short story.
It's pretty darn good.
While "Last Men in Aleppo" could stand a trim here and there, it mostly uses its length to good and heart-rending effect ...
Stenberg and Robinson are enormously appealing young actors, but charisma only goes so far in a story that manages to be, as directed by Stella Meghie, sterile and wildly far-fetched.

"Pirates of the Caribbean: Dead Men Tell No Tales" remains true to its Disney theme park roots. Loud, overstimulating and hard to take in all in one sitting, it feels like the vacation that you'll need a vacation from.
movie_title: Pirates of the Caribbean: Dead Men Tell No Tales (2017)

movie_review_blurb: "I've stranded myself," Howard laments, as the film nears its open-ended climax. So, too, does "Wakefield," unfortunately.
For much of its brisk running time, "It Comes at Night" teeters between delicious atmosphere and almost unbearable tension.
I wouldn't call "Band Aid" profound, but it's wiser and deeper than the average pop song, if not by much.
In the end, "The Book of Henry" falls apart in a heap of loose pages, each one taken from a different script.
"Cars 3" feels like it may be time for a trade-in.
What little dancing we do see is lovely to watch, but it's also lovely to see a performer who once seemed to have an iron grip on the barre finally learn how to be gracious and let go.
In addition to presenting a parable about the collapse of society, Amirpour's film is also a kind of postmodern Adam-and-Eve story.
Hawke is good at playing bad, but Hawkins is better, rendering, in "Maudie," a portrait of a woman that feels raw, real and revelatory.
A movie that's cut like the world's longest and most tedious trailer, pinballing from scene to scene and rarely spending more than a few seconds on any single shot.

"Sami Blood" is a beautiful, haunting film, anchored by a startlingly accomplished lead performance. It has the feeling of a distant memory - one that is neither entirely pleasant nor painful, but persistent.
"Despicable Me 3" disappoints, if only mildly, not because it's bad, but because it only aspires to be good enough.
An authentic, refreshingly nerdy and high-spirited reboot of the well-worn Marvel franchise ...
A psychological portrait of resistance, made all the more timely - and creepily, almost offensively, unsettling - given the current political climate in the United States.
"King Arthur: Legend of the Sword" is a fun, if sacrilegious, first step in a franchise creation - one that observes the first commandment of storytelling: Thou shalt not be boring.
movie_title: King Arthur: Legend Of The Sword (2017)

movie_review_blurb: It's crazy and ridiculous at times. But I can't help agreeing with Assaf, who observes, of his companions' rescue plans, "I like it. It has the logic of a dream."
movie_title: My Entire High School Sinking Into the Sea (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Guardians of the Galaxy Vol. 2 is a toe-tapping, eye-popping indication that summer is here, and that it might not suck after all.
Fans of haunted-house movies may be disappointed. But anyone who knows the depth of grief ... will feel the chills that this movie delivers deep in their bones.
There ought to be no lack of firepower in telling this shameful tale. Too often, however, "Bitter Harvest" is guilty of overkill.
It has, simultaneously, the exhilarating feel of a departure and the finality of a full stop.
It may not sound like it, but calling this barely 70-minute Swiss stop-motion film "heavy" - as in substantial and almost swollen with feeling - is a true compliment.
movie_title: My Life as a Zucchini (Ma vie de courgette) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: A moribund movie that doesn't have a spontaneous, surprising - or genuine - bone in its body.
It's likely to leave viewers in a state of Documentary High Dudgeon (that brand of cinematic outrage that is not entirely unmixed with a pleasurable feeling of moral superiority).

Depending on how you take your twee - sparingly or, as is the case in this preciously concocted tale of English misfits, slathered like marmalade over a crumpet - it will either delight or quickly cloy.
There's a story here, all right, but it's a heartless and bitter one.
Life has cool effects, real suspense and a sweet twist. It ain't rocket science, but it does what it does well -- even, one might say, with a kind of genius.
Lowery pushes the tropes of the haunted house film past the breaking point, creating something that is entirely original - and oddly, if not profoundly unsettling.
Solid yet subtly sphinxlike ...
movie_title: After the Storm (Umi yori mo mada fukaku) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: "Frantz" contains revelations unrelated to the manner in which it protects, and then peels away, its central mystery. Ultimately, it addresses the question: Why go on living when life itself betrays us?
"Gifted" is a clever, if less than brilliant film. Like Mary, its true genius lies not in what's on the page, but in its humanity.
"Your Name" is still highly watchable, even when this mystical Young Adult love story cloys - or confounds.
For a movie with so much heart, "Queen of the Desert" is a remarkably bloodless enterprise.
There's a subdued quality to watching golf as a spectator sport, and that same quality of reserved detachment applies to this golf movie.
"Truman" avoids preachiness as scrupulously as it evades certainty.

Handsome Devil succeeds in delivering a far more satisfying examination of masculinity than before, presenting an encouraging message for teenagers to not be bound by stereotype if it feels unnatural to them.
[A] movie ... solidly constructed by American documentarian Ryan Suffern.
Although very little happens in the way of traditional horror-movie jump-scares, "Blackcoat" builds and builds toward a profoundly disquieting sense that something really bad is coming.
Evidence would suggest that it's the creators of this rope-a-dopey farce who took too many blows to the head.
Dorfman ... makes for a lively and loquacious subject ...
movie_title: The B-Side: Elsa Dorfman's Portrait Photography (2017)

movie_review_blurb: There is more candy here, of the retinal variety, than a jumbo bag of Airheads.
movie_title: Valerian and the City of a Thousand Planets (2017)

movie_review_blurb: In his most bracing and maddening morality tale yet, Lanthimos doesn't so much paint himself into a corner as he runs into it, headlong, dragging us with him all the way.
movie_title: The Killing of a Sacred Deer (2017)

movie_review_blurb: It may sound as if the movie is only for 13-year-old boys, or the Marvel faithful, but it isn't.
Betts has put together a talented acting ensemble, and the performances are, for the most part, uniformly good and subtle, particularly among the actresses who play the young novices.
The film by writer-director Francis Lee, who grew up on a Yorkshire farm before turning to acting - and, later, filmmaking - is sweet, even if Johnny is not.
Miller's weird, antiheroic Flash is one of the most refreshing breezes to blow through Justice League, making three years seem a long time to wait for the character's 2020 stand-alone film.
This sweet, affectionate (and unapologetically slight) comedy is an all-too-rare homage to harmless, hilarious incompetence, at a time when there is plenty of the more hurtful kind to go around.
[A] well-acted, yet pointless and, most disappointingly, dull tale of lust.
The film softens the bouts of cruelty with an abiding sense of humane, if absurdist, comedy, smoothing out the tonal shifts that may have you gasping in horror one minute and laughing the next.
Everything and everyone has a price, the film suggests, in ways that are far from subtle, but effective.
movie_title: All the Money in the World (2017)

movie_review_blurb: "The Commuter" may be set on the way home after a long, hard day at the office, but this movie feels less like happy hour than work - and uncompensated overtime at that.
More often than not, "12 Strong" feels like a sports movie, where all the stakes rest not on matters of honor and duty, but on a single field goal.
Every frame of Inti Briones's starkly gorgeous black-and-white cinematography ... hints at an inherent contradiction, either visually, in the narrative or in its larger themes.
There's an implicit social critique here, as there often is in Haneke's work.
A slow, talky and only faintly moving meditation on mortality and memory.
Its message isn't subtle, but it is delivered with deadly, haunting finality.
It's a fascinating story, if one that has been told before.
The whole thing has the air of a cynical, low-quality knockoff of something that wasn't very good to begin with.

The film is long ... but the cumulative effect is not exhaustion or boredom, but rather sorrow and outrage at the violence, economic despair and persecution - whether religious, ethnic or political - that have driven these people from their homes.
Set up like a suspense thriller, with on-screen titles that count down the minutes - not days or weeks - "The King's Choice" has the feel of a film that probably played better in its native country.
The special effects are impeccable, and include sequences that blur the line, evocatively, between what's real and unreal.
The tale of Queen Victoria and Abdul Karim ... is one that's good and true and worth telling. But the way that "Victoria and Abdul" slops it around is - mostly - hogwash.

"Dunkirk" bolts out the gate not like a thoroughbred racehorse, but like a pack of them, never stopping until - thunderingly, and with a feeling that encompasses both victory and defeat - it crosses the finish line.
Ultimately, "Atomic Blonde" is, like its heroine, something of a machine.
Provost's film is, in the end, a story about attaining the wisdom that comes from forgiveness and the acceptance of those things - namely the past and the future - that none of us can control.
Covers much of the same ground of the first film, but with a tone that feels, at times, midway between a sense of resignation and despair.
movie_title: An Inconvenient Sequel: Truth To Power (2017)

movie_review_blurb: "Escapes" is an eccentric portrait of a not especially eccentric - or even terribly interesting - subject ...
Sandberg knows how to ratchet up suspense, composing shots filled with beautiful shadows, in whose corners there always seems to be lurking something scary ...
Round about the third act, "The Only Living Boy in New York" veers wildly off whatever course it had been on, leaving the realm of the improbable for the preposterous.
movie_title: The Only Living Boy in New York (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Despite all the mayhem, "The Hitman's Bodyguard" is a surprisingly bland dish.
"War for the Planet of the Apes" may have the body of an action film, but it has the soul of an art-house drama and the brains of a political thriller.
movie_title: War for the Planet of the Apes (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Plaza, of course, is marvelous in the title role, embracing Ingrid's unflattering neediness with a commitment that's scary.
As Polina, Shevstova delivers a performance that feels wonderfully unforced, if that's the right word, in a role that can only be called "driven."

This very thinly sliced character study of beautiful if benighted adolescence is more a pre-coming-of-age tale, one that takes us close to, but not through, the transformative acquisition of good judgment.
Call it a symphony of orchestral meta-horror, an elaborate waking nightmare in which you, as the dreamer, are constantly reminded of what the film is trying to do, and yet are powerless to stop it.

In tone, "School Life" feels like a recruiting film for prospective students. It isn't exactly profound, except perhaps in the way it makes a case for the theory that happiness comes first, and then learning.
Tamarkin's point is clear: Women would do well to know their history before the future makes them regret it.
Often, "The Lego Ninjago Movie" feels like it's obeying the conventions of throwaway entertainment when it should be making more of an effort to comment on it.
Even as Cruise keeps us rooting for Barry, Liman reminds us that this is a story of bad guys.
The question that looms large here, lingering long after the closing credits, is whether, despite our human need for forgiveness, absolution is ever truly possible.
"Rumble" asks us to be still for a moment and to listen to the heartbeat - at once familiar and newly strange - that pumps the lifeblood that flows through the songs this country is known for.
movie_title: RUMBLE: The Indians Who Rocked the World (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Way late in the movie, by the time most thrillers have already begun parceling out a morsel or two of resolution, you will still be scratching your head and wondering just what in God's name is going on.
It's a story with heart, heady humor and action - parts that snap together, with a satisfying click, like, well, you know what.

It isn't easy to explain the appeal of the "John Wick" movies, and they are inarguably not for every taste, but there is a purity to them that transcends their barbarity and has something to do with the central character.
"The Man Who Knew Infinity" tells a great story. It's just that it's a little too by-the-book to make anything other than a so-so movie.
The story is slightly melodramatic, but director Paddy Breathnach finds ways to make it surprisingly moving at times, in the same way that he makes the Havana slums look paradoxically beautiful.
Tom Hiddleston's Dr. Robert Laing isn't so much a character as a machine part.
There's something admirable about the fact that "Being Charlie" exists at all. It's a testament to Nick Reiner's survival. That doesn't mean it's a great movie.
"Vaxxed" should come with a warning label: "May cause irrational anxiety, especially if taken with an empty head."
In short, the movie feels, if not exactly glamorous, then simultaneously overly processed and overwrought, even when it's wallowing in the most abased behavior.
At times, "Apocalypse" can be great fun, even if it doesn't know when to hand its car keys to a friend and ask to be taken home.

Plá, working from a spare yet jangly screenplay by Laura Santullo, steadily builds suspense, craftily calibrating subtle shifts in perspective that allow us to alternate, seamlessly, between impartial observers and, as it were, active participants.
movie_title: A Monster With A Thousand Heads (Un Monstruo de Mil Cabezas) (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Like a well-plated but nutrition-free meal, it registers on the senses while being bad for you.
movie_title: Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles: Out of the Shadows (2016)

movie_review_blurb: As Singleton puts it: "The battle to save the orangutan is not just the battle to save the orangutan. It's the battle for climate change. It's the battle for everything."
"The Conjuring 2" satisfies more than it disappoints.
The film is, at times, almost sinfully fun, assuming you have a taste for self-indulgently logic-free hedonism.
If Refn is trying to skewer our cultural fixation with youth and good looks, his blade isn't up to the task. "The Neon Demon" attacks, but indiscriminately.
Is "The Shallows" a thriller for the ages? No, but it's decent popcorn fare.
Just a respectful appreciation for the old-fashioned political thriller, in an adaptation by screenwriter Hossein Amini ("Drive") that knows how to get the job done.
You will probably find yourself bawling your eyes out - without ever knowing how you got to that state - at the film's profoundly, heartbreakingly somber conclusion.
movie_title: My Love, Don't Cross That River (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Why couldn't the film have found a way to be both relevant and funny, a la "Zootopia"?
Near the one-hour mark, the filmmaker asks, "You aren't tired of listening to me yet?" If you aren't, you will be soon.
Garrone has created a world of both rich and ugly textures - visual, narrative and imaginative - that transports, delights and imparts disturbing lessons.
movie_title: Tale of Tales (Il racconto dei racconti) (2016)

movie_review_blurb: "Nina" filters the singer's voice - and her life - through tinny-sounding speakers and an out-of-focus lens.

As "Louder than Bombs" inches slowly toward its quiet yet resounding conclusion, it raises intriguing questions about that thing that journalists care so deeply about, but that artists know to be a slippery thing: truth.
It's a voraciously self-aware comedy, one that dines out on the inherent inanity of its own premise as much as it does the movies it's competing with.
Plays out like a harrowingly bloody, real-life "Les Miserables."
movie_title: Winter on Fire: Ukraine's Fight for Freedom (2015)

movie_review_blurb: Larraín is clearly critical of the church. "The Club's" tone is cynical, bordering on the satirical, but it's never very funny. Not that it should be.
Like his 2012 film "A Hijacking," Danish writer-director Tobias Lindholm's drama "A War" explores the theme of moral compromise with an uncomfortably astringent honesty.
"Snowtime!" is off-puttingly grown-up for the audience it seems to court, while also simplistic to the point of tedium for anyone much older.
It's not just the animation that stirs, it's also the sound design.

Fans of Greenaway's work - a mix of the brainy, the controversial and the grotesque - won't necessarily be surprised by any of this. They may, however, be disappointed at how little of it actually works.
Goodman's performance, while unhinged, never veers into caricature. Similarly, Winstead avoids the cliche of the tank-top-wearing bimbo/victim, bringing an earthy self-reliance to her role.
"Microbe and Gasoline" doesn't reinvent the wheel, but it just might ride four of them into your heart.

The question is never what will happen to 10-year-old Anna (Kylie Rogers), who suffers a bloated belly and chronic pain. The only issue is how long she, and the audience, will have to wait to find out.

Nuance, subtlety, feeling - anything that might help an audience relate to what is happening rather than passively experience it, like a roller coaster - apparently are luxuries this movie could not afford.
In the end, the movie gives voice not just to Marguerite's deficiencies as a singer but also to emotional frailties that are too human and familiar.

The director allows us to inhabit not just Krisha's pill-induced zone-out but also her acute distress and, yes, guilt over her past behavior. It's slightly fussy, in-your-face filmmaking, but it's viscerally effective.
"I Saw the Light" isn't just incohesive, but ultimately - and far more frustratingly - incoherent.

Director Ilya Naishuller has said that he originally thought a 90-minute feature using the same technique was a bad idea, based on little more than a gimmick. It turns out he was right, but that won't matter to certain audiences.
Although genuinely gripping - at times, uncomfortably so - the tale of Lena and Daniel's efforts to escape from Colonia and expose its abuses suffers from a heavy-handed telling.
Like its brain-damaged protagonist, "Criminal" just shouts and shoots its way into, not out of, an oblivion of illogic, plot holes and emotionally unengaging scenery-chewing.
Anyone looking for the ferocious originality, and unexpected humanity, of "Blue Ruin" will be disappointed by Saulnier's uninspired cover version of a song we all know.
At times, I felt like I was out on a date with "Creative Control," only to find the movie kept checking its hair in the mirror every five minutes.
Earnest if rough-around-the-edges ...
"Lights Out" deserves to be considered in the company of such recent horror standouts as "It Follows," "The Babadook," "Goodnight Mommy" and "The Witch."
It may not boldly go where no "Star Trek" film has gone before, but it gets there at warp speed, and with a full tank of fresh ideas.
Manages to harvest not just understanding of one peculiar, broken little man, but a broader wisdom about the cycle of seasons that we all must endure on this planet.
The plot thickens, along with the emotional tension, which was always the best part of the Potter universe, and not the dazzling special effects.
movie_title: Fantastic Beasts and Where to Find Them (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Kennebeck may be a newcomer to feature filmmaking, but her grasp of the material is accomplished.
It's a tale bluntly told that arouses intense, evanescent emotion and then leaves you haunted, long afterward, by provocative but arguably answerable questions.

The dangerous sense of intrigue, potential betrayal and moral ambiguity - the very thing that keeps the film going for so long, and us on the edge of our seats - disappears, replaced by a slough of mawkishness ...

"Bad Santa 2" insults the intelligence and taste of the first film's audience by including all of the biliousness and vulgarity of the first film, but none - or precious little - of its scabrous joie de vivre.

Shot in black-and-white video, the 76-minute horror film benefits from crisp, striking visuals that are well framed and moodily lit. But that's about all this absurd, illogical and underwhelming thriller has going for it.
"Office Christmas Party" is an invitation to the kind of mind-and-conscience-erasing escapism that doesn't really exist outside of movie theaters.

Despite a solid central performance by film veteran Lynn Cohen and a Detroit setting that will please expats and current residents of the Motor City, there is little here to lift this film beyond its regional appeal.
Morbid comedy? Meditation on happiness? Theological allegory wrapped inside a silly joke? Maybe a little of all three.
movie_title: The Brand New Testament (Le tout nouveau testament) (2016)

movie_review_blurb: "Assassin's Creed" isn't quite as bad as one might fear, as measured against the abysmal track record of movies inspired by video games.
It sure takes [Scorsese] long enough to drive [his] point home - putting the film's audience through its own kind of torture - but the morale of his story is ultimately both tough and nuanced.

After dispensing with the sluggish setup of the film's first act, Berg shifts into high gear, powerfully evoking the feelings of dread and white-knuckle excitement that much of America no doubt felt as the manhunt progressed.
The movie falls oddly flat: less tantalizingly enigmatic "et cetera" than "blah blah blah."
"A Dog's Purpose" is hokey but harmless bunkum.

The most ironic thing about "Gold" is this: For all its efforts, the movie seems to know it's sitting on a gold mine of a backstory, but it just can't figure out how to get the stuff out of the ground.

Even if you agree with the film's argument that teenagers shouldn't be locked up for life when there are other ways to save them, "Monsters" doesn't offer a convincing argument that a screenwriting class is that lifeline.
Although it hints at the unhappiness - and, occasionally, outright hostility - that underlie humor, "The Comedian" never really seems all that interested in probing the comic's psychological wounds.
If only real life could so easily be realigned, by a singing pig.
The make-believe world of "Boy and the World" is confusing, scary and gorgeous. But then again, so is the real one.
movie_title: Boy and the World (O Menino e o Mundo) (2015)

movie_review_blurb: All in all, "Doctor Strange" is a fun and trippy excursion to a place where Marvel rarely seems to go: that is, to the retinal roots of the comics.
Uncomfortable squirms, not titillation, seem the only reasonable response to ... the whole point of the movie.
There's an appealing quaintness to the storytelling that calls to mind the Tintin books of the artist and writer Hergé, especially that series's old-world charm.
All this plays out at a breakneck pace that is paradoxically unengaging, despite the nonstop action.

In aiming for - but falling short of appealing to - the teenage demographic, the film is a double cop-out, disappointing both fans of the source material's grown-up gloom-and-doom aesthetic and discerning adolescents.
With a firm grasp on the duality implicit in its title, "Little Men" is a story that's neither tragic nor triumphal in the way it resolves itself, but rather one that's sadly, even satisfyingly true.
While "Pete's Dragon" does a fine job of evoking the delight one might feel at flying over hill and dale on the back of a mythological creature, it is less successful in rendering real human emotion.
This new "Ben-Hur" could just as easily have been called "Been There, Done That."
A saga that feels somehow both ancient and entirely fresh, at once steeped in the tradition of evocative Japanese poetry yet deeply, universally relatable.
As considerable as her gifts may be, Buy is ultimately unable to hold "Mia Madre" together.
"Inferno" takes itself way too seriously, even for a movie in which the quarry is a ticking time bomb in the form of a virus that, once unleashed, will kill half the planet.

The intimate, idiosyncratic and very funny Buffalo '66 --directed by and starring Vincent Gallo, from a semi-autobiographical script co-authored with Alison Bagnall --feels like a projection of Gallo's very psyche.
What saves it, paradoxically - even, at times, delightfully - from skidding off course into cliche is the profound appeal of its middle-of-the-road, but never dull, protagonist.
The movie is at its best when it recreates what it must feel like to be in a constant state of paranoia and pain. If only that feeling were accompanied by one or two other emotions.
"Storks" delivers its package, but it's a bundle of just-okay, not joy.

Far from being a historical cautionary tale, "Command and Control" looks forward, not backward. Kenner's unsettling film casts its worried gaze not at the accidents that already have taken place, but at the ones yet to happen.

The very idea of this - at once gruesome and darkly funny - is perfectly suited to Burton's sensibility, which also reveals itself in the casting of Butterfield, who has the quality of a young, slightly less freaky Johnny Depp.
movie_title: Miss Peregrine's Home for Peculiar Children (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Like the inspiration for its title, there's a wild sweetness to the people - and maybe even to the land - depicted with such breathtaking honesty and raw beauty in "American Honey."
"Long Way North" combines thrilling adventure with a slightly somber mood. It's a beautiful trip, even if it's a little chilly and sad when it finally gets to where it's going.
movie_title: Long Way North (Tout en haut du monde) (2016)

movie_review_blurb: A great performance does not necessarily make for great tragedy, and "Christine" remains mired in the minutiae of its portrait of a doomed, bitter young woman.
If only the questions it asks were more involving, and not just philosophical window dressing on what is ultimately a fembot-in-a-cage action flick - albeit one with a nice bit of torque.

Though the setting is a retreat from the world, where not terribly much happens, within its confines Lorenzo gets an eye-opener about both human frailty and interconnectedness, courtesy of someone even more troubled than he is.
A droll, demented and slightly depressive tale of doomed love.
"Code Black" is a powerful and quietly damning film.
The way Techine holds them up to the film's unforgiving light, they sometimes seem less like people than like insects in a jar.
"The Well-Digger's Daughter" feels decidedly, almost defiantly, old-fashioned, but not necessarily in a bad way.
A useful primer, though it also focuses a bit more on the activism than on the art.
Anyone with an expectation of reality, or an aversion to mawkish melodrama, should probably stay home.
movie_title: The Odd Life of Timothy Green (2012)

movie_review_blurb: Just about the time that Robot starts to grow on his curmudgeonly client, so may this movie -- a sci-fi fantasia that's surprisingly sweet and old-fashioned -- win over any skeptics.
The movie seems destined to irritate the president's supporters while mobilizing his detractors, even as it is doomed to win precious few converts. It's a textbook example of preaching to the choir.
What started as a long, elaborate joke becomes a journey, both for Gandhi's students and for the filmmaker himself.
Somehow manages to feel sprawling and epic, while at the same time presenting an intimately observed view of two women's love lives.
A strange, and not entirely successful, hybrid of a kiddie story and dark, mature themes.
It's a sour, only fitfully funny affair, wasting the abilities of its otherwise talented cast, which includes Kirsten Dunst, James Marsden, Adam Scott and Isla Fisher.
"Switch," a thorough and sober-minded documentary about the past, present and future of energy, is refreshingly free of hot air.

A dear film, sentimental and fond, full of beautifully acted British resolve.

movie_review_blurb: An odd little movie and a good one, worthy for what it is and potentially groundbreaking for how it's being made available.

Eighty-five minutes you'll never get back.

The leaps of faith Midnight Kiss demands are many. Among them: If Vivian acts the way she does on their arranged date, why does Wilson worry about impressing her, even for a second, even on New Year's Eve?
movie_title: In Search of a Midnight Kiss (2008)

movie_review_blurb: It tells a good, snakelike story, slithering in some unpredictable directions.

On screen, delusional schmoes are more fun than smart people, and in the latest film from Joel and Ethan Coen, the imperious former spook played by John Malkovich accuses his blackmailers...of heading a league of morons.

My kid went with it, and I had a fairly good time, as I waited for the reappearance of a marble-mouthed peasant tart, voiced by Jennifer Coolidge. Half the time her line readings are hilarious, and it's impossible to know why.
For all its digitally effected chaos, the cinematic threat level in Eagle Eye never even comes close to orange.
Sollett works easily and well with Cera and Dennings, and lends a touch of awkward realism to what, from a screenwriting perspective, is pure formula.
The figures in Blindness have no names; that's how deep into the Valley of Allegory we are.
Mortensen should certainly do another western, soon. Preferably he should do one with a real sense of danger to go along with all the neat, tidy, highfalutin' honor and decency.
It works from a specific place and lets audiences relate to that place, and the people in it, like trusted intimates.
[The filmmakers] create a sharply realized and fantastically rich underground city.

I don't want to oversell The Rocker, but in a summer of erratic, assaultive comedies all up and down the budget scale, this Rainn Wilson vehicle -- a kind of Home School of Rock -- stakes out its own corner of the market.
There's nothing to Cloverfield, really, but stripped-down chaos shot in a faux-verite Blair Witch Project fashion...But I have to say, I was with it.
Thompson, Goode and Atwell make for fine screen company, despite [Emma]Thompson's arguable miscasting.

The trick to the Men II Boyz comic genre -- where grown men are simply older, pudgier versions of their teen selves, struggling to find their place in the world -- is to find the surprises and payoffs within the Peter Pan syndrome.
A lot of the picture veers uneasily between solemnity and slapstick and 47 different genres.
movie_title: Indiana Jones and the Kingdom of the Crystal Skull (2008)

movie_review_blurb: A kinetic delight, Reprise comes from director Joachim Trier, born in Denmark but raised in Oslo, Norway, and it's a highlight of the filmgoing year so far.

Some filmmakers can imagine everything and select nothing, and while it's clear as a bell Tarsem has more talent than almost any 10 directors put together, in The Fall he's basically showing off with every new wondrous image.
Everything about Kung Fu Panda is a little better, a little sharper, a little funnier than the animated run of the mill. It's one of the few comedies of 2008 that knows what it's doing.

Incredible overstates it, but The Incredible Hulk finds a viable way to retell an old Jekyll and Hyde story, dating back to the early 1960s and a Cold War that inspired its share of unruly Marvel Comics misfits.
After the insufferably dense mermaid mythology of Lady in the Water, Shyamalan clearly wanted to keep things simple. He whizzed straight past simple to simplistic.
Savage Grace is content to glide along, and while its key performances are intelligent, none of the writing activates these real-life characters fully.
War, Inc. has that provocateur's edge, and it's at least awake to the world around us.
War, Inc. has that provocateur's edge, and it's at least awake to the world around us.

The film has a bit of the overdetermined, cosmic-coincidence quality you find, for example, in a work like Babel. These are troubled people caught in the grip of fate, yet Akin, I think, has the skill and the insight to make do with a little less p
movie_title: Auf der Anderen Seite (The Edge of Heaven) (On the Other Side) (2007)

movie_review_blurb: We're talking 15 or 20 minutes of decent material. The movie runs a little longer than that.
Missed it by that much. Actually, the new version of Get Smart misses by a fair-size margin. It's too bad. It's just trying to give us a good time at the retroplex.
The director guides the viewer through a sly consideration of near-sociopathic not-quite-lovers, one of whom finds refuge in religion, the other in romantic obsession.
movie_title: The Duchess of Langeais (Ne Touchez Pas La Hache)(Don't Touch the Axe) (2007)

movie_review_blurb: A grandly kitschy rendering of Genghis Khan's early years, the ones revealing how a boy became a ruthless yet humane warrior, devoted family man and all-around good fellow, Mongol might as well be called Braveheart in a Yurt.
The story is both a muddle and a drag, having to do with stem cell research and regeneration and missing limbs and a fraught psychic, and that's enough detail for the purposes of this review.
movie_title: The X-Files: I Want to Believe (The X Files 2) (2008)

movie_review_blurb: It's remarkable to see any film, in any genre, blend honest sentiment with genuine wit and a visual landscape unlike any other.
Much of what Maddin asserts as truth is balderdash. He was not, for example, born in the locker room of the local hockey team's arena.
Finding Amanda, the alternate title of which might well have been "I Oughta Be in Rehab," is an uneasy chronicle of addiction and denial wrapped in the rhythms of Neil Simon.
In this highly superheroic summer of Iron Man and the forthcoming The Dark Knight, Hancock can offer only an A-list headliner in a D-list project.
As driven by linguistics and euphemism as this film is, it's also a slippery and wonderfully acted drama%u2014Michael Clayton with a far more troubling moral landscape.
Striving for low-key character comedy, Diminished Capacity ends up diminishing its returns.
It's a sharp mixture of neorealist grit and lyricism.
I can barely keep up with the mythology put forth by the Hellboy series, but I enjoyed the first film, and I enjoyed the new one.
I can't tell you how this film looks in 2-D, which is how the majority of the nation's customers will partake of it. I saw it in 3-D. I liked it. It's dopey, but I liked it.
movie_title: Journey to the Center of the Earth (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Better material and more adept direction might've made this a perfectly solid commercial enterprise.
Werner Herzog is a magnet for obsessives, and his lovely new film, Encounters at the End of the World, takes you places an ordinary filmmaker might've gone to yet missed completely.
movie_title: Encounters at the End of the World (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Under the direction of Guillaume Canet, who adapted Harlan Coben's English-language best seller with Philippe Lefebvre, this is a splendid ensemble doing its level best to keep the audience guessing all the way through an increasingly knotty narrative.
movie_title: Ne le Dis à Personne (Tell No One) (2006)

movie_review_blurb: Nolan paints an inky portrait of a city falling apart, and in a movie rife with two-faced masquerading freaks, the Joker is merely the least conflicted of the bunch. Ledger's work is improbably droll, impossibly creepy, meticulously detailed.
Space Chimps sucks a whole lot of talented people into a wormhole of lousy.
Everything's in twinkle overdrive. As with most stage-to-screen transfers, about a half-hour of material has been excised, and Mamma Mia! never had that much story to begin with.
If you went for Sin City or Shoot 'Em Up, you'll probably enjoy Wanted. I like my trash with a little less fetishism when it comes to instruments of slaughter.
For reasons they'll have to go to hell for someday, the Motion Picture Association of America ratings board gave Once an R, for a handful of swear words. Ignore that. And enjoy the film.
With its themes of selflessness and grace, as well as its graceful intertwining of comedy and pathos, this is a fine time for a revisit.
This one has focus trouble, canvassing too many countries, too many issues, and the filmmaking is on the ordinary side.
The salacious close-ups of saucepans and gnocchi and quail guarantee it: After seeing No Reservations you'll be hungry for a really top-flight meal. And, to go with it, a better film.
It's heartening to see anyone pull off any sort of comedy along these classically established lines.
Feels constrained and rather dutiful, no matter how passionate these people are about what they're observing.
Incoherent and semi-vile.
A hell of a show.
And I thought I Now Pronounce You Chuck & Larry was hypocritical.
Burnett's documentarian empathy, coupled with his easygoing skill as a dramatic essayist, result in a film that doesn't look, feel or breathe like any American work of its generation.

Watching bear cubs and walrus pups struggling to survive against increasingly tough odds, and on ever-slushier ice shelves, has both its shamelessly manipulative side and its dramatically necessary side, as handled here.

Stardust piles on the conflict and the bombast.
Even the most ardent Herzog admirer may want to hail this fledgling documentarian a cab and call it a day.
Director and co-writer Laurent Tirard's pleasant but tame approach to his birth-of-a-major-world-dramatist portrait has its virtues.
Janssen is an intense screen presence. Too often she's stuck playing humorless towering antagonists. Here, happily, she's allowed to be a real person.
[No End in Sight] may be the best and saddest film of the year so far.

The comic peaks of Superbad deal in specific characters rather than easily pegged stereotypes. Their most outlandish verbal riffs -- none of which can be quoted -- give the edgiest stuff in Knocked Up a run for its money.
[It's] far from the worst thriller of the year, but it's wholly lacking in reasons for being.
The harsh and lovely achievement of Bruno Dumont's Flanders is its mixture of the concrete and the abstract. It isn't about a specific war. It's about conflict of every stripe, in any time.
Live television going down in flames is always good for a laugh.
movie_title: 12:08 East of Bucharest (A fost sau n-a fost?) (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Jeffrey Blitz's Rocket Science doesn't quite work but is worth seeing anyway.
The film is easy to take, though it must be said: It's almost 100 percent blather.
The casting is all fine; everything else is pushy and out of joint.
Delpy's skill, which is considerable and wide-ranging, points to better, fuller films in her directorial future.
If it gets people thinking about which light bulbs they buy and their current gas mileage and such, then it's good to have it in the world. It is, however, a panicky blur as documentaries go.
If music were all, Gypsy Caravan would be amazing. As is, it's worth seeing, but you may get frustrated at the way Dellal raises provocative questions about ancestry and prejudice...
movie_title: When the Road Bends: Tales of a Gypsy Caravan (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Too often in Mr. Bean's Holiday, you get the feeling Rowan Atkinson and his collaborators confused the notion of 'building a gag slowly' with 'forgetting to build one at all'.
With its gore-comix sensibility and self-conscious flashes of nudity, Trapped Ashes clunks along, and (to be completely petty) never really overcomes its clunky title.
It's refreshing to see a bit of escapism that takes place in contemporary Southern California as seen, and lived, by those uninterested in aping the Ocean's 13 vibe of ice-coolness.
Lapica isn't yet enough of a writer or director (or an actor) to make the dramatic arc unpredictable in any way. It may be effective for some as therapy. It is far less so as cinematic storytelling.
Those who have a deeper abiding love for the western genre than I, may love the new Yuma. I liked a good deal of it -- just enough to be frustrated by the clutter.
The Simpsons Movie is comparatively minor. But it's hard not to like it. And in both senses of the phrase, America keeps asking for it.
If Dugan's crude, occasionally effective effort ends up chipping away at America's moron class regarding gay rights, that'll be nice. But even unrepentant homophobes deserve funnier.
movie_title: I Now Pronounce You Chuck & Larry (2007)

movie_review_blurb: As mile-high-wig musicals go, the film version of Hairspray is less polished but more fun than Dreamgirls. Both are drag revues at heart, one funny, the other serious. I prefer the funny one.
A promising first film with moments exceeding that promise.
Funny and scary in deftly equal measure.
Apatow's awfully sharp as a chronicler of contemporary romantic anxieties.
Thirteen is all about maintaining a barely perceptible smirk behind an impassive pose. The line between cool and cold is a thin one, however. Cool isn't the word for Thirteen; it's just smug.
You live in a free country, you put up with crud like Hostel Part II.

The film's vibe could only be described as 'sun-baked.' Some kids' movies don't try very hard, and you resent the laziness. This one doesn't try too hard, but its offhandedness is a break from the usual manic Over the Hedge-y attack.
It is passable comic book stuff, dumb and loud. Loud. LOUD.
movie_title: Fantastic Four: Rise of the Silver Surfer (2007)

movie_review_blurb: The film itself is more nice than good, but nice isn't the worst trait.
Wildly uneven. Fully half of writer-director Olivier Dahan's drama sticks to the surface, and even then, many of the factually accurate bits come off as Hollywood lies.

It's a good, solid scare picture, modestly scaled but well-crafted. And unlike certain other horror items on offer right now, this one doesn't make you feel like a psycho-in-training for sitting through it.
When Leoni's character learns what Frank does for a living, her look of puzzlement is marvelously subtle. You Kill Me has a lot of little moments like that.
A worthy film on a great, tragic subject.
The divine guidance afforded the title character does not extend to script doctoring.
The film may be animated, and largely taken up with rats, but its pulse is gratifyingly human. And you have never seen a computer-animated feature with this sort of visual panache and detail.
The not-funniest comedy of the year so far.

[Director] Ziv's relative sense of balance and context is admirable, though the whole thing may be too broadly focused to sharpen anyone's perceptions of this conflict. Then again, maybe that's too much to ask of any film on a horribly open-ended subject.
In its genre writer-director Sue Kramer's film sets a new record for bright shining peepers and dimply smirks. It's enough to kill Buster Keaton's entire family.
It's a better-than-average gay relationship film, largely because neither plot mechanics nor the same old camp intrude much.

I suspect [director Jonathan] King's next film will be better.
Conceptually outlandish but routinely executed, this comic exploration of macho, control-freaky power struggles the world over remains skin-deep.
movie_title: The Glamorous Life of Sachiko Hanai (2003)

movie_review_blurb: The most striking aspect of Harry Potter and the Order of the Phoenix is its contrast between the hormonally and supernaturally tormented teenager at its center and the modestly well-made and easygoing picture unfolding all around him.
movie_title: Harry Potter and the Order of the Phoenix (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Blessedly free of the usual biopic freight and sanctimony, the exuberant new film Talk to Me has a great subject and a great actor working in tandem.
Its tone is reflective, not combative, and it operates on a lulling rhythm, so that the jungles become either mesmerizing or a narcotic, depending on your blood sugar.
It lacks size and nerve where it's most needed: in the performances.

With a wry tone all his own (the writer-director calls his thesis 'absurd'), South Korea's Kim Ki-duk asks in his calmly assured spellbinder a simple question: How far can we go to transform who we think we are?
Bone-dry but completely assured, both in its visual strategy and its wry deconstruction of the workplace comedy genre.
movie_title: The Boss of it All (Direktøren for det hele) (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Near-classic modern science fiction.
The results may not seem to be taking place on planet Earth among verifiable humans, but, taken in the spirit of gladiatorial battle, the film is often fascinating.
A better, more focused effort than Fahrenheit 9/11 or Bowling for Columbine.
Even those wary of [director] To's eastern/western ethos cannot help but admire the stern panache of the best sequences.
Really, this thing is pretty rank.
The Brave One is Death Wish with a guilty conscience, and while it may be a bit of a hypocrite as vigilante thrillers go, the internal contradictions of the thing make for a very interesting picture.
While you may wish the superlatively talented cast of American Gangster had a classic to show for their efforts, a good modern gangster film is its own reward.
Redford confounds expectations, not politically but dramatically.
A breezy diary from a pair of first-time farmers, as well as a wry rebuke to a nation devoted to eating cheaply but not necessarily well, King Corn makes its points without much finger-wagging.

As pure craftsmanship, No Country for Old Men is as good as we've ever gotten from Joel and Ethan Coen.
As far as cinematic mythology goes, this film flies only so high. And call me anti-Geat, but I was rooting for Crispin Glover's Grendel all along.

The film is very sweet -- in fact it represents the dawn of a new sport, Extreme Whimsy -- but it doesn't look or feel like most other kid-friendly Hollywood products that make it to market. When it counts this fable is surprisingly moving.

Newell has done some fine work in all sorts of genres, from Four Weddings and a Funeral to Harry Potter, but in Cholera he seems to be chronicling a half-century of events, passions and desires as a tourist, not a native.
movie_title: Love in the Time of Cholera (2007)

movie_review_blurb: We're plunked down in the middle of an apocalyptic mess. This time the mess is not so much addressed as embodied by the film itself -- but damned if it doesn't roll around in your head a while.
[Amy Adams is] every Disney princess in one ebullient package.
Overstuffed, formulaic but very easy to take.

I appreciate Haynes' craft and ambition. I love the Ledger/Gainsbourg scenes, which are sweet and sad and delicately shaded. And Blanchett's inspired not-quite-impersonation of Dylan is reason enough to tussle with the rest of it.
Good and creepy, The Mist comes from a Stephen King novella and is more the shape, size and quality of the recent 1408.
Baumbach's achievement stings. It also has the sureness of tone and direction of a Chekhov story.
Ridley Scott created a triumph of retro-futuristic design over narrative or character richness.
It's one of the most queasy-making and confrontational films of the year, in which a deliberately artless presentation...takes the sting out of some extremely unruly content.
movie_title: It Is Fine! Everything Is Fine. (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Now and then you find a period picture that affords this sort of rightness of scale and satisfaction.
