Alvin and the Chipmunks goes in one eye and out the other, featuring a CGI Alvin, Simon and Theodore interacting with a human-ish world.
Director Tim Burton has found the right look and, more crucially, the right scale for his film version of the grandiose 1979 Broadway musical thriller.
movie_title: Sweeney Todd: The Demon Barber of Fleet Street (2007)

movie_review_blurb: It is wonderful: a rhapsodic adaptation of a memoir, a visual marvel that wraps its subject in screen romanticism without romanticizing his affliction.
movie_title: The Diving Bell and the Butterfly (2007)

movie_review_blurb: While "Walk Hard" makes for a fine soundtrack, it's less entertaining as a movie.
movie_title: Walk Hard: The Dewey Cox Story (2007)

movie_review_blurb: All you want from a movie like this, really, is a little brainless fun, and it keeps holding out on you.
Something doesn't smell right with Charlie Wilson's War. I'm not particularly concerned with the specific facts it has left out of its telling. But what has been left in feels compromised and dodgy.
Too much of the film is a muddle, and it feels like work, not play.

Director Denzel Washington's The Great Debaters is pure Hollywood, not without its share of storytelling cliches and golden-toned inspirational teaching moments, but you know what? The results really are inspirational.
Watanabe brings ferocious commitment to the sort of role that many an American awards body has been known to champion.
There Will Be Blood reminds us that the greatest screen performances don't settle for capturing one trait, a dominant emotion or an easy way in.
Lumet directs the script with the actor-centered efficiency that has served him well over a surprising array of projects.
movie_title: Before the Devil Knows You're Dead (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Nonjudgmental without being morally dense, the film makes human sense out of an inhuman example of addiction capitalism, '70s style.

While Eastern Promises works overall on more of a low, insinuating simmer, it's one of Cronenberg's most satisfying pictures.
It has the air of an officially sanctioned tribute rather than a probing study, but it's stirring all the same.
movie_title: In the Shadow of the Moon (2007)

movie_review_blurb: The film is some sort of humor-deprivation experiment.
If the director traffics in the realm of black comedy, any attempts to win us over or encourage sympathy or empathy with the rollicking hell-raisers on screen tend to give off a bad odor.
Freshman Orientation is not incompetently made. Nor is it badly acted. But there's not a fresh idea in it, and everyone on screen seems to be in a different comedy.
With an estimated 400,000 dead since 2003, and 2.5 million Sudanese left homeless in the wake of the genocide, ignoring the story doesn't seem like a humane option.
A small but droll big-box comedy.
This feast is more like an artfully arranged appetizer plate.
If Into the Wild falls short of giving McCandless an indelible cinematic life, the film gets under your skin anyway. It doesn't feel improvised, exactly, but it does feel inhabited.
The Kite Runner feels authentic in its ethnic tensions, even when the narrative itself, with its handily reappearing and easily avenged villain, undermines that authenticity.
This is one of the major disappointments of the film-going year.
However irregular the beat, this one has a heart.
It's one of the most satisfying films of the year, recalling a classy breed of studio film more common in the 1970s and the early '80s.
It's on the easygoing level of Surf's Up, and a full tick up from, say, Over the Hedge or The Ant Bully. But given the Seinfeld pedigree it's something of a disappointment.
The oddest major studio release of the year, and one of the most admirable.
movie_title: The Assassination of Jesse James by the Coward Robert Ford (2007)

movie_review_blurb: The story remains oddly unaffecting, and Gray's camera sense is visually lethargic outside the two big action sequences.

Consistently well-acted and, for a studio picture, pretty sharp on the subject of addiction and recovery and relapse.
movie_title: Things We Lost in the Fire (2007)

movie_review_blurb: I've seen the film twice. It is a wonder, marked by a sense of wondrous skepticism that has nothing to do with cynicism.
Ira & Abby has plenty of sharp details, mostly verbal, and it gives old pros and newer faces a chance to show off their poker-faced comic wiles.

You'll pardon me if I feeling like urping just a tiny bit at screenwriter Nancy Oliver's blend of pathos and heartland condescension.

Branagh, whose screen career with Shakespeare began on a high note with Henry V and has gone steadily downhill since, does a nice job keeping a stagebound piece relatively cinematic without resorting to the usual opening-up techniques.
The best efforts of the performers cannot authenticate a plot that no longer feels inevitable. It feels contrived. And the audience stays at a remove instead of entering someone else's nightmare.
The script is simple stuff, simpler than the graphic novel, which at least managed to devote a page or two to the vampires' back story.
A dour, fairly intriguing mystery based on the fourth book in a series of South Boston-set detective novels by Dennis Lehane.
A low-key, highly agreeable charmer.
Methodical and cool, this film is more artful sonnet than fanzine rave.
No one will have an easy time of it with Lake of Fire, a work of profound anguish centered on the abortion rights debate.

Monaghan's comic timing saves this go-nowhere affair from 100 percent lousiness, and I couldn't really tell you why; she doesn't earn any laughs, exactly; there are none, but she's charming and she makes tiny bits of a stuporous flop slightly less grim.
Another John Milton wrote: "Better to reign in Hell than to serve in Heaven." Cage's character would concur, heartily, before reloading.
It's a dark comedy about matters of the heart, and how far some people go to take their minds off such matters.
The mystery of Topher Grace's film career, and why it isn't better, continues with "Take Me Home Tonight."
The relative success or failure of "Adult Beginners," directed with a steady, nonjudgmental hand by Ross Katz, depends on how funny you find Kroll. I find him funny-ish.
The film, a sleek and oddly moving study in the cost of debauchery, has its gleeful excesses.

Entertaining as much of "Avengers 2" is, especially when it's just hanging out with the gang in between scuffles (the "Guardians of the Galaxy" lesson, learned), Whedon's picture meets expectations without exceeding them.

At its most palatable the film recalls "The Long Good Friday"; at its harshest, it's a grotty cousin to "The Bad Lieutenant." There's enough filmmaking intelligence to guide "Hyena" through its worst excesses, however.
The movie is small, but the actors make it seem larger, like binoculars turned around the right way.
There are no false notes anywhere in this cast of performers.
A good, solid version of this novel, guided by Mulligan, is still an achievement.

For big fans of the first "Pitch Perfect," the sequel will not aggravate or offend. But I swear, in one party sequence Kendrick appears to be stifling a yawn.
The actors are terrific. It's too bad, though, that co-writer, editor and director Brett Haley settles for so little.
movie_title: I'll See You in My Dreams (2015)

movie_review_blurb: I enjoyed large chunks of San Andreas, largely because the actors give it a full load of sincerity, and there's some bizarrely effective comic relief thanks to Hugo Johnstone-Burt and Art Parkinson as Brits who picked the wrong week to visit the Bay Area.
The first encounter among Cooper, McAdams and Stone is so awkward and unsettled that it becomes the movie's own albatross. There are some moments, most of them thanks to McAdams.

The fun of "Spy" comes in watching the right actors mess with their own images, blithely.
We've had plenty of good musical biopics ("Walk the Line," "Control") and a handful of better ones ("Sid and Nancy," the more recent "Get On Up"). This one's special, more inward-seeking.

Gomez-Rejon has a seriously promising future; this film is shot in a hundred different styles, reflecting the sentimental and cinematic education of its protagonist.
movie_title: Me and Earl and the Dying Girl (2015)

movie_review_blurb: This is straight-up commercial comedy, low-keyed division, and while it can't hold a candle to recent, dark-comic Israeli achievements such as Joseph Cedar's "Footnote," the actors more than save it.
Perhaps Pixar will never again reach the heights of its remarkable string of masterworks, "Wall.E," "Ratatouille" and "Up." The best of "Inside Out" comes close.
Holmes has a face that reveals everything and nothing. Besides being strikingly photogenic, she's a natural.

The tone of "Dope" is very interesting - funny, but rarely stupid-funny. The film does not wear its serious observations, about aspirations and realities and hypocrisies of all kinds (not just racial), in a heavy fashion.
I've seen worse comedies this year, and I'll see better.
The film grows into itself, and lovingly chronicles the celebratory meeting of these very different but ancestrally connected groups.
This time the jokes are heavier, more on-the-nose, though a surprising percentage of them work anyway.

Made on a reported (and mystifying, given its lack of visual imagination) budget of $170 million, Terminator Genisys doesn't take any pokes or try any dark satire in its technology-enslavement angle. This is strictly business, and dull business at that.
Like many, I have loved this thriller of conscience and betrayal most of my moviegoing life.
Time has proved its unassuming, unadorned craftsmanship - and Ryan's understanding of men pushed to the edge, never asking for an audience's sympathy, only our awareness.

The Infiltrator is a true-crime story, familiar but compelling, about false identities, affording Cranston the chance to play a man who is pretending to be another, more swaggering, more dangerous man.
Lin's movie works best when approached as a relaxed, somewhat playful two-hour expansion of one of the old '60s episodes.
There are scenes, typically the most destructive ones, that could be plopped into any old "X-Men" movie. But director Yates knows his way around this stuff.
movie_title: Fantastic Beasts and Where to Find Them (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Not every biopic needs to reinvent the form. Sometimes it's enough to inhabit it, engagingly.
The movie doesn't really work. The script is all too faithful to Fountain's florid brand of not-quite-human poetry. The thesis lines thud into place.

The film is bright, busy, enjoyable, progressive without being insufferable.
The material ends up cheapening the experiences of so many real-life veterans, which surely was not the filmmakers' intention.
At its best, "Seasons" shakes off its predecessors and captures the simple, grand ideas it's after purely visually.
Even if it lacks full dimension, and a final imaginative leap past the biopic strictures, "Jackie" pulls you into its web, shot by shot, moment by moment - most of them Portman's.
A little bit "Guardians of the Galaxy," a little bit "Dirty Dozen" in its mass wartime slaughter, and a pretty good time once it gets going.
movie_title: Rogue One: A Star Wars Story (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Chazelle is a born filmmaker, and he doesn't settle for rehashing familiar bits from musicals we already love. He's too busy giving us reasons to fall for this one.
The people in charge, on screen and off, know what they have here, and they don't get material like this very often in their careers.
It's just a mediocre action movie, poorly edited and larded with a terrible musical score, based on a video game. Nothing new there.
"Hidden Figures" is a fairly entertaining gloss of a docudrama elevated by its cast.
It's a crazy amount of ground to cover, but only rarely does 13th sacrifice clarity for cinematic energy.
The fine, quiet, carefully modulated ... "Loving" from writer-director Jeff Nichols is the opposite of a rabble-rouser.
"20th Century Women" doesn't get unduly hung up on plot, or even with the usual forward motion of a coming-of-age narrative. It's a group portrait of a makeshift family.
Nobody in cinema can rival the unique, electric combination of scowling power and exuberant physicality of Mifune.
"Live by Night" may look first-rate (though Affleck's direction, whether it's action or simply two people, seething, is routine) but it feels second-hand.
If you have any Broadway or Sondheim or show business in your bloodstream, you should go.
movie_title: Best Worst Thing That Ever Could Have Happened... (2016)

movie_review_blurb: "The Founder" gives anyone who has eaten at a McDonald's a few things to think about.

The semiretired superassassin killed 77 adversaries last time around. The numbers are similar here.
Watching "The Red Turtle" ... is like falling into an 80-minute wormhole of spare artistry.
The results offer a collective shiver (not a lot of shrieks here) for those in the mood for sprightly, short-form misfortune.
Touching, light-fingered ...
movie_title: 76 Minutes and 15 Seconds With Abbas Kiarostami (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Lassgard isn't the whole show, but he's most of it, and he's rock steady without being predictable, or falling into easy caricature, even when the movie veers that way.
movie_title: A Man Called Ove (En man som heter Ove) (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Parker sees the Nat Turner story as righteous wrath, straight, no chaser, not much characterization. Very likely, the real Turner was a more unruly, contradictory and human figure than the icon at the center of things here.

movie_review_blurb: [It] does a few smaller things right but the bigger things not quite. I've come to fear these movies.

Stars (the Carpenter version didn't have any) Ethan Hawke and Laurence Fishburne provide enough gravitas to keep things involving even as some of the supporting characters fight a losing battle with caricature.
A quintessential Hollywood story that might have just as easily been called Karma.

Nowhere to be found here is any of the goofy charm of the original.

Should have no trouble living up to its title at the boxoffice.
Certainly has the goods but it ultimately fails to make the sale.
An affectionate and intimate celebration of the acclaimed troubadour in stirring music and words.
An absolute delight from start to finish.

While the sunny production values and '70s bubblegum soundtrack carry the film up to a point, there's a more-of-the-same quality to the narrative that simply can't sustain its 36-chapter, 135-minute running time.
Painfully earnest but dramatically inert.

A considerably scaled down version that still effectively retains the book's warm eccentricity and gently persuasive sentimentality.

In trying to nail just the right mix of comic book action, comedy and pathos, the movie emerges as a tone-deaf mishmash of underdeveloped characters, half-baked humor and unhatched plotting drenched in CGI overkill.
A superbly acted, beautifully shot, highly engaging drama that ranks as one of Howard's best efforts.

Runs out of gas.
More Mirth Machine than Mean Machine, this agreeable remake still manages to go the distance.
Explosively funny.
Director Ken Kwapis coaxes convincing performances out of his youthful cast.

The latest installment could well be Romero's masterpiece.

An often imaginative though less than magical family feature.

movie_review_blurb: A bracingly candid documentary portrait of the artists in a career-defining transition, the film simultaneously offers a unique perspective of a nation at a similarly significant crossroads. It also happens to be a lot of fun.
movie_title: Dixie Chicks - Shut Up and Sing (2006)

movie_review_blurb: Guest's track record is hilariously intact with this buzz-worthy send-up of awards-season histrionics.
Passionate if prosaically rendered.

movie_review_blurb: When the picture gets around to its calculated socko ending, the viewer has long been pummeled into a state of numbness.

A skillful examination of the things people do when they think no one's looking.

movie_review_blurb: Takes the well-traveled concert film to exhilarating new heights.

Sorry Sly, not this time.

Could have been called How to Lose an Audience in 10 Minutes.

Tired, corn-fed storyline and generic, plug-and-play direction!
A little pretentious by the half-hour mark. An hour beyond that, medication begins to sound like an attractive option.
Overall, it's a pleasantly bearable experience.
Hampered by a flighty tone that wears mighty thin by the time the two-hour picture ... takes its final over-the-top turn.
An unexpectedly moving surprise!
A flimsily constructed knockoff, completely devoid of charm and even the merest flicker of originality.
The character work is strong, and the celebrity recruits are fun.
What begins promisingly ... quickly turns from wicked to insipid, taking a thematic plunge into insanity from which there is no recovery.
Ang Lee tries a little martial arts on for size with jaw-droppingly exhilarating results.
More preoccupied with themes and moods than providing anything intriguing plot-wise or character-wise for the viewer to truly care about.
Despite the concerted efforts of its Oscar pedigree cast to keep it real, Kevin Spacey, Helen Hunt and impressive young Haley Joel Osment unfortunately find themselves smothered by the schmaltz.
A crisply paced romp featuring pitch-perfect performances by adversarial leads Robert De Niro and Ben Stiller.
Uninspired end result.
Even at 90 minutes, the tottering Tuck sure feels everlasting.
The only truly offensive thing about Tomcats, a bottom feeder of a gross-out comedy desperately wanting to be the next Road Trip or American Pie, is how numbingly unfunny an hour and a half can be.
Admittedly has its moments of pop culture-skewering pleasure.
A smart, satisfying throwback to the days when editing still allowed for a little breathing room.
Manages to overcome an awfully slow start and sprint spryly to a highly satisfying finale.
Becomes one big yawn of uninspired battle sequences, half-baked plotting and ultra-clunky dialogue leading to a lame, tacked-on coda.
The initial, neatly sustained eerieness soon gives way to increasingly freaky plotting that seriously diminishes the picture's promising fear factor.
The spirit of MASH runs through this sharply observed, absurdly funny take on the folly of war.
A low-rent Waiting to Exhale that wages the battle of the sexes with precious little ingenuity and even less charm despite the efforts of an appealing ensemble led by Vivica A. Fox.
Truly robotic storytelling and laughably artificial dialogue.
A sterling example of how to cover familiar territory ... and make it crackle with vitality.
The picture emerges as a surprisingly anemic disappointment.
While Atkins' novice direction has its pockets of unevenness, his script is full of quirky invention and his crack cast never skips a beat.
The kind of gooey, inspirational drama that reigned supreme back in the day of the disease-of-the-week TV movie.
Achieves a neatly balanced tone right smack dab in between reverence and ridicule.
Given the scarcity of kid-appropriate fare in the marketplace these days, the feeble Keeble will probably move more tickets than it ought to, but it will never be mistaken for a keeper.
It's encouraging to see more than passing attention paid to character development.
As capers go, Heist is considerably less than thrilling.
Will somebody please put an end to all this nonsense?
Between its tired, cliche-ridden target and its cast of tiresome characters, a better title for this Belgian import would have been Everybody's Fatuous!
The tissue-thin script adaptation ... grows more ridiculous by the minute.

While Fox Searchlight was obviously hoping for another tasty serving of Soul Food, this ensemble-driven message dramedy is considerably less digest-ible with its oversized portions of heavy-handed sentiment and cartoony characterizations.
This involving, nicely crafted whodunit achieves the neat trick of remaining culturally and theologically true to its environment without being heavy-handed or preachy.
A pathetic, unparalleled abomination. Ishtar, come back. All is forgiven.
Despite all the good intentions and worthy performances, the result is annoyingly didactic.
Despite solid performances and handsome production values, the picture ultimately feels like secondhand goods that have been refurbished for North American consumption.
An artfully entertaining psychological thriller.

While there will be those who applaud the film for generally steering clear of heavy-handed manipulation, the scenes nevertheless have a prefabricated, synthetic feel that prevent the material from being tangibly affecting.
movie_title: La Stanza del Figlio (The Son's Room) (2002)

movie_review_blurb: A patience-trying docudrama almost completely devoid of any trace of narrative structure or even defined characters.
Squanders a terrific cast and some tremendous early promise on a weak structure.
Technically, it's the Coens' most accomplished work to date.
A lyrical if sluggish excursion set in war-torn Iranian Kurdistan.
This masterfully calibrated psychological thriller thrives on its taut performances and creepy atmosphere even if the screenplay falls somewhat short.
Despite some terrific performances and an energetic start, the picture's maturity ultimately is stunted by awkward tone-shifting and character inconsistencies.
The appeal will ... be restricted to art house audiences who don't mind people messing with their literary history.
The party's over a lot earlier than the distracted hosts appear to realize.
Boasts eye-catching art direction but has a forcefully quirky tone that quickly wears out its limited welcome.
An eloquent, reflective and beautifully acted meditation on both the profoundly devastating events of one year ago and the slow, painful healing process that has followed in their wake.
Richly observed, beautifully written and performed.
Toni Collette is finally given ample room to strut her considerable acting stuff in Japanese Story.
A high-decibel biker flick that puts the 'less' back in mindless.
Despite a promising setup, the journey leads to the same kind of dramatic dead end found at the end of the playwright-filmmaker's last screen effort, Heist.
A certifiably oddball but irresistibly entertaining concoction.
A '50s sci-fi spoof that's a silly hit to the funny bone.
A handsomely appointed, solidly acted feature.
A crass, sophomoric and, more to the point, offensively unfunny parody.
Meg Ryan's swell, but this 'Erin Rocky-vich' inspirational story lacks punch.
Cruises along agreeably on the easy chemistry between Ben Stiller and Owen Wilson.
There's the inevitable hit-and-miss aspect that goes with the territory, but there's also sufficient character-driven kookiness to propel it all agreeably along.
A limp sex comedy about men behaving badly.
A playfully quirky and, ultimately, unexpectedly affecting portrait of a 17-year-old slacker.
Constant interruptions prevent the story from building to a satisfying emotional pitch, leaving the film, like the characters, to trudge circuitously across that vast frozen tundra.
An often intriguing documentary, albeit one with wires attached.
movie_title: Red Trousers: The Life of the Hong Kong Stuntmen (2003)

movie_review_blurb: Although packing lightly story-wise, the jokes travel reasonably well in this harmless teen comedy.
Beneath the ill-fitting title lies an intriguing if flawed medieval murder mystery.

The production is a haphazard rendering of the original Michael Swerdlick script that's incapable of sticking to any one tone or character motivation long enough to give the viewer any reason to care about the outcome.
A consistently amusing collection of 10 black-and-white shorts shot over the past two decades.

Billed as the first entirely Afghan film shot on home soil since the rise and fall of the Taliban, Siddiq Barmak's Osama ends up being of greater historical significance than of any lasting artistic merit.
This particular reconceptualization actually does an impressive job of capturing the nasty dread of the original.
It combines candid recollections and spectacularly photographed dramatic reconstructions to highly compelling effect.
New director, new writers, same old shtick.
In the end, the picture comes up sufficiently short on both the wit and action fronts to be declared a keeper.
While the words 'instant holiday classic' might be pushing it, Elf is at the very least a breezily entertaining, perfectly cast family treat.
The patented blend of the outrageous and the sweet that has become the brothers' trademark struggles to find the desired balance here.
Better than Reloaded, but the thrill is gone.
After a seductive start, it all becomes an empty swirl of smoke and mirrors -- or, in this case, flickering fluorescent bulbs and icy glass.
Extremely funny -- at times sidesplittingly so -- thanks to Zwigoff's way with raw irreverence and Thornton's perfectly pitched, ready-for- anything performance.
An agreeably goofy road movie of a documentary.
Beneath all the requisite genre trappings there's a vast, empty gulch where the affecting dramatic element should have been found.
The laughs are strictly budgeted in this TV-tuned family outing.
In turns heart-wrenching and eye-opening, this documentary is one of the year's best.
Masterful direction and commanding performances make this epic voyage highly see-worthy.
movie_title: Master and Commander: The Far Side of the World (2003)

movie_review_blurb: While the results are predictably mixed, most manage to rise to the occasion, with Spike Lee, Spain's Victor Erice and Chinese director Chen Kaige doing particularly impressive stuff.
The teen Bond's latest mission finds the would-be franchise creatively Banks-rupt.
A loud, obnoxious mess of lame humor, CGI overload and (jinkies!) the Mystery Inc. gang stopping the action dead to confront their own personal demons during extended self-analysis sessions.

Simultaneously brings the original Cold War scenario bracingly up to date with a story line that pulses with a topical resonance while paying respectful homage to the late Frankenheimer's artistic vision.
Falls prey to a creeping structural rigor mortis that sets in early.

Has a commercial reach that goes beyond local hero worship thanks in part to an all-star lineup of interviewees, including Cher, David Bowie, Mick Jagger, Gwen Stefani and Courtney Love, to name just a few confirmed Rod-heads.
The only thing missing is a 1-800 number flashing on the bottom.
Stander attempts to pass itself off as a fast-paced caper picture doubling as a socially conscious apartheid drama but ends up equally unconvincing in both departments.
Charts an uncertain course between wild and mild, eventually running aground in a pile of male-bonding muck.
Every time you feel like you're finally grabbing hold of something involving, the picture once again spins frustratingly out of reach.
The picture ultimately overcomes some clunky dialogue and clunkier line readings to deliver the goods in a diminished-expectations manner, particularly when the bloodbath gets going.
movie_title: Anacondas: The Hunt for the Blood Orchid (2004)

movie_review_blurb: Waters has returned to trashy form with what is unquestionably his most outrageous film since those heady Pink Flamingos days.

Both tough and tender, the movingly rendered production often strikes a devastating chord without resorting to any of the manipulative string-pulling known to accompany movies about 'men who made a difference.'
A sharply observed tragicomedy that draws laughter as genuinely as it coaxes tears.
Boasts exceptional lead performances (by a never-better Liam Neeson and Laura Linney) and lovely writing by Condon.
There is nothing like a couple of dames -- especially when the ladies in question happen to be the divine Dame Judi Dench and Dame Maggie Smith.
An often funny if slight satire that's never as edgy as it thinks it is or as sharply focused as it needs to be to put it in a league with a Get Shorty or a State and Main.
A stilted, episodic tale of obsession that grows more ridiculous by the second.
It's been pumped up with steroid-enhanced direction, but this zombie horror remake's got no soul.
Essentially sleepwalks its way through a strictly by-the-numbers premise.
A blissfully silly, character-driven road movie with impressive laugh-per-minute performance specs.
movie_title: Harold & Kumar Go to White Castle (2004)

movie_review_blurb: By the end, the Punisher's greatest adversaries emerge as an unwelcome trio known as jokey, hokey and hammy.
The low-key picture gets by on the genial charisma of its cast, but it fails to rise to the occasion when it comes to building to a necessary comic pitch.
Awkward comic timing and uneven performances spoil the desired effect.
A crass, clumsily constructed romantic comedy.
Foxx and an appealing ensemble ... plus a nice, light touch with the material by writer-director Daniel Taplitz, make for a generally pleasant diversion.
Ultimately loses something in the translation from 28 minutes to 97.
Provides entry level, risk-free enlightenment with a great deal of charm and invention.
movie_title: What the Bleep Do We Know!? (2004)

movie_review_blurb: Mercilessly plodding pacing, problematic character motivations and a fundamental lack of chemistry between the two star-crossed lovers.
Despite the clunky bits, Tomorrow still manages to deliver the blockbuster goods.
A deeper, darker, visually arresting and more emotionally satisfying adaptation of the J.K. Rowling literary phenomenon.
movie_title: Harry Potter and the Prisoner of Azkaban (2004)

movie_review_blurb: Feels like a stagy adaptation of an already contrived play.
An overstuffed, ponderous affair that sends its anti-hero on an epic excursion into dullsville.
This one's strictly for the kiddies.

Graced by bold performances, lyrical visuals and, most notably, Irving's own words, which have made the transition quite intact thanks to a faithful but still filmic adaptation by writer-director Tod Williams.
The atmospheric psychological thriller weaves a compelling web thanks to dense, stylized direction by Nick Willing and a smartly assembled cast.
Every time it seems like it's going to move forward, its absurdist themes are instead rerun in a continual loop with steadily diminishing comedic returns.

An exercise in drudgery, with nothing particularly insightful or revealing to say about the charter member of the Suicidal Poets Society and the artistic endeavor in which she would make her indelible mark.
Armed with playwright O'Rowe's fresh dialogue, the characters are a treat to get to know, but the most intriguing thing about the film is the always inventive way in which their lives intersect.
It's still loud, crude and lewd but without the loopy energy and bright characterizations that helped to distract from the fact that there was never much going on in the plot department.
A surprisingly flat retread, hobbled by half-baked setups and sluggish pacing.
Tries to pass off a scattered, cliched approximation of the real deal.
It's pretty difficult to resist the film's freshly choreographed charm.
Where's Vin Diesel when you need him?

When compared to the usual, more somber festival entries, Davis' highly personal brand of romantic comedy is a tart, smart breath of fresh air that stands out from the pack even if the picture itself is somewhat problematic.
movie_title: Amy's O (Amy's Orgasm) (Why Love Doesn't Work) (2002)

movie_review_blurb: Moodysson, a former poet, directs with an accomplished mix of lyricism and grit.
Demonstrates how an exceptional documentary can be every bit as emotionally compelling, original and surprising as any first-rate fictional work.
There's an assembly-line, direct-to-video feel about the whole production.
The cast's a kick.
The smartly written picture is graced by another accomplished Javier Bardem performance.
movie_title: Mondays in the Sun (Los Lunes al sol) (2003)

movie_review_blurb: A collection of false starts interrupted by an awful lot of angst-ridden contemplation, the picture serves up soul-searching gush with scant pulse-pounding rush.
After a while, the extremely limited camera movement and languid pacing take an exacting toll, resulting in a viewing experience that is considerably less than idyllic.
At a point when the whole Dogme exercise seemed to be losing creative steam, along comes Bier with welcome filmmaking substance to invigorate the stripped-down style.

Works better than it probably should thanks mainly to a ready-for -anything lead performance by the ridiculously charismatic Jimi Mistry and equally game performances from an amusing supporting cast including Heather Graham and Marisa Tomei.
Fails to make the grade as either a gritty crime drama or an intriguing piece of historical relevance.
A beautifully observed character piece.
Proves to be just as vapid and directionless as its no-account subjects.
An odd hybrid -- part thriller, part social commentary, part quirky comedy -- that adds up to something that's entertaining, enlightening and highly original.
A dark, quirky road movie that constantly defies expectation.
A ragingly controversial feature that makes it very tricky to distinguish between insightful and incite-ful.
An agreeably charming, brightly performed romantic comedy.
Makes for some truly odd, at times confusing, kids entertainment ... but at least this time there's some centered storytelling to go along with all the weird stuff.
While [its] diverse parts don't always coalesce, Duvall's performance is a fully dimensional, richly robust keeper.
While Yanes isn't quite able to sustain the quirky tone, his international cast does a fine job of keeping the energy aloft.
movie_title: Sin noticias de Dios (Don't Tempt Me) (2003)

movie_review_blurb: A remarkably insightful look at the backstage angst of the stand-up comic.
Both damning and damned compelling.
Finally coming down off of Miramax's deep shelves after a couple of aborted attempts, Waking Up in Reno makes a strong case for letting sleeping dogs lie.
While [Guttenberg's] tenacity is undeniable, he would have been wiser to let sleeping cats lie.
Critics need a good laugh, too, and this too-extreme-for-TV rendition of the notorious MTV show delivers the outrageous, sickening, sidesplitting goods in steaming, visceral heaps.
A not-so-Divine Secrets of the Ya-Ya Sisterhood with a hefty helping of Re-Fried Green Tomatoes.
Rich in wryly observed characterization culled from a freshly mined cultural perspective.
It's mighty tedious for the viewer who has to contend with unpleasant characters, hit-and-miss performances and awkwardly staged scenes.
At a very noticeable three hours, it feels like a month of Sunday school classes.
Questionably tasteful but often laugh-out-loud funny.
A wholly uninspired Spy Kids knockoff that squanders some decent high-tech gadgetry with its slipshod plotting and clunky pacing.
A well-intentioned study of illegal immigration and its various social ramifications ultimately trips over a tangle of clunky scripting.
Schwentke's solid cast and a visual talent for nailing the unsavory, noir-soaked milieu compensate for some of the more gratuitous eccentricities.
Graff ... at least has his heart in the right place, and those expressive, talented kids are the real deal.
Travels a considerable distance on its gentle humor and the engaging performances of its largely nonprofessional cast.
The familiar formula feels significantly watered-down the third time around.
Witless, excessive and ultimately boring gore-a-thon.
Pairing two bankable actors as likable Kate Hudson and Luke Wilson in a romantic comedy would seem like a recipe for success, but the end result proves to be a dull, draggy disappointment.
Has its humorous moments thanks to Steven P. Baer's broad but buoyant script and a supporting cast of character actors who know how to hit a good line home.
It looks great and the special effects are decent, but its scare tactics leave a lot to be desired.
Too often potential elements of suspense and true terror are sacrificed for intended laughs (in-jokes and otherwise) that don't always materialize.
Keeps getting held back by an uncertain pace and a too-tight- lipped tone that elicits a few inadvertent snickers.
Fails to hit those all-important marks intrinsic to the success of every screen crime thriller.
A compellingly competent telling of the scandalous fall from grace of New Republic staff writer Stephen Glass.
Some worthy performances aside, this helter-skelter portrait of John Holmes and the Wonderland murders is far from wonderful.
A big fluff ball of a sex farce that's so light and flimsy it's a wonder they were able to thread it through the projector.
movie_title: The Other Side of the Bed (2003)

movie_review_blurb: An atmospheric but insufferably soapy drama.
Forced, ungainly vehicle that stalls each time it threatens to actually start.
An eloquent, achingly reflective taking of stock.
An unsuccessful mix of sci-fi horror and a highly exaggerated filmmaking approach that borders on unintentional parody.
It's no surprise that Brody, Douglas, Walter and Leibman make for one highly entertaining, if messed up, family unit, but the big revelation here is Jovovich.

In the process of pushing the envelope of acceptance, Bani-Etemad carries off the neat trick of presenting an involving, beautifully cast film that portrays contemporary Iranian issues in a remarkably universal light.
movie_title: Under the Skin of the City (Zir-e Poust-e Shahr) (2003)

movie_review_blurb: You don't need to own a pickup truck or know how to use the word 'aorta' in a sentence ... in order to appreciate the amiable humor.
movie_title: Blue Collar Comedy Tour: The Movie (2003)

movie_review_blurb: Its makers have been so busy running around trying to push all the preprogrammed buttons that the tender father-daughter theme at the picture's core seldom feels like anything more than another opportunity to alter the frantically changing pace.

While it doesn't quite reach the blissfully inspired heights of Best in Show or Waiting for Guffman, Christopher Guest's latest nevertheless makes a worthy addition to his canon of brilliantly improvised mockumentaries.
The always reliable Emmanuelle Beart is an entirely credible Odile.
By the time B-Rad says 'Don't be hatin' ' for like the seventh time, a good portion of the audience will already be there.
What starts off lively and offbeat soon becomes repetitive and shrill.
Suffers from inexperienced filmmaking and a self-absorbed lead character who fails to elicit any truly tangible degree of audience sympathy.
Stands as the filmmaker's most satisfying and contained work to date.
Ultimately, all of von Trier's social moralizing feels as theatrical and artificial as the fake snow that falls over Dogville's chalk-drawn streets.
Yet another film about disaffected, aimless Asian youth.
It might help you sleep better, but it offers nothing that's going to stimulate the mind or touch the soul like a well-programmed festival picture should.
movie_title: Incantato (Il Cuore Altrove) (The Heart Is Elsewhere) (2003)

movie_review_blurb: Director Fred Schepisi's painstakingly paced approach to screenwriter Jess Wigutow's already weighty material makes for a strained viewing experience.
The third time's the bomb -- and not in a good way.

Those singing-and-dancing trolls will likely appeal mainly to younger viewers. Older moviegoers might experience a cloyingly sticky sensation that isn't caused by the soda-splattered floor beneath their feet.
The magic is minuscule in this handsome-looking but drearily told animated tale.
There's little that comes off as "natural" in "Natural Selection," a stiffly heavy-handed, drawn-out, faith-based drama about a Christ-like teen struggling to find his true path.
Long before the overwrought ending arrives, "In Search of the American Dream" ... will send most viewers scrambling in search of the exits.
movie_title: In Search Of The American Dream (2016)

movie_review_blurb: If the 2001 documentary "Dog Town and Z-Boys" engagingly gave Southern California's skateboard culture its influential due, then "Made in Venice" comes across as its scrappy, but no less lovable, kid brother.

While a fictionalized account of Lee's career certainly held some sex, drugs & rock 'n' roll potential, the blandly pedestrian film "Spaceman" seldom delivers despite an engagingly game lead performance by Josh Duhamel.
An occasionally enlightening if long-winded primer that will prove best suited to connoisseurs.
movie_title: Kampai! For the Love of Sake (2016)

movie_review_blurb: [Kubo and the Two Strings] is an eye-popping delight that deftly blends colorful folklore with gorgeous, origami-informed visuals to immersive effect.
[An] annoyingly oblique exercise in arty affectation by Bingham Bryant and Kyle Molzan.
"Edge of Winter" suffices as a diverting breath of recycled cool air.

While one wishes Carré, who shares screenplay credit with Charles Spano, might have hung those stirring visuals on more involving plotting, "Embers" nevertheless makes a strong, not to mention timely, impression.

Through the incorporation of multiple strategically placed cameras, including helmet cams, the filmmakers, who achieved a similar, grunts-eye-view in 2014's "The Hornet's Nest," create an undeniably palpable experience.
Looks ... like a musty remnant from the old Cinemax late night programming block.
"Can We Take a Joke?" ... poses a valid question at a juncture when freedom of speech is a hot topic, especially where the Internet is concerned.

Budding filmmakers can take away a valuable lesson from the documentary "Hooligan Sparrow": You don't need fancy camera equipment (or in some instances, even a camera) if you're passionate enough about the story you want to tell.
[A] keenly observed, utterly contemporary group portrait of disconnected individuals, both young and old, whose lives are on spiritual and emotional lockdown.
Doesn't even qualify as effectively executed propaganda.
movie_title: Hillary's America: The Secret History of the Democratic Party (2016)

movie_review_blurb: An amiable if aimless ensemble comedy that's unable to overcome its amateur status.

Persuasively putting a face on the meals most of America consumes regularly without coming across as a sanctimonious expose, "At the Fork" serves up an even-handed perspective on the subject of eating ethically.
The hapless viewer who has stumbled upon this cheesy knockoff will likely feel trapped right along with the wooden performances and plodding plot.
Thanks to a strongly rooted lead performance by Charlie Plummer as a 15-year-old small-town kid who's well on his way to a stint in juvenile detention, "King Jack" still strikes a resonant chord.
A formulaic fish-out-of-water buddy caper given an amusing boost with a casual scrunch of Guzmán's pug-nosed mug.
Remains intriguing despite its troublesome issues.
Few will likely embrace the insufferably chirpy, high-concept rom-com that struggles to stretch a mighty shallow premise into a feature-length proposition.
Though indulgently overlong, "Raiders!" manages to unearth the inner geek in all of us.
movie_title: Raiders!: The Story of the Greatest Fan Film Ever Made (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Illustrates the diminishing returns inherent in going back to the shock comedy well.

Sadly, 15 years in, even the domestic developments surrounding Manny and his brood have been relegated to the sidelines, displaced by too many shrill characters frantically attempting to pad the emaciated plot.
A darkly compelling, skillfully crafted cold case thriller.
movie_title: The Keeper of Lost Causes (Kvinden i buret) (2016)

movie_review_blurb: "A Conspiracy of Faith" marks the darkest and most gripping screen adaptation of the Jussi Adler-Olsen novels to date.
movie_title: A Conspiracy of Faith (Flaskepost fra P) (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Another unsavory journey into contemporary Denmark's seamier underbelly.
A thoroughly engaging portrait of Unlocking the Truth, a heavy metal outfit composed of African American middle schoolers.

This first feature by TV documentary director Alex Simmons, about a weeklong, male-bonding hiking trip, hasn't packed enough plot or humor to distinguish itself amidst all that lush mountain greenery.
The film's prevailing theme may be that nothing is black and white, but the execution ... proves spottier than a kennel full of caged Dalmatians.
It's easy to root for this disciplined but naive "girl-child," especially as portrayed by Pappas, herself a hard-to-resist blend of Audrey Hepburn and Joan Cusack.
An effectively moody, well-acted and impressively understated thriller by Greg Kwedar in his feature directing debut.
[A] sensitive, luxuriantly filmed documentary ...
Adam Nimoy ... has freely allowed his love and admiration to permeate every frame of this richly rewarding tribute.
This smartly cast, vengeance-fueled oater proves mighty entertaining in its own right.

Michael Mueller's character-driven script is about the only thing that feels driven in this otherwise listless vehicle, and "The Beat Beneath My Feet" conveys all the pulse-pounding energy of a funeral procession.
Plays like third-rate Richard Linklater, minus the acclaimed filmmaker's eye for keenly observed characters and ear for realistic dialogue.
"Chief Zabu" may have been buried for the past three decades, but this tiresomely talky would-be satire is no treasure.
In a retribution-driven era increasingly defined by hate-charged absolutes, "An Eye for an Eye" offers a decidedly more reflective vantage point.

Rose's pickles might have a pleasant snap, but there's none to be found in the tired, limp shtick in Sheldon Cohn and Gary Wolfson's screenplay, which has been choreographed at a lumbering, drawn-out pace by director Michael Manasseri.

It's entirely fitting that "The River Thief" is an unabashedly faith-based drama - it would take a considerable leap of faith to find many redemptive qualities in this hackneyed, heavy-handed first feature written and directed by YA author N.D. Wilson.
Another soggy batch of Southern Gothic horror-comedy from writer-director Richard Bates Jr. that spews out pitch black smoke with little combustible substance.

Contemporary Disney at its finest - a vibrantly rendered adventure that combines state-of-the-art CG animation with traditional storytelling and colorful characters, all enlivened by a terrific voice cast.
Biller ... emerges as a feminist Russ Meyer skilled at fetishizing archetypal images of narcissism with the exacting eye of a Douglas Sirk.
A tenderly observed, bittersweet comedy featuring a beautifully rooted Gabriel Byrne.
Jim Carrey's back in the zone with this agreeable concept comedy.
A strictly by-the-numbers political thriller that fails to capitalize on Idris Elba's formidable screen presence.
A rewardingly unassuming, tough and tender portrait of a drug-addicted London busker whose ill-fated life takes a surprising turn after a ginger tabby turns up in his kitchen.
A compelling but unnecessarily long-winded sociological study about a group of adults recruited to watch for signs and wonders in a small village in Bosnia-Herzegovina.

Capably delivering on its ominous title, "The Ones Below" is a masterfully calibrated psychological thriller that deviously plays off of anxieties surrounding contemporary notions of domesticity and identity.
The parameters of homeland security are chillingly assessed in "Do Not Resist," a troubling documentary examining the escalating militarization of the nation's police forces.

Introducing both a fresh new voice and a fresh new face to independent filmmaking, Jean of the Joneses is a crisply urbane comedy from first-time writer-director Stella Meghie, boasting a sparkling lead performance by Taylour Paige.
Somehow Murphy manages to lift his dignified, all-knowing servant character off the page, giving a meticulously composed performance in a vehicle that can't help but feel superficially repackaged.
A zippy, compact history of the rise and rise of Compaq Computer Corp.
Gritty authenticity goes up against cloying pathos - with the latter unfortunately emerging victorious - in the skid row drama "Cardboard Boxer."
It's hard to begrudge the agenda.
There's a nice, snappy playfulness in the rapport between Samberg and engaging newcomer Crown. That lively, back-and-forth vibe also extends to the Aniston/Burrell and Key/Peele dynamic.
It might have set out to convey the disturbingly sadistic nature of institutional brotherhood, but it's the familial variety with which "Goat" explores something ultimately more compelling.
This overcooked Thanksgiving turkey succeeds only in managing to take all the fun out of dysfunctional.
It's a rare film that can dredge up nostalgic fondness for 2002's awful "National Lampoon's Van Wilder," but "Total Frat Movie" manages to rise to the dubious occasion.

Incorporating fluid flashbacks and snippets of narration that refreshingly serve to enhance rather than distract, director-writer Hannes Holm maintains a gentle, lyrical flow while coaxing fine performances from a diverse cast.
movie_title: A Man Called Ove (En man som heter Ove) (2016)

movie_review_blurb: The theme of enlightenment has seldom come across as leaden as it is in "Milton's Secret," a dull drama based on the children's novel of the same name by spiritual author Eckhart Tolle.
Despite the drama's questionable, abrupt shift into B-thriller territory, its leads remain affectingly rooted.
[A] misguided hybrid that makes tediously clear from the outset that [its] conceit just isn't working.
Dugdale captures some terrific, reflective moments, including a poetic open air performance in the middle of a persistent São Paolo rainfall.
movie_title: The Rolling Stones: Olé Olé Olé! - A Trip Across Latin America (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Despite the admittedly unique angle, this ambitious drama gets crushed under the considerable weight of its artistic, as well as budgetary, limitations.
It's potent stuff, but the film ... casts an unnecessarily wide net, spending needless time going over the finer points of polo and Ramsey's post-war career with the Hughes Aircraft Co.
movie_title: Never Surrender: The Ed Ramsey Story (2016)

movie_review_blurb: At its most absorbing, Lasseter's story plays like an Aussie Treasure of the Sierra Madre, in which the main subject is a bit of a cypher whose true nature proves to be as difficult to pinpoint as that elusive gold.

A stagy "Raging Bull" meets "Rocky" hybrid that tosses every boxing movie cliché into the ring yet fails to land a single convincing punch ... plods on listlessly despite a supporting cast including Alec Baldwin, Danny Glover and Michael Madsen.
A sobering, all-too-relatable indictment of the bureaucratic Hydra that is the medical insurance industry.
movie_title: A Monster With A Thousand Heads (Un Monstruo de Mil Cabezas) (2016)

movie_review_blurb: "Drone" is a solid, thought-provoking documentary that raises some pertinent questions even if they may not originate from the most objective of places.

Haley whips it into something reasonably entertaining even as you start thinking about how truly great "Get Shorty" and Travolta's Chili Palmer were midway through those double-crossing criminal activities.
A richly crafted documentary that serves as an enlightening tribute to the filmmaker who masterfully tapped into the medium's wide-reaching socio-political potential.
Despite assurances to the contrary, Wim Wenders' "Every Thing Will Be Fine" turns out to be a frustratingly distancing drama that fails to capitalize on its compelling 3D cinematography.
Writer-director Hank Bedford's Mississippi-set romantic drama would have benefited from judicious tightening and a rethink of its uninspired, decidedly downbeat crime element.
Even with the likes of Amy Ryan and Will Forte providing capable backup, it all grows ancient, fast.
A visually breathtaking work of computer-generated animation that is ultimately unable to compensate for a disappointingly derivative script.
"The Girl in the Book" proves to be anything but a page-turner.
While the film, with its preponderance of potty jokes, might placate the very young already primed by boisterous singing chipmunks, older viewers will likely find it all harder to, uh, bear.
Tosses out a lot of potential what-ifs but never commits to any of them.
Refuses to panda to the lowest common denominator.
"Ip Man 3," set in Hong Kong circa 1959, combines the customary, inventively choreographed action with an unexpected emotional depth, proving as hard to resist as its entertaining predecessors.
Awfully silly - and just plain awful ...
As stripped-down, revisionist Westerns go, "Jane Got A Gun" may not have reinvented the wagon wheel, but it rolls out as a sturdy, well-crafted genre piece despite its rocky road to the screen.
Confronts the global issue of swelling immigration in the face of steely bureaucratic indifference with a disarming grace and palpable humanity.
movie_title: Those Who Feel The Fire Burning (2015)

movie_review_blurb: Greenaway's boundary-pushing, breathlessly in-your-face approach begins to take its toll on viewer patience, resulting in Eisenstein not being the only one to ultimately lose interest in his bold Mexican odyssey.
Music aside, this Pakistani "Buena Vista Social Club" is a testament to the enduring potency of creative expression.

As vapidly generic as its title, British director Scott Mann's "Heist" is a by-the-numbers crime thriller that squanders a decent cast, including Robert De Niro, Jeffrey Dean Morgan and Dave Bautista.
An amusing, fearlessly over-the-top screen rendering of the book franchise.
A playful deconstruction of the slasher film that ultimately packs a surprisingly affecting punch.
An intensive, propulsive political thriller representing a tautly executed return to form for director Stephen Daldry.
Klein and those impassioned protesters provide something that has been in short supply in the predecessors - namely, a modicum of hope for the future.
Sure, it's an evangelical "Remember the Titans," but at least the Erwin brothers have made an effort, parochially speaking, to go outside the lines.
A well-intentioned but drawn-out crime drama.
Succeeds despite an intrusive soundtrack that underscores each genuinely heartfelt moment.
Ultimately fails to deliver the sort of inspirational uplift that should have been a given.

Even if the world had been clamoring for yet another "Step Up"-type hip hop dance movie, it wouldn't be "Dancin' It's On!," an inept knockoff that proves every bit as clunky as its punctuation-challenged title.
A delightful romp that captures the spirit of the adored 65-year-old comic strip.
With a title that obligingly provides its own capsule review, "This Isn't Funny" is a would-be rom-com that comes up seriously short on the laughs.
"Heneral Luna" would never be mistaken for more serious-minded art-house material, but there are certainly less lively ways to be taught a history lesson.
A bombastic, overlong melodrama that doesn't recognize the occasional need to takes things down a decibel or three.
Frequently laugh-out-loud funny and tangibly tender where it ought to be, the immensely satisfying screwball romp feels freshly contemporary even as it largely conforms to genre conventions.
A fascinating, skillfully assembled chronicle of the rise and inevitable fallout surrounding the granddaddy of the environmental activism movement.
Lopez's first feature comes across as fragmented and overwrought, with characters and performances that seem to have been egged on by the score's achingly purposeful piano.
"Tumbledown" sees its good intentions undermined by cloying sitcom conventions.
A freshly contemporary change-up on the traditional cross-cultural romantic-comedy.
"11 Minutes" finds veteran Polish writer-director Jerzy Skolimowski in a decidedly experimental mood.

It might sound like the title of a schmaltzy TV movie, but "Be Here Now (The Andy Whitfield Story)" is an extraordinarily moving, deeply personal, filmed diary of late "Spartacus" star Andy Whitfield's battle with cancer.
movie_title: Be Here Now (The Andy Whitfield Story) (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Watson, with her razor-sharp Hermione Granger conviction very much intact, gives us reason to care about her character's predicament even as the dramatics that put her there prove considerably less convincing.

This seriously warped family portrait - an inspired thematic hybrid of Kafkaesque alienation and Farrelly brothers farce, with a healthy grafting of Tod Browning's "Freaks" - still has an organic sweetness at its core.
An insistently distancing if aesthetically pleasing Canadian production.
movie_title: An Eye for Beauty (Le règne de la beauté) (2014)

movie_review_blurb: A stickily genteel, cross-cultural comedy-drama that comes up blandly lacking on all counts.

While it's admittedly refreshing to see a documentary taking a decidedly sunnier, pro-active approach to pressing environmental issues, "Catching the Sun" could have benefited from a more concentrated focus.
Even viewers who were transported by the considerable charm of 2006's "Paris, je t'aime" will be hard-pressed to show any love for the latest entry in the travelog/anthology.
movie_title: Rio, I Love You (Rio, Eu Te Amo) (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Despite clocking in at a scant 70 minutes, the troubled-youth drama "Memoria" manages to make a hauntingly poetic impression.
With its twinkly piano and soul-stirring cinematography, "Love Thy Nature" feels like the visual equivalent of a hot oil spa massage - and leaves a residual effect that proves equally as fleeting.
The childhood years of Brazil's national treasure have been given a lamentably pedestrian big-screen treatment by "Pelé: Birth of a Legend."
Cursed with obnoxiously broad characters and nonsensical plotting, "A Bit of Bad Luck" is an intended backwoods satire that runs hopelessly off-course from the outset.
Even by diminished B-movie standards - and the name Steven Seagal above the title - "Asian Connection," about a pair of American bank robbers who set up shop in Southeast Asia, is a dumb, boring dud.

Travolta, who took over the role from Nicolas Cage, and Meloni, who's looking more and more like Robert De Niro every day, have a loose, easy chemistry that goes a long way to enliven all that overworked familiarity.

East engagingly meets West in "The Professor: Tai Chi's Journey West," an affectionate documentary portrait of Cheng Man-Ching, the Chinese master who brought Tai Chi to New York during the groovy but stressed-out '60s.
movie_title: The Professor: Tai Chi's Journey West (2016)

movie_review_blurb: A diabolically effective anti-date movie.
"High Strung" wears its tired let's-put-on-a-show clichés as if they were neon turquoise leg-warmers.
While we may have been locked up with these characters before ... Cohen's unwavering commitment nevertheless commands attention.
This overly talky, slackly executed game of cat-and-mouse comes off as cheesy rather than chilling.

Just when it was looking like animated animal movies had run out of anything original to say, along comes the smartly amusing, crisply relevant Zootopia to handily demonstrate there's still plenty of bite left in the anthropomorphic CG menagerie.
Dickman's lively documentary functions as both a handy pot primer and a telling portrait of the volatile, adapt-or-die climate that continues to hover over the newspaper industry.

The film traces Cernan's career trajectory, going back to his days in San Diego as a hot-shot naval aviator, blending terrific archival footage with contemporary perspectives to quietly poetic effect.
movie_title: The Last Man On The Moon (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Parents in the market for some deserved date-night distraction couldn't do much worse than "Emelie" - and that's meant as a compliment.

[Bell's] anticipated hand-to-hand encounters are ultimately beaten into submission by an irritating atonal score that constantly drowns any trace of nuance under an onslaught of shrill electronic sludge.

Those taking in "Someone Else," an unconvincing, nonlinear drama about a pair of dramatically different Korean American cousins who are attracted to the same woman, will soon likely be wishing they had chosen to watch something else.
A compelling bit of family drama that packs a corrosive punch.
"All the Time in the World" makes a visually compelling case for living, at least temporarily, off the grid.
movie_title: All The Time In The World (2015)

movie_review_blurb: Plummer, half-a-century after outsmarting the Nazis in "The Sound of Music," manages to further hone his reliably persuasive presence.
Although Senko ultimately overplays Hillary Clinton's "vast right-wing conspiracy" card, her film, with its timely "Trumpian" reverberations, nevertheless serves up some compelling food for thought.
You don't have to be a baseball fanatic or for that matter a historian or a physicist to appreciate "Fastball" ...
"Get a Job" is nothing special.
A shrill, yappy live-action comedy that proves considerably more annoying than adorable despite an accompanying charitable marketing campaign designed to draw attention to animal welfare causes.
Gross ... is ultimately unable to satisfy the rules of dramatic engagement.
Systematically yet subtly, the Bolings and their strong cast take this certifiably oddball film in some thoughtfully intriguing places.

Jacobson shines a spotlight on a troublingly murky corner of the criminal justice system - one in which prison officials, not the courts, determine the necessity for and the duration of long-term segregation.
Mehta overplays the significance of virtually every aspect of Rajiv Shah's script, no matter how minor, with painfully slow pans and needlessly lingering establishing shots.
A plucky ensemble fails to elevate "Crash Pad," a forced, formulaic revenge comedy about an obnoxious slacker whose new housemate turns out to be the husband of his older ex-mistress.
It's a safe bet that audiences the world over will go loco for Coco.
Short on big laughs despite the game efforts of an energetic cast.
A tenderly intimate, affecting documentary portrait ...

"6 Below" ultimately can't rise above the swelling inspirational score or the flat adaptation by Madison Turner, which mechanically pivots between the mountaintop and flashbacks from LeMarque's dysfunctional past.

Other than serving as potential homework for Jared Kushner, there just isn't much of value in "Surviving Peace," a self-serving documentary dialogue on the century-old Israeli-Palestinian conflict ...
Taking a lively approach to an increasingly serious 21st century issue, the skillfully assembled documentary "Wasted! The Story of Food Waste" proves as eye-opening as it is mouth-watering.
movie_title: Wasted! The Story of Food Waste (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Attention The Emoji Movie: Your status as worst animated feature of the year might well be in jeopardy when My Little Pony: The Movie trots into theaters this weekend.

One doesn't need to be into pugilism or well-versed in Gaelic to appreciate "Rocky Ros Muc," a documentary that is as much about roots and identity as it is a portrait of Irish American boxer Sean Mannion.

Curtis ... admittedly takes advantage of a record-breaking western New York snowfall to mood-setting effect, but all that smirk-inducing dialogue and the weightless performances inevitably take their toll.
A perfectly serviceable B-movie.
movie_title: The Osiris Child: Science Fiction Volume One (2017)

movie_review_blurb: "Prosperity" may position itself as a primer for making environmentally-conscious business decisions, but it ultimately feels inescapably self-serving.
Refreshingly devoid of talking animals and anthropomorphic vehicles, Ann Marie Fleming's "Window Horses" is a lovely surprise of a stirringly original animated feature.
An eye-opening, not to mention ear-opening, experience.
movie_title: Clive Davis: The Soundtrack of Our Lives (2017)

movie_review_blurb: There has been no shortage of films tracking the immigrant pursuit of the American dream, but few have been as laugh-out-loud delightful as "The Tiger Hunter," a sparkling first feature by Lena Khan.
It's ultimately the hardened intensity of Patrick's commanding portrayal that gives "Last Rampage" its take-no-prisoners tautness.
Any hope of prestige is dashed by the heavy-handed, cliché-ridden direction of former stuntman Johnny Martin and his star's detached portrayal of a guy whose mind is permanently elsewhere.
It's as if filmmaker Kirk Simon entered into the project without a carefully thought-out agenda, instead opting for more of a free-form approach that constantly undercuts its effectiveness.
An effective - and affecting - fact-based political drama set against the bloody backdrop of South Korea's 1980 Guangju Democratic Uprising.
Once again Arnett, Heigl and company simply don't come off as dimensionally warm and engaging as required.
movie_title: The Nut Job 2: Nutty by Nature (2017)

movie_review_blurb: While the dramatic underpinnings could have used more work, the labyrinth that's the focus of "Dave Made a Maze" is truly an amazingly inventive sight to behold.
A stiffly executed re-creation of the events surrounding the 1980 hostage-taking attack on London's Iranian Embassy that packs all the high-stakes intrigue of a filed police report.
Three influential Delta bluesmen are affectionately given their long overdue time in the spotlight in Scott Rosenbaum's fittingly soulful "Sidemen: Long Road to Glory."
"Dealt" achieves the neat trick of giving its main subject a rewarding character arc.
An incessantly shrill and awfully derivative fish-out-of-water tale.
A straight-ahead political thriller that fails to ratchet up the requisite tension despite its timely subject matter and (largely) effective cast.
"Embargo" plays like a freshman college paper that's long on reference material but comes up short in establishing an overriding premise.
An achingly raw and tender portrait of two spiritually isolated individuals for whom the laying on of hands is a surrogate for some desperately needed human contact.
Although the path taken by Dayveon and the plotting are well-traveled, 28-year-old filmmaker Abbasi does some intriguing things with tone and texture ...
All that repetition in the absence of more inspired plotting results in a payoff that feels inescapably contrived.
Gabai's film is too preoccupied corralling all the genre clichés to come up with anything original or compelling.
A raunchy, ploddingly unfunny comedy sequel to 2012's equally crass but disarmingly endearing "Goon."

On paper, a 90-minute documentary involving the playing of a 3,000-year-old Chinese board game wouldn't seem to lend itself to adjectives like "lively" and "compelling," but darned if Greg Kohs' "AlphaGo" isn't those things and more.
Vividly photographed by René Diaz and adroitly edited by Dan Swietlik, "A River Below" skillfully - and quite compellingly - navigates the murky complexities of contemporary reality filmmaking.
Infusing his film with a scrappy surf punk energy, director Takuji Masuda combines fresh interviews and impressive wave-riding footage with extensive audio ...
Despite its undeniable visual artistry, the latest incarnation of White Fang fails to leave a lasting indentation.
"The Neighbor" finds a sturdy constant in its thoughtfully delineated performances and handsome production values.
Truth be told, "Lies We Tell" is a pretentious and muddled dud of a melodrama.
A decent premise - and a game Gina Carano - get left in the dust kicked up by "Scorched Earth," a dull, draggy post-apocalyptic western set in the not-too-distant, environmentally toxic future.
Awfully flimsy plotting ... fails to take full advantage of terrific production values and the work of an engaging cast led by the affably energetic James Corden.
A broadly played though vibrantly photographed musical romantic-comedy that fails to find a happy medium between cute-and-clever and simply cloying.

In his feature debut, filmmaker Gustav Moller masterfully ratchets up tension without the benefit of the usual visual aids, forcing viewers to dust off their imaginations and put them to work with chillingly effective results.

A criminally inept throwback to '90s urban gangsta movie posturing that plays like a stone-faced version of the 1996 Wayans brothers spoof, "Don't Be a Menace to South Central While Drinking Your Juice in the Hood."
A valuable primer for those estimated 13 million Americans who are arrested every year.

As the storyline progresses, the inevitable truths and hypocrisies that Gabe encounters along the way unfortunately serve to throw that sharply attuned comedic-dramatic touch out of balance, resulting in an unsatisfying, uneven third act ...
movie_title: Confessions of a Teenage Jesus Jerk (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Remains stuck in a stubborn rut somewhere between confusing and snooze-inducing.
Plays like "Blood Simple's" impressionable but less proficient kid brother, nevertheless has some devious touches of its own.
A former stand-up comic's attempt to pick up where he left off two decades earlier is engagingly chronicled in Brad Kuhlman's terrific documentary, "Where Have You Gone, Lou DiMaggio?"
movie_title: Where Have You Gone, Lou DiMaggio? (2018)

movie_review_blurb: While those vibrant Vietnamese backdrops make for an enticing tourism pitch, audiences are advised to skip this girls trip.
Given the terrific setup, the rather lackadaisical ending is flat. Still, the performers have a lot of fun getting there.
By the time one of the gun-toting members of Team Snipes growls "Let's finish this!" viewers would be hard-pressed to disagree.
Engagingly anchored by character actor John Hawkes, "Small Town Crime" is a satisfyingly quirky serving of frisky pulp fiction.
A stale espionage thriller that possesses all the pulse-pounding intrigue of waiting in line at the DMV.
An attentively presented but oddly unrewarding viewing experience despite a persuasive Woody Harrelson lead performance as Lyndon Baines Johnson.
A tenderly observed, remarkably insightful keeper. No joke.
An excruciatingly flat, forced Southern-fried farce about a bunch of old friends who have accidentally killed a man and must find a way to dispose of his body.
... an affably quirky debut feature by Bogota, Colombia-based Samir Oliveros.
A warm, affectionate smooch of a documentary tribute chronicling "the longest career in showbiz history."
Unfolding like a more intricately plotted installment of "48 Hours," Erik Nelson's "A Gray State" is a genuinely unsettling examination of a 2015 murder case.
Turns out Australia's national icon is one mightily maligned marsupial, as revealed by the eye-opening investigative documentary "Kangaroo: A Love-Hate Story."
Trots out the standard mix of historical martial arts intrigue without managing to be particularly intriguing.
It's no Coco, but Ferdinand... manages to squeak by with enough charming set-pieces and amusing sight gags to compensate for a stalling storyline.
A tenderly rendered inspirational piece about the healing power of forging human connections that wisely maintains its focus on its spirited, stylish main subject.
Their unassuming story speaks volumes about the extraordinary resilience of the human spirit.
Over the course of almost two hours, all the amped-up visual effects and slapstick silliness can become awfully exhausting, making a hinted-at sequel ultimately feel like a threat.
The genuine rapport between Peters and the magnetic Abdi...mainly succeeds in keeping it all on an even keel.
With a dirge-like pace that provides ample opportunity to figure it all out well ahead of the protagonists, you keep wishing somebody would buy a vowel to hurry things along.
A documentary profile that blows the whistle on a disturbing pattern of excessive force and corruption within its ranks.

Plot-wise, it's a workable set-up, but, in his feature film debut, Broadway composer Singer ... seems to have no interest in adhering to traditional crime caper rhythms that put a premium on crisp pacing and creeping peril.
"500 Years" is a palpably passionate if somewhat less contained effort than the two films preceding it.
If words occasionally fail the picture, the images speak indelible volumes.
This draggy, computer-animated feature exhibits neither bark nor bite in its portrayal of a sheep-guarding, guitar-playing Himalayan mastiff who has his head perpetually in the clouds.

While the approach taken by filmmaker Marina Zenovich, who directed 2008's "Roman Polanski: Wanted and Desired," relies heavily on talking heads - Gov. Jerry Brown among them - she admittedly paints a compelling picture of timeless greed.
An immersive fictionalized portrait of an aspiring rapper struggling to find his voice amid the constant din of long-festering Arab-Israeli tensions.
A curious if unsuccessful cross-breeding of gritty domestic drama with conventional coming-of-age sports crowd-rouser.
In the absence of a more dramatically dynamic approach to that awfully familiar subject matter, "Burning Sands" proves neither as incendiary nor as challenging as intended.
Pollock compellingly points a finger at the institutionalized racism that has permeated a disturbing number of the country's police forces.
An amped-up video game vision of a revenge fantasy that's so preoccupied with switching gears that it neglects to provide viewers with any place to park their battered attention spans.

Words like "inventive" and "inspired" are very rarely applied to the parade of cookie-cutter animated features that pass through the multiplex each year, but The Boss Baby proves a refreshing exception.

Good luck preventing that big, goofy grin from spreading across your face while watching Muppet Guys Talking, a warmly affectionate conversation between five of the talented individuals responsible for many an earliest childhood memory.
movie_title: Muppet Guys Talking: Secrets Behind the Show the Whole World Watched (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Thanks to a tasty take-no-prisoners lead performance by Melissa Leo, it can ... be a lot of fun, even if the Netflix original film's dramatic dividends prove less satisfying.
movie_title: The Most Hated Woman In America (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Visually atmospheric but tonally all over the place, Hot Summer Nights, a first feature by Elijah Bynum, has much to appreciate but ultimately possesses the sampler-platter vibe of a director's demo reel.
Co-directors David Alvarado and Jason Sussberg ... effectively chart their affable subject's trek from mechanical engineer to renowned Science Guy to passionate defender of the planet.
Early promise quickly evaporates once the film sheds its smirk and turns increasingly sanctimonious.
"American Anarchist" delivers a fascinating cautionary tale that asks, "How many mea culpas are we expected to make for our reckless youth?"
Strikes a giddy, winning balance between hilarity and heart.
A diverse, highly personal musical odyssey which, while undeniably inspired, occasionally is structurally thrown off course by its inherent wanderlust.
[A] tough/tender portrait of an ex-con attempting to find redemption in modern-day transitional Harlem.

Although there is still much to enjoy here, this DC Comics-fueled Lego adventure fails to clear the creative bar so energetically raised by co-directors and writers Phil Lord and Christopher Miller back in 2014.
So adroitly pushes every button and insistently tugs on every string that even if one is usually immune to such pandering, this unabashedly mainstream offering still proves tricky to deny.
A laughably inept political thriller that would have been right at home on the USA Network lineup circa 1990.
The loneliness of the long-distance chess grandmaster is affectingly conveyed in "Magnus," an intimate portrait of the game's reigning champ, 25-year-old Magnus Carlsen.
It may be by-the-book, but "American Wrestler" is a story well worth telling.

Often the word "legend" in a film title can be a fairly good indicator that you're not in for a breezy frolic, but that still doesn't prepare you for the ponderously protracted slog that is "The Legend of Ben Hall."
A tone-deaf mix of live action and computer-generated animation that never engagingly clicks into gear.
A remarkably dull Canadian tween caper about a sought-after magical ancient box with wish-making powers.
2017 already has a viable contender for Worst Movie of the Year.
An intriguing if flawed techno-thriller that gets an effective boost from a high-caliber cast.
The film's ultimate dubious achievement is its remarkable ability to make "Dude, Where's My Car?" feel like vintage Kubrick.
A staged kidnapping isn't the only thing that goes from botched to worse where the tone-deaf black comedy-thriller "Get the Girl" is concerned.

By the time it all culminates in a Chan-led classic Bollywood production number, the cuteness factor may have been pushed to its limit, but good luck trying to stop that goofy smile from spreading across your face.
After a while all those constantly shifting styles and mounting what-ifs involving those nonlinear paths not taken yield diminishing returns in the absence of a more cohesive whole.
A terrific showcase for the comedic talents of its ensemble, especially Freund, Bagby and the Ray Romano-esque Fein.
A generic coming-of-age comedy that feels inextricably stuck in the '90s, "Hickey" serves as the feature debut of TV commercial director Alex Grossman and plays like a never aired UPN series pilot.

While its own roots never go quite as deep as they might, there's still something goofily endearing about seeing Reitman, armed with that trusty bonsai, traipsing around the country on a healing mission.
A visually rewarding account that will make a good fit for art museum and educational video libraries.
movie_title: Through the Repellent Fence: A Land Art Film (2017)

movie_review_blurb: In attempting to address its many concerns, the film's agreeable, lightly satirical tone gives way to increasingly didactic dialogue and a stalling pace.
Visually galvanizing but dramatically leaden ...
A character-driven battle epic that plays more like a brightly rendered action-adventure than a starchy history lesson.
Falling just short of being so bad it's good, "Rogue Warrior: Robot Fighter" is a shameless low-budget "Terminator"/"Star Wars"/"Mad Max" knock-off that will have to settle for being merely godawful.
Transcends any lingering trace of gimmickry with emotionally gripping results.
While visually dynamic, Lightning McQueen's newest challenge still feels out of alignment with a languid end result that lacks sufficient forward momentum.
Bruce Willis' latest effort to dislodge his film career from a stubborn rut goes unrewarded with "Once Upon a Time in Venice," a wincingly unfunny comedy caper set along L.A.'s funky beach community.
movie_title: Once Upon a Time in Venice (2017)

movie_review_blurb: In the absence of a sturdier storyline and more dimensional characters, the manic, rapid-fire delivery, while yielding some well-deserved laughs, proves more exhausting than inspired.
movie_title: Captain Underpants: The First Epic Movie (Captain Underpants) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: An ethnically diverse cast and authentic New York locations help to effectively ground "Lucky," a palpably gritty, if familiar, take on the immigrant experience.
