A risible misfire of a contemporary war drama, the low-budget "Unfallen" stands as an epic fail on all fronts.

As captured through the ceaselessly unflinching lens of Sharif's borrowed video camera, "Nowhere to Hide" offers an uneasy prognosis that is at once graphically gut-wrenching and doggedly life-affirming.
For a film about one of the fastest guns in the West, the dramatically lightweight "Hickok" is mighty slow on the draw.
A little-known chapter in Hong Kong's wartime history has been vividly re-created in "Our Time Will Come," a female-driven drama poignantly directed by Ann Hui.
The oddball premise and quirky characters ultimately aren't enough to lift up "Man Underground," a sci-fi-infused indie drama that puts the "alien" back in alienation.
An affecting rumination on the moral weight of personal choices.
The film ultimately feels like a marketing tool for ISKCON, the International Society for Krishna Consciousness.
movie_title: Hare Krishna! The Mantra, The Movement And The Swami Who Started It All (2017)

movie_review_blurb: A criminally underplotted South Korean caper that's as disappointingly generic as its title.
He might view himself as "the cinder in the eye of unfulfilled justice," but this cranky exposé would seem to more convincingly embody Barbour's own personal resentments.
movie_title: American Media & The Second Assassination of John F. Kennedy (2017)

movie_review_blurb: If only every inspirational documentary could be as delightfully diverting as "If You're Not In the Obit, Eat Breakfast" ...
movie_title: If You're Not in the Obit, Eat Breakfast (2017)

movie_review_blurb: There's howlingly awful and then there's "The Assignment," a thoroughly ridiculous, numbingly slow neo-noir thriller about a low-life hit man forcibly given gender reassignment surgery by a vengeful doctor.
An evocative snapshot of contemporary Polish twentysomethings that packs a universal poignancy.
A well-crafted, revealing British documentary reuniting the surviving team members entrusted with safely taking astronauts to the moon and back.
movie_title: Mission Control: The Unsung Heroes of Apollo (2016)

movie_review_blurb: A talky, drawn-out crime thriller that's big on posturing but comes up empty in the delivery of convincing dramatic goods.
There's scant evidence of any creative spark in Spark: A Space Tail, a thoroughly generic, unremittingly charmless computer-animated adventure.

A forward-thinking take on addressing the demise of the human race, the French documentary "Tomorrow" swaps the usual handwringing doomsday prophesizing in favor of a decidedly more proactive approach.
Capturing every key moment with ... immediacy and tension ... director Piscatella maintains an engaging grip on his unassuming subject's ascendancy.
Ultimately, neither narrative receives sufficient attention, robbing the subjects and that unique p.o.v. of the focus and urgency that lent the previous two films their undeniable potency.

OK, so it will never be mistaken for vintage Pedro Almodovar or Bigas Luna, but the feel-good satire How to Be a Latin Lover nevertheless gives you less cause to be a hater than you might have expected.
movie_title: How to Be a Latin Lover (2017)

movie_review_blurb: A slab of D-grade, B-movie nonsense set in a maximum security military prison that serves as a cover for a secret drone control operation.

Healy is never able to find an absorbing middle ground in Mike Makowsky's script, vacillating gratingly between shrill farce and murky thriller that flails its way toward an intended twist-ending that really shouldn't surprise anyone.
Endlessly fascinating, bracingly up-to-the-minute ...

All the inter-cutting between the barren stage and the barren desert ultimately has a distancing, artificial effect that waters down much of the dramatic potency generated by the shared experience of a live performance.
Despite the casting overhaul, it's the same old Wimpy Kid in that it still hasn't figured out how to make its characters as likeable or knowingly engaging as Kinney's simple line drawings and text.
movie_title: Diary Of A Wimpy Kid: The Long Haul (2017)

movie_review_blurb: The adventure seldom gets sufficiently up to speed, and on the occasions it threatens to come to life, the pedestrian action sequences fail to compensate for that lethargic pace.
The term "inspirational" gets bandied about a lot, but "Becoming Bulletproof" is thoroughly deserving of that tag.
Like "The Big Chill" and "Peter's Friends" but without a single character you'd want to spend five minutes with, let alone a weekend, "The Drama Club" makes for a crassly unpleasant ensemble piece.
Mendelsohn and Reynolds are terrific, each wrapping himself up in the material like a well-worn favorite sweater.
Artificiality prevents this trite mother-daughter dramedy from hitting home.
Leave it to the folks who brought us Wallace & Gromit, Chicken Run and Flushed Away to bring a delightful blast of fresh air to the conventional Christmas genre.
Mild tween fare that would have been more at home on the small screen.
A sweet 'n' sassy period comedy with a Juno sensibility and the soul of a Little Miss Sunshine.
Fortunately McGrath ultimately moves beyond the shtick and keeps things moving at an agreeable pace, relying on his talented ensemble to capably close the deal.
movie_title: I Don't Know How She Does It (2011)

movie_review_blurb: There are some dedicated performances, but this unfocused drama adds nothing new to the girls' boarding school film curriculum.
For all the digitally enhanced Smurfness, the results are remarkably mirthless.
Justin Timberlake and Mila Kunis make for engaging leads in this unexpectedly fresh R-rated comedy.

After a beguiling once-upon-a-time beginning... the charm begins wearing off as the film gets bogged down in more contemporary, uninteresting notions of identity and sexual empowerment, leading to a shoulder-shrugging ending.
What happens in Bangkok isn't as much fun as when it happened in Vegas, but it's still worth the trip.
A stirring treatise on the nature of violence from the Danish director of After the Wedding.
Viewers get paddled into submission in this strident frat-house thriller.
Sensitive performances smooth out the dramatic rough spots of this well-intentioned, racially-charged drama.
Highly entertaining and arguably the most satisfying Richler screen adaptation to date.
Despite the novel approach to Shakespeare's oft-told tale of doomed love, this 3D animated garden gnome variation never fully comes to life.
An undeniably engaging musical portrait that delivers major bangs for the buck.
An effective ensemble backed by a bracingly haunting soundtrack strike a compelling chord in this rural Canadian crime drama.
A dramatically inert, lethargic dramedy that isn't nearly as quirky and poignant is it perceives itself.
movie_title: It's Kind of a Funny Story (2010)

movie_review_blurb: This unsettling, effective American remake really gets under the skin as one of the year's most powerful thrillers.
Spacey's splendid in this brisk and engaging portrait of the disgraced Washington lobbyist.

Presumably a glib attack on sanctimonious small-town religious hypocrisy informed by Black's own strict Mormon upbringing, the film is tonally all over the place, eventually settling in a rut that comes a lot closer to resembling bad camp than edgy satire
When all is said and done, their Pulitzer-winning photographs prove more potent than this well-intended but frustratingly generic picture.

Although the Canada-Germany co-production from first-time feature director Larysa Kondracki isn't as gripping as it could have been, that's no fault of Weisz's: She gives a bracing, wholly connected performance.
The result proves to be as appealing and effervescent as a flute of flat champagne.
A spare, unflinching examination of a married couple coping with the tragic death of their 18-year-old son.
There's an old belief in TV series production circles that if you're doing a stuck-in-an-elevator episode before Season 4, it's a telltale sign you've run fresh out of ideas.
More funhouse than grindhouse, this unrated horror-comedy has its D-grade charms thanks to its killer cast.
Despite the added dimension, Knoxville and company end up falling flat on their aspirations.
A darkly mischievous, bracingly original and thoroughly captivating Yuletide import.
Despite some entertaining moments, this long-in-gestation crime-fighter feature never reaches top speed.
Soggy theatrics render this gorgeously-shot underwater 3D excursion more shrill than thrilling.
Canet has difficulty maintaining the film's finely calibrated tragic-comedic balance in the heavily maudlin third act, much to its detriment.
Well, at least it isn't in 3D.
Proves as scary and unsettling as a slab of devil's food cake - only considerably less satisfying.
To his credit, director Asger Leth (Ghosts of Cite Soleil) gets right to the business at hand where the set-up is concerned, but it's in the execution that this would-be thriller falls flat.
That crack cast still keeps things involving, especially Rapace's emotionally and physically disfigured Beatrice.
With its secret, magical worlds and legions of evil-battling leafy warriors, there's plenty here to engage young audiences of both genders.

While the new edition doesn't quite catch that inspired spark, there's still plenty to enjoy here courtesy of those zippy visuals and a pitch-perfect voice cast led by the innately animated Steve Carell.
An engaging, intelligent, character-driven addition to the well-pillaged heist genre.
The Thor Freudenthal-directed Percy Jackson: Sea of Monsters, which actually runs about 10 minutes shorter than its 2010 predecessor, lacks the energetic zip of the Chris Columbus-helmed installment.
Despite the more aerodynamic setting, this Cars 3D offshoot emerges as an uninspired retread.
A tender cinema verite take on one man's quest for spiritual redemption.
This desperate Twilight wannabe hits more than its own share of clunky notes.
movie_title: The Mortal Instruments: City of Bones (2013)

movie_review_blurb: Vince Vaughn gives his all as a prolific sperm donor in this fluffy, innocuous comedy.
First-rate CG effects do battle with third-rate dialogue in this 3D adventure based on acclaimed BBC series.
A whimsical period setting helps this 3D animated caper escape some overly familiar trappings.
A full-throttle, giddily inventive, all-ages joyride that buoyantly boosts the bar for 3D computer-animated movies.
You won't be treated to any rousing choruses of "Some Enchanted Evening" in Journey to the South Pacific, but this equally exotic Imax entry proves enchanting in its own right.
Another typically engaging, vividly shot entry in the successful Disney wildlife series.
While not as delightfully breezy as the original, an engaging voice cast and hordes of "Foodimals" still manage to serve up a tasty sequel.
movie_title: Cloudy with a Chance of Meatballs 2 (2013)

movie_review_blurb: A giddily over-the-top, super-entertaining goof on the Everyman crimefighter flick written and directed with evident relish by James Gunn.

What Escape from Planet Earth may lack in novelty, it compensates for with a zippy pace and lively voice characterizations, led by Brendan Fraser, Sarah Jessica Parker, Sofia Vergara and William Shatner.
Chasing Mavericks manages to sufficiently overcome the obstacles with admittedly affecting results.
Lawrence Kasdan's pleasant dramedy boasts a prized ensemble but lacks bite.
The merging of dramatic re-creations and on-camera "performances" proves less seamlessly executed than those masterfully coordinated land, sea and air missions.

Armed with a splendid voice cast and a gorgeously-rendered 3D-CG landscape, Dr. Seuss' The Lorax entertains while delivering its pro-environmental, anti-greed message wrapped in a bright package of primary colors that truly pop.
Co-directors Lord and Miller keep the comic pace humming along agreeably with the same sort of animated energy they provided for those raining meatballs.
This unexpected Best Animated Feature Oscar nominee is sleek, stylish animated escapade that makes vivid, affecting use of its brief running time.
A rock solid Samuel L. Jackson adeptly anchors the twists and turns of this noir crime thriller.
The end result should appeal to audiences, including bonding grandparents and grandkids, looking for a little undemanding holiday cheer.
Beauty and the Beast meets Sergio Leone in this amusing Western import.
This keenly-observed, if generically-assembled, Grunge-era doc tells the Hole story through the eyes of its successfully rehabbed drummer.
The third installment in the "Wimpy Kid" franchise turns out to be not so wimpy after all.
movie_title: Diary of a Wimpy Kid: Dog Days (2012)

movie_review_blurb: The third time might not be the charm, but this harmless family comedy proves more pleasant than its episodic 2011 installment.
movie_title: Diary of a Wimpy Kid: Dog Days (2012)

movie_review_blurb: It has its entertaining moments, but this paranormal stop-motion animated comedy-chiller cries out for more activity.
Ferrell and Galifianakis make for entertaining rivals in a flimsy political satire that too often mistakes bad taste for comic acuity.
A scarily unfunny animated monster movie that goes awry right off the bat.
An attractive, game cast helps liven up this handsome but overlong urban rom-com.
This peculiar little road movie is full of tiny, irresistible surprises.
Self-possessed performances elevate this creepy but half-cocked faux-doc.
A bloody entertaining blast of a flesh-eating fish-out-of-water story.
Head-poundingly (in a good way), sidesplittingly funny.
Diabolically entertaining.
Despite the ever-energetic Tony Scott at the throttle, the sleek new edition isn't as transporting as it should have been.
Terrific performances make this tender if slight little film worth the trip.
Prehistory repeats itself in this dispiritingly slothful third installment.
movie_title: Ice Age: Dawn of the Dinosaurs (Ice Age 3) (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Increasingly formulaic plotting clouds an otherwise brisk rom-com.
Not a perfect 10, but the Wayans crew hit their mark more than they miss.
An unmitigated B-movie that isn't thrilling enough or cheesy enough to make it worth the trip.

Jorge Franco's novel about a young Colombian couple who take a shot at the American Dream and land at the far side of paradise has made a vibrant transition to the big screen courtesy of acclaimed commercial and music video director Simon Brand.
The Collector grafts a torture porn payoff onto a heist thriller setup with messy, illogical results.
This savvy, music-fueled high school comedy really rocks.
An aggressively hard-sell of a loud, abrasive comedy.
movie_title: The Goods: Live Hard, Sell Hard (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Despite its dependable cast, this ponderous road movie remains stuck in the slow lane.
Manhattan's storied hotel is the timely subject of this passionate tribute.
A 3D ball of energy, but its furry characters are flatly run-of-the-treadmill.
A bloody, disgusting blast.
A chilling look at the monks' uprising inside Burma in 2007.
movie_title: Burma VJ: Reporter i et Lukket Land (Burma VJ: Reporting from a Closed Country) (2008)

movie_review_blurb: The machines rise to the occasion. Too bad the dramatic element's just as robotic.
This snowy Minnesota rom-com is as funny as frostbite.
Round 3 in the vampire-werewolf battle to the undeath rises to the occasion.
movie_title: Underworld: The Rise of the Lycans (2009)

movie_review_blurb: "Narcopolis" starts off intriguingly and ends solidly. It's everything else in between that isn't particularly compelling.
The packaging is appealing, but the previously owned contents are flimsy.
An over-cranked teen comedy that only travels so far on its one-gag premise.
It's business as usual at Camp Crystal Lake, with very little in the way of fresh jolts or an innovative visual style that would have really revitalized the hokey franchise.
This time around there's a little more life on display.
movie_title: Night at the Museum 2: Battle of the Smithsonian (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Stripped of that sociological context, the extreme brutality here can't help but feel more than a little exploitative, especially where the film's female victims are concerned.
movie_title: The Last House on the Left (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Travels in some unexpected, thoughtful directions.
A terrifically cast bittersweet coming-of-age story -- ticks and all.
Miley's return to her Tennessee roots goes a little heavy on the country corn.
Unfortunately, the whole seldom adds up to the sum of its illustrious parts, and Jarmusch's trademark deadpan quirks seem to have gotten lost in the translation.
Pixar again raises the bar to wondrous new heights.
Michael Caine raises this odd-couple comedy to highly agreeable levels.
This first feature by Ray Griggs wears its Mad Magazine influences like a badge of honor but fails to round up enough laughs to save the day.
While the delivery isn't the smoothest, this portrait of a sociopath comic still hits its keenly-observed marks.
One of the fall's funniest films -- honest.
Sophie Okonedo again shines in this unusual but fact-based apartheid drama.
Good luck staying awake.
Just trite.
A giddy Diddy turn aside, this wildly uneven comedy doesn't travel very far.
Woody, Buzz and playmates make a thoroughly engaging, emotionally satisfying return.
Although Josh Brolin rises to the occasion, much of this comic book adaptation appears to have been abandoned on the cutting-room floor.
A lyrical, if slight, breeze of an Irish fable.
The cleverly constructed film manages the neat feat of containing all ingredients of a potential hit while remaining true to Egoyan's body of work.
While it's nice to see they all got along so swell, it would have been nicer if we could have shared in all the frivolity.
Makes its own distinct impression thanks to a finely tuned attention to atmospheric detail over broad sci-fi sensationalism.
More is not necessarily scarier in this often lively but scattered reboot.
The cinematic adventures of Beverly Cleary's pint-sized big dreamer comes up short on scope and imagination.
Just when it seemed like the once-robust buddy-cop action-comedy was going to require a do-not-resuscitate order, along comes Will Ferrell and Adam McKay to show 'em how it's done.
Clumsy dramatics aside, this gimmicky sequel delivers on the dance floor.
A colorful supporting cast gives this uneven Internet porn saga a potent boost.
A revealing portrait of the freedom-fighting man beneath the silk pajamas.
movie_title: Hugh Hefner: Playboy, Activist and Rebel (2010)

movie_review_blurb: Derivative bits aside, the pint-sized Japanese icon takes flight in vibrant CG animation -- no 3D glasses required.
Let the 2010 Razzies race begin!
Saving the day is Harrelson's low-key, rooted performance, adding an unexpected layer of poignancy when things take a decidedly darker turn.
If Duffy's decade away has proved to be a humbling experience, you wouldn't know it from this bloated follow-up, which tonally goes all over the place, but its primary direction is over the top.
movie_title: The Boondock Saints II: All Saints Day (2009)

movie_review_blurb: This stiff paranormal thriller could stand a lot more activity.
Missed opportunities and surface gestures aside, Hancock draws affable, energetic performances from all concerned.
Incoming director Weitz is a smart choice for the material.
An initially intriguing plot line makes a messy getaway in this throwback heist movie.
Ross Bagdasarian's enduring characters are a bit tougher to endure in this charmless sequel.
movie_title: Alvin and the Chipmunks: The Squeakquel (2009)

movie_review_blurb: An unexpectedly stirring first feature by Kyle Patrick Alvarez about the challenges of making human connections in the weird and wired 21st century.
An uneven romantic comedy that feels as fresh as a hunk of week-old soda bread.
Travolta has/is a blast in an action-thriller-comedy that otherwise comes up short on all three counts.
Not so much howlingly bad as it is disappointingly lifeless.
Any actual action's an afterthought in this garrulous goof on the classic buddy-cop flick.
This spirited yet faithful George Romero remake has the makings of a certified hit.
A fantastical romp that proves every bit as transporting as that movie about the blue people of Pandora, his Alice is more than just a gorgeous 3D sight to behold.
A beguiling kaleidoscopic indulgence for the eyes and soul.
An intense Mel Gibson performance anchors this brutally effective crime thriller.

Dutifully covering all the requisite inspirational sports movie/fish-out-of-water bases yet still managing to throw a few fresh curves into the mix, Disney's Million Dollar Arm assuredly hits a home run.
Director Paul McGuigan and screenwriter David Boula are content to rely on the usual suspects, taking their visual and dramatic cues from other, more clever and involving sci-fi capers.
An engagingly oddball sports documentary that's as much about community as it is about competition.
It would be hard to imagine a more entertaining corrupt-cop documentary than "The Seven Five," a slick and fascinating portrait of disgraced New York policeman Michael Dowd.

The bizarro plot threads, and dippy characters fail to connect in any rewarding way, resulting in a largely unfunny film that proves as repetitive and tedious as the 1971 Philip Glass snippet that provides its entire score.
The somber period western "Echoes of War" retraces some well-traveled moral ground but is invigorated by a cast that includes James Badge Dale, Ethan Embry and William Forsythe.
Combining those stirringly shot vistas with easy-to-digest scientific fact-finding, the documentary is not so much a call to action as a moving portrait ...
Compared with the other anti-fracking docs that have preceded it, "Groundswell Rising" doesn't dig deeply enough.
movie_title: Groundswell Rising, Protecting Our Children's Air and Water (2014)

movie_review_blurb: Director Marah Strauch gives the film an exhilarating uplift of its own.
An energetic, entertainingly assembled documentary portrait ...
movie_title: Soul Boys Of The Western World (2015)

movie_review_blurb: When going for gritty realism, it doesn't hurt to have your lead actress essentially playing herself.
Comes across as a squirm-inducing heap of propaganda at its most self-congratulatory.
The rom-com isn't such a lost cause, after all. It was just waiting for someone like indie filmmaker Andrew Bujalski to resuscitate it.

It's not every day you get to see a satanic-revenge home-invasion martial-arts thriller, but should another come along that's as laughably cornball as "The Cain Complex," you'd best hide until it blows over.

Although the results could never be accused of being uneventful, the characters cry out for deeper, more complex dimensions than simply the wide-eyed dreamer and the rhetoric-spewing agitator on display here.
This film keeps reaching for cleverness but comes up with a fistful of clichés.

The quirky visual poetry eventually proceeds to work its magic, paving the way for an unexpected final act that cracks open a long-shuttered door on the life of a man who was, in his own words, "losing hope in tomorrow."
[A] stagy, overstuffed costume drama.
The film's oddball assortment of broadly played characters feel like sketch comedy escapees stretched beyond their limits, an attempt to fill the demands of a feature-length canvas.
This energetic film satisfyingly brings viewers up to speed on Newman's remarkably enduring career detour.
movie_title: Winning: The Racing Life Of Paul Newman (2015)

movie_review_blurb: A cliché-ridden, heavy-handed redemptive drama written and directed by Rustam Branaman.
As long as it shuts up and keeps moving, "Tracers" makes for a sufficiently diverting, not to mention zero-emission, vehicle.
Director Hilarion Banks dutifully captures all of it in a series of nicely shot extended takes, which would have been fine if the cast had been able to interact in some sort of uniform tone.
"The Forecaster," a documentary study of the rise and fall of commodities advisor Martin Armstrong, would have paid greater dividends by taking a more impartial approach to its subject.
Jacoby's carefully crafted film deftly blends archival footage with dramatic re-creations and interviews with surviving family members to illuminating effect.
movie_title: My Italian Secret: The Forgotten Heroes (2015)

movie_review_blurb: Although Lambert .. died in 1981, his presence is felt in the rich archival footage and the perceptive on-screen accounts that compellingly demonstrate the alchemy that can transpire when kismet and perseverance intersect ...
Summers' big-screen take on those ongoing group tensions surrounding Sting's reluctance to be considered a career team player constantly strikes a by now all-too-familiar, predominantly sour, chord.
Uneven but nonetheless emotionally gratifying ...
Unfortunately, Presswell's direction and his writing (with Andras Forgacs W.) simply aren't up to the task at hand.
The film offers a valuable life lesson in the powers of determination and timing, but most of all it's darned entertaining.
A strikingly poetic documentary that illustrates the push and pull of life's opposing forces.

Stewart, who narrates, ultimately learns that advocacy begins at home. We, unfortunately, learn very little in this Earth Day release that we haven't seen before in more evolved, better focused documentaries.
A forced comedy that mines uneasy humor from stale stereotypes.
For anyone who's not a Francophone tween girl, the film likely will be a tedious, precious exercise in indulgence.
Surprisingly affecting.
Although the performances are uniformly on point and the dialogue is tartly British, the film ultimately fails to earn its riotous stripes.
Horvath ... records every wind-swept activity with geological precision, but he dispenses with any sociological context regarding what continues to be a highly male-centric conceit.
This evangelical "Dear America: Letters Home From Vietnam" by way of "The Dukes of Hazzard" takes a mighty ridiculous route to righteousness.
A densely atmospheric, Sergio Leone-steeped western that ultimately proves too reverential for its own good.
[A] Bible study class of a feature film ...
A satirical romantic comedy that gets mixed grades in the laughter department.
"Bloodsucking Bastards" only occasionally matches the inspiration of its jokey title.
By widening his soulful puppy eyes - matched only, quite eerily, by those of his French bulldog in real life, Arrow - Schwartzman successfully dares audiences to care.
Beginning with a gentle lullaby and ending with a tightly packed wallop, "Goodnight Mommy" is one viscerally chilling, seriously unsettling horror film.
A glossy, cliché-laden revenge thriller about the perils of meeting Mr. Too Good To Be True.
Another cautionary yarn about a political hopeful whose adulterous behavior catches up with him, Mora Stephens' "Zipper" hits a snag from the get-go.

It's all pleasant enough, but the film, ultimately more of a checklist than an in-depth analysis, never really shines any fresh light on Canada's identity crisis or gets to the source of all those preconceived notions.
Like an uncle making a long-winded, embarrassing toast to the bride, Smith may have a lot of defining childhood memories at his disposal, but that doesn't mean they all need to be shared.
movie_title: My Last Year With The Nuns (2015)

movie_review_blurb: There's infinitely more than one anomaly to be found in "The Anomaly," a thoroughly nonsensical futuristic sci-fi thriller that makes a case for the perils of vanity projects.
There's still no shortage of sight gags, but most of them work.
An unpleasant, dramatically inert drama surrounding a Jonestown-type commune.
A dull, meandering romantic comedy with serious believability issues.
Legends of Oz: Dorothy's Return is visually energetic but tonally all over the Yellow Brick Road map.
The mechanical script strands a capable young cast in a sea of hackneyed character types and soggy platitudes.
It's a wonder the two lead characters in "Meet Me in Montenegro" manage to take in any of the vibrant sights, what with all the navel-gazing that permeates this mopey romantic comedy.
An intriguing set-up yields a disappointingly ponderous payoff in Craig Zobel's post-apocalyptic drama, "Z for Zachariah."
"Learning to Drive" is a richly observed, crosscultural character study that coasts along pleasurably on the strengths of its virtuoso leads.
A standard-issue female vigilante thriller that's skillfully elevated by the performances of leads Viola Davis and Jennifer Lopez.

Expertly playing with our preconceived notions, Granik's multidimensional portrait also serves as a telling state-of-the-union address, as seen through the caring eyes of her philosophical main subject.
The film taps into some genuine, relatable truths lurking beneath all that try-too-hard quirkiness.
As this cosmopolitan documentary progresses, it migrates from cute and effervescent to seriously affecting.

With its solid performances, nice attention to period detail and a foreboding rumble of a symphonic score by Jan Duszynski, Jack Strong adds a unique Eastern Bloc POV to the enduring Cold War movie arsenal.
Gameau, like a certain beloved British nanny, recognizes the value in a spoonful of you-know-what helping the medicine go down.

What begins as a quirky portrait of the artist as a gringo mariachi troubadour proves to be a telling study of a lost soul whose palpable passion for his music acts as a surrogate for more meaningful human contact.
A colorfully constructed film surveying the vastness of the Lego universe that can't help but come across as corporate horn-tooting.
Working off a budget of $16 million, filmmaker Choi Dong-hoon keeps the unapologetically mainstream but twisty story moving along engagingly despite some less-than-seamless shifts in time.
An unpleasant exercise in self-indulgence directed and written by Paul Bojack.
A hollow, listless political drama that could have been a contender.
A promising setup is left to wither in the intense Albuquerque sun permeating "Big Sky," a slack agoraphobic thriller marking the English-language debut of Mexican filmmaker Jorge Michel Grau.
Although the disaffected youth drama knows no international boundaries, few have felt as fresh and consistently unpredictable as the slyly satirical "Prince" by Dutch filmmaker Sam de Jong.
A savvy documentary that gives the granddaddy of extreme sports his due while gauging the national climate that welcomed his shrewdly timed arrival.
Comes across as an agency fundraising tool rather than an organic documentary portrait.
This portrait of strong, independent women grappling with change in their individual lives holds initial allure, but the effect proves ephemeral.
A densely atmospheric portrait of disaffected youth by artist-filmmaker Daniel Peddle that flouts preconceived notions at every unconventional turn.
There's a veil of artifice clinging to every aspect of "The Lovers," a thoroughly unconvincing time-traveling epic costume drama pairing a miscast Josh Hartnett and Bollywood beauty Bipasha Basu.
Melancholy runs deep in "Private Peaceful," a richly appointed British period piece about fraternal loyalty adapted from the book of the same name by "War Horse" author Michael Morpurgo.
The journey taken by Junger and company was likely more rewarding for the participants than it will be for audiences.
"Magical Universe" is a tender portrait of the artist as a weirdly gifted, wildly prolific and strange man.
All that extensively researched authenticity and soul-stirring cinematography go only so far in establishing a compelling connection to a specific time and place.
An engaging documentary following the idealistic political campaign waged by 22-year-old Michael Tubbs, "True Son" offers an object lesson in the power of conviction.
Director Richard Gray, the writer's husband and a man obsessed with slow motion, doesn't build necessary tension into the playfully pulpy material.
Those eager young faces and Weaver's informed, reassuring tones only go so far in a production that seldom pulls back to reveal a broader sociological scope beyond its few interview subjects.
While there are plenty of madcap antics to fill a feature, all that manic energy ultimately proves to be more exhausting than exhilarating.
Virtually everything about this production feels thrown together.
A curious documentary by Oscar-nominated filmmaker Marshall Curry that makes interesting observations about contemporary thrill seekers.

Darling's documentary is garden-variety filmmaking, but it does an effective job in illustrating how years of fiscal crises have forced academia and industry to forge alliances that once would have been considered unlikely.
The film puts a brave, much-adored face on a disease that has touched so many families.

Although the resulting tonal shifts between funny and serious aren't always executed as seamlessly as they might be, Khoury deserves props for defying rom-com conventions more often than he succumbs to them.

With its sweeping visuals and colorful pageantry, the film, directed and written by Sadyk Sher-Niyaz, certainly provides a stirring backdrop for its patriotic narrative, although, as edited, some of the chronological compression can be tricky to follow.
movie_title: Kurmanjan Datka Queen Of The Mountains (2014)

movie_review_blurb: A savvy if uneven satire about a struggling 29-year-old actress whose career peaked two decades earlier.
You don't have to speak the language to get drawn into the captivating performances - or set your toes tapping.
Writer-director Barnaby weaves a surprising amount of tenderness into the fabric of violence, as well as a good measure of magic realism, to keep the gritty story engaging.
"E-Team" has a ripped-from-the-headlines immediacy as it takes the viewer on an intense ride-along with Human Rights Watch investigators.
Despite all those echoes of classic '80s sci-fi fantasy adventures, Earth to Echo proves engaging in its own right.
Dolphin Tale 2 is another engaging film inspired by the real-life inhabitants of the Clearwater Marine Aquarium.
The Dark Horse is an emotionally potent story of redemption anchored by a heart-piercing lead performance from Cliff Curtis.
There's a palpable, soulful authenticity to the musical performances, which ultimately draw you in ...
"Christmas Ride" is so inept on every level that it almost has to be seen to be believed. Almost.
A ceaseless, hurtin' tune of a music-driven romantic drama, "The Song" plays out its tired refrain with all the subtlety of a Sunday sermon.
A film that would have been more potent had it been a 40-minute short rather than a feature-length proposition.
Though not entirely an original concept, this vibrantly shot, East-meets-West fusion of Wushu and Washington never feels like a cheap forgery.
[A] smart, relentlessly chilling thriller that opts for originality over cheaply rejiggered jolts.
Visually inspired but thematically derivative, the apocalyptic sci-fi drama "Automata" pits humans against robots with predictable results.
Fittingly enlightening, "Awake: The Life of Yogananda" is a vivid, elegantly assembled portrait of the savvy guru with the cherubic face and penetrating gaze who brought meditation to the West.
Often-intriguing if not completely absorbing viewing.

Stepping behind the camera, versatile actor Dylan Baker makes an assured directorial debut, drawing spirited performances from his seasoned cast while mainly steering clear of the usual, treacly movie-of-the week conventions.
East meets West to immensely satisfying effect in the vibrant mash-up of an animated romp, Big Hero 6.

Whether the crypto-currency in this documentary film is viewed as the inevitable future of e-commerce or a speculative bubble destined to burst, "The Rise and Rise of Bitcoin" makes for an enlightening primer.
movie_title: The Rise and Rise of Bitcoin (2014)

movie_review_blurb: Inept on every level, "Panic 5 Bravo" is a virtually unwatchable, blood-soaked crime drama serving as the writing-directing debut of actor Kuno Becker.
A talky adult comedy that finally succumbs to the confines of its setting despite a cute setup.
Although the documentary can feel like a volunteer instructional video at times, the faces on those who have fallen through the cracks in the system speak volumes.
"Suburban Gothic" misses the mark, but thanks largely to its cult-worthy cast, the miss can still be fun.
While it has plenty of zany moments, SpongeBob's second feature outing proves less absorbing than the first.
movie_title: The SpongeBob Movie: Sponge Out of Water (2015)

movie_review_blurb: Frantic and flagrantly formulaic, this forced farce about a sham engagement sacrifices plot credibility and character motivation for stale humor and cheap setups.
A faith-based inspirational drama that plays like an after-Sunday-school special.
Just when it looked like the vampire genre had been bled dry, along comes the insanely inspired horror-satire "What We Do in the Shadows" to give it fresh bite.
movie_title: What We Do In The Shadows (2015)

movie_review_blurb: Disturbing is the film's apparent conviction that the surefire way to a woman's heart involves lots of candles and a mani-pedi, the sort of notion that isn't so much cute and old-fashioned as it is acutely offensive.
The film looks as though the bulk of the budget was reserved for ammo.
An entertaining documentary following two years in the life of an idealistic amateur filmmaker intent on becoming Canada's first action hero.
It's so rare for an American film to boast a pair of 60-year-old protagonists, you wish "Roxie" had been much better than the squirm-inducing, aging-white-male fantasy that emerges.
Tough to categorize, tougher to shrug off, "Buzzard" firmly places young indie filmmaker Joel Potrykus on the ones-to-watch list.

Dispensing with any heated rhetoric about the sorry state of education, director Pascal Plisson instead allows this quartet of beautifully photographed incredible journeys speak inspirational volumes.

While the end result feels a tad overstuffed at 92 minutes, it's entirely understandable if, after more than half a century of being identified as "that guy," Miller's in no hurry to relinquish the spotlight.
A dead pet isn't the only inert element of "Murder of a Cat," a plodding comic caper that fails to deliver.

There may be no place like home, but there are a lot of places like Home, an animated adventure about the unlikely friendship between a lonely girl and an alien misfit that can't help but feel familiar.
The script, co-written by director Georgina Garcia Riedel and Jose Nestor Marquez, plays like a first draft that misses out on comic opportunities.
There's little that feels direct-to-video about this lively, surprisingly cinematic CG adventure.
movie_title: TinkerBell and the Legend of the NeverBeast (2014)

movie_review_blurb: Attempting to capture the screwball essence of the old-school suspense-comedy ... Lawrence Michael Levine's flighty "Wild Canaries" lacks the filmmaking discipline required to pay effective homage.
Jude Law makes for an effective rogue submarine captain in "Black Sea," a fittingly immersive thriller, tautly directed by Kevin MacDonald.

The age-old search for the fountain of youth is engagingly appraised in "The Immortalists," a lively documentary focusing on a pair of very different biomedical scientists who are equally obsessed with eradicating the ravages of time.
All three actors turn in solid, committed performances despite physically limiting surroundings, even as you're left with the inescapable feeling that this raft has sailed.
Despite the limited scope, the documentary, made for Japanese TV, puts a smile on the lips - and hope in the heart.
"Anything for Alice" handily demonstrates how there's no need to divert from the dog-eared romantic-comedy playbook when you've got a pair of ace players in your corner.
A poignant documentary about the transformative power of art.

A charming supporting cast fails to invigorate "Goodbye to All That," a relentlessly flat seriocomic take on contemporary relationships marking the directorial debut of "Junebug" scribe Angus MacLachlan.
A culinary and cultural odyssey that ultimately has much more on its plate than that spicy-sweet-crispy chicken.
Time to hang up the "Closed for Renovation" sign.
movie_title: Night at the Museum: Secret of the Tomb (2014)

movie_review_blurb: Tugging shamelessly yet persuasively on the heartstrings, "Ode to My Father" is an epic South Korean melodrama capturing more than half a century of recent history through the eyes of an everyman shopkeeper.
A documentary that too often feels manipulatively Machiavellian in its presentation of all those "irrefutable" facts and findings.

A shrill, garish hodgepodge of familiar elements from other animated vehicles (most evidently 2013's Epic), there's virtually nothing about this forced, fractured fairy tale that feels remotely fresh or involving.
A technically impressive but talky sci-fi drama that never quite comes to life.
"Me" lends a thoroughly unflattering name to the term "vanity project."
While the appropriately titled "Spare Parts" might feel like it has been assembled from bits and pieces of other inspirational movies, that doesn't mean the fact-based drama is any less effective ...
While undeniably gorgeous, at some point all those sweeping vistas can't help but feel like a pitch for Wyoming tourism.

This is the best movie of the year, yes I said it, I'm coming hot out of the gate here. It's funny, compelling, and there are so many things in this movie that reasonate so deeply as true, that I can't possibly cover them all.

Andrew Bujalski spends a hefty 105 minutes trying arduously to break the formula of a rom-com, meandering into bizarro dreamscapes and meditative vignettes and yet ultimately lands where the genre insists upon.
Blind is a strikingly beautiful and intuitive escape into the mind of a blind person, and Vogt writes and directs the film as if he has experienced such terror.
When your favorite songs bubble up, the marriage of sound and screen will win your tears, your smiles, and your soul. To paraphrase Wilson, Love & Mercy ... that's what you need tonight.
The D Train is an accessible celluloid debate on society's often expected barriers of sexuality.
Every arc and every twist is predictable from the get-go and the stakes are pretty low given the circumstances. But, there's something truly cozy about this picture. It's comfort food.
If you're looking for an exhausting mental exercise and interested in experiencing the physical trauma of a polar vortex, well, go forward with Aloft.
Despite Eric Gautier's dreamy scenery of Hawaii and an A-list cast that would give David O. Russell a hard-on, Cameron Crowe's Aloha lacks any emotional resonance.
Whatever purpose Vince's entourage might have served 10 years ago has long been buried for good in the Hollywood Forever Cemetery. This isn't a commentary on Tinseltown, but a tepid bachelor party.
Jurassic World is as much of a jumbled hybrid as its own featured dinosaur. It's an action-adventure blockbuster that feels very of its time: overstated, overstocked, overblown, and overdone.
There's no fate but what box office we can make.
Moments do drag and there are some questionable wrinkles in either character's arc, but Night Owls is a gratifying subversion of the romantic comedy genre.

The Martian thrives simply for its humor, its heart, and its magnificence, accomplishing what Christopher Nolan yearned to do with Interstellar less than a year ago: turn our eyes to the stars and our imagination beyond.
American Ultra works best as an alternative love story. It's cute, it's fun, it's unpretentious, and it's primed for future midnight screenings at home
As for Schwartzman, he remains the master salesman of the disenfranchised.

It's a relief to see Johnny Depp so alive, so visceral, and so overwhelming. Not since 2001's Blow, or better yet, 1998's Fear and Loathing in Las Vegas, has he taken a film and run away with it like this.
What unfolds is a transparent example of why the music industry continues to spiral downward toward a fiery hell.

Denis Villeneuve can do Blade Runner. Denis Villeneuve can do anything. At least, that's the feeling one has walking out of Sicario, arguably the savviest, smartest, and most exhilarating crime thriller to hit American cinemas in years.
It's cute, it's funny, it's exciting, and it'll remind you why you ever spent hours of your childhood dreaming about what might dwell in the basement or beneath the sink.
Rock the Kasbah never wrinkles out its speeches after wrenching them from its pockets, which elicits a jumbled tone that's neither funny nor serious nor coherent.
Adorable, faithful, and all sorts of innocent, The Peanuts Movie is a definitive family affair.

A cold, visceral, and overwhelming piece of cinema, The Revenant not only sets a new precedent for the survival genre but may be the strongest American film since Paul Thomas Anderson's There Will Be Blood.
For a character study, David Gordon Green can hardly do better than Manglehorn. It's a rustic film that capitalizes on the tokens of the past in a style that's less nostalgic and more endearing.

They got the job done with The Force Awakens, and while Abrams pays more homage than he rightfully should, he also introduces the most exciting characters Star Wars has seen since, not going to lie, Lando Calrissian and Lobot.
movie_title: Star Wars: Episode VII - The Force Awakens (2015)

movie_review_blurb: Fantastic Four is a patchy affair and one that's been stunted by a soulless and exposition-lined screenplay, which was likely scrapbooked together after juggling between the hands of Kinberg, Trank, and Slater.
Unfriended is a smart, thrilling, and addicting byte of horror that's worth thinking about. It'll be awhile before your mind hits CTRL + ALT + DEL on this one
Dead Snow 2: Red vs. Dead is even more fun than its predecessor, thanks to tight pacing, clever plotting, and an expanded mythology that stays true to its aura.
movie_title: Dead Snow 2: Red vs. Dead (Død snø 2) (2014)

movie_review_blurb: Hot Tub Time Machine 2 feels tepid, uninspiring, and comically hollow. It's about as innocuous and boring as a sequel can get and about as messy and unappealing as a hotel jacuzzi.
Wiener-Dog is a balmy, addicting stroll through Todd Solondz's not-so-delirious vision of America that charms just as much as it haunts.
J.C. Chandor's strongest meditation to date, a slice of American cinema that's as rare as it is beautiful.
Lack of necessity notwithstanding, The Gambler is also plagued by its vacancy of spiritual tissue.
Exodus: Gods and Kings is exactly the sort of film Hollywood doesn't need anymore: a gluttonous epic that fails to evoke or teach or entertain.
An intense and intimate experience that's relentless in its warmth and chills. To date, depression has never felt so delicate and hypnotic on film.
The entertainment is watching them think, fumble, stumble, and win. It's what made the original such a success, and it's what makes this sequel at the very least acceptable.
Bennett Miller's merciless direction and strong performances by Carell, Tatum, and the ever lovable Ruffalo make Foxcatcher one of this season's more essential viewings
If you really wanna hear the most annoying sound in the world, head to your local theater and listen to America laugh at this heartless drivel.
Watching Murray putz around in a world where danger and happy endings co-exist is a breath of fresh air, albeit familiar but refreshing nonetheless.
VHS: Viral fractures its format with gluttonous camera work, excessive CGI, and pandering sentiments that are more preachy than legitimately frightening.
If Kill the Messenger champions anything, it's that Renner's Oscar racing days go well beyond The Hurt Locker. It's not an "if" anymore; it's a matter of "when."
Whatever celluloid renaissance David Cronenberg once experienced seems to be cracking and his latest production adds a nasty fissure.
Tusk does for zoos what Jaws did for beaches, A Nightmare on Elm Street did for sleeping, and A Silence of the Lambs did for skin lotion.
A Walk in the Woods never indulges in the darkness that such an excursion might warrant, but it captures a rare, hearty chemistry that only two veterans of this caliber could scrounge up.
There's this weird, unshakeable feeling of nostalgia by the time the credits roll: the party's over, it's time to go home, but damn, what a night.
Mistress America is chewy philosophical pop with a clear dedication to style. It's all very hip, it's all very fun, and it's all very smart. It's just not very affectionate.
It'll tug at your heart and send you straight to your vinyl collection - that's a good thing.
Dope is a smart if not hefty comedy by a filmmaker who has a lot to say and yet still much to learn.
A poignant documentary for a time when nostalgia runs rampant, satire's under fire, and comedy's experiencing its own renaissance.
movie_title: Drunk Stoned Brilliant Dead: The Story of the National Lampoon (2015)

movie_review_blurb: Marriage is hard, parenting is impossible, and life will always invite mystery. Swanberg and Johnson know this first hand and it's that knowledge that empowers Digging for Fire.
A hollow piece of fantasy horror that opens the door before knocking.
Lack of subtlety downgrades True Story into a crumpled piece of questionable non-fiction.
There's nothing promiscuous about this sexually charged thriller. It's a total romp with hilarious, predictable tension and unruly visual metaphors that press the tongue way beyond the cheek.
What should have been a smart political farce is instead a slapstick nightmare, record skip and all, whose laughs are too dependent on volume
Blackhat isn't interested in being a Michael Mann film. It's a serviceable crime thriller with the confused aspirations of wanting to be the next Jason Bourne vehicle.
Lanthimos trumps the outlandish premise and turns the film into accessible and timeless reverie. It's a spark of ingenuity that doesn't rely on subversions or meta humor. Just originality.

...once more Allen seems to be of the mindset of his own protagonist. Only here, Allen comes across less like the reinvigorated Lucas and more like the dilapidated Lucas, bored and unconvinced by his own work, trade, and influences.
Certain Women is not always thrilling, but it's certainly faithful.

Some stories actually end. Some characters don't deserve another go-around. Some tales are best left untold ... simply because they never needed to be told in the first place. It only takes a whopping three minutes of Bad Santa 2 to realize this.
The Force should have been stronger with this one.
movie_title: Rogue One: A Star Wars Story (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Robert D. Siegel delivers a meat-and-potatoes screenplay that offers very little nuance and chows down on banner statements that move the story along at a pace akin to an average McDonald's counter.
Robert De Niro and Leslie Mann's time together is weirdly charming, recalling the tit-for-tat banter between Michelle Pfeiffer and Al Pacino in Garry Marshall's Frankie and Johnny.
While American Fable isn't without its share of flaws, it's the type of inventive production that hints of happier endings to come.

Logan is a total anomaly. James Mangold turns the key on the tawdry, predictable superhero formula, delivering both his best film to date and one of the most game-changing comic book adaptations to ever leave the pages.
This is the La La Land of car chase movies, a jaw-shattering spectacle of sight and sound that sets the bar through the roof for any filmmakers currently cutting their teeth in music videos.

It's a dense character study that rests on the shoulders of Jake Johnson, who delivers his strongest performance to date, casually handling every scene with a magnetism that recalls the likes of '70s era De Niro and Caan.

Anyone who grew up watching Michael Mann's Miami Vice will be on cloud nine reveling at how the New Wave classics turn the film's feverish action into something of a cotton candy dream - sugary, weightless, creative, and beautiful.
A very effective story that works as a love letter to both a life and a city in transition.
The Transfiguration is a curious horror film that uses the vampire medium to the best of its abilities, sinking its teeth in all the right places.
Small Crimes offers big thrills, and they're not always cheap; in fact, they're pretty cold-hearted and that's exactly the point.
Elijah Bynum's directorial debut, Hot Summer Nights, is a brazen anti-coming-of-age thriller that oozes with all the right confidence, chutzpah, and passion.

After a long, storied career of engaging, thought-provoking films, Ridley Scott has succumbed to the gutless predictability that Pauline Kael initially envisioned, and Alien: Covenant is precisely the carnival fare she saw in the 1979 original.
Rough Night isn't the sharpest movie, but that doesn't mean it isn't a blast.
Spider-Man: Homecoming is an enchanting reminder why we ever hid comic books under our bed in the first place.

The whole movie is so affecting that Pennywise doesn't even matter. In a way, he's more of a McGuffin to the real horrors at hand, from parental abuse to violent bullying to the unnerving revelation that life has only just begun.

With plenty of nostalgic music by the one and only Randy Newman, it's easy to get the sense that The Meyerowitz Stories (New and Selected) is also a love letter to a past that's disappearing by the day.
With Creep 2, you're never truly convinced the narrative is going the way you think it's going, and while that may be frustrating to some, it's enchanting for those looking for one good scare.
Last Flag Flying is a treacly slog that's regretfully forgettable.

There's a musicality to Wain's direction that's addicting, and the emotional punch in the final five minutes proves there's a future for the filmmaker that goes way beyond the yucks. In that respect, A Futile and Stupid Gesture is anything but that.
What you get here is a battlefield of comedy and action, one that's self-aware enough to eek by despite trying to look so cool and snazzy. It's a popcorn movie, a Friday night rental, a game night.

Why Rob Zombie felt the need to mask this pile of garbage is unfathomable, though perhaps he knew it was a blatant regurgitation of everything he's done before, which means everything he's aped previously.
Operator is sleek, stylish, and downright honest.

Bleed for This never registers as anything more than a boilerplate boxing drama, which is a shame because the material is all there, it's just hamstrung by a flimsy screenplay that refuses to let its characters exist on their own.
For all its strengths, The Last Jedi is a very manic film, fueled by excellent ideas that could have been parsed out in smarter ways.

This isn't a rollercoaster, it's more like an assault. Berg's so unflinching with his direction, refusing to let go from the melting destruction and glass-riddled body horror, that it's impossible to dig into the popcorn with wild eyes and baited breath.
This 128-minute slog from Warner Bros. is not only as boring and forgettable as its yawn-worthy title suggests, it's as messy and uneven as the studio's recent slate of blockbusters.
Journey from Motown to Off the Wall is a friendly, warm, and inviting documentary that dances and shouts without ever shaking its body down to the ground.
movie_title: Michael Jackson's Journey From Motown to Off the Wall (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Joshua Marston's latest is an existential drama with big questions that hit harder on the way out of the theater than in it.

This is pitch-perfect filmmaking, the kind that turns a hungry visionary into a popular last name. Rest assured, it's all earned. Manchester By the Sea is a hearty, rewarding drama audiences will remember for years.

Antibirth feels more like an anti-film, a piss-poor assembly of remarkable cult actors and brazen narratives that start off divorced without ever being married. What a disappointing, irrelevant misfire.

While The Intervention tastes vanilla, there's enough flavor here to keep wanting more from DuVall. Despite its flaws, the film still manages to win you over, even if it never actually surprises you, making it quite an assured debut.

Richard Tanne has pieced together a lovely story that rises above its novelty premise. Southside with You is a rewarding bite-sized drama, rich with characters that we already know, but also don't really know.
A spooky ghost story that singes the nerves as much as it coddles the mind.
A lot of it's funny - for instance, any scenes involving Powell's admittedly charming Finnegan or Hoechlin's testy McReynolds - but hanging out with these guys eventually becomes a chore.
Born to Be Blue serves as an honest and heartfelt ode to not only Chet Baker, but those who revel in the occasional highs and neverending lows that overwhelm the pursuit of art.
Sophie Goodhart's My Blind Brother has clear eyes on full hearts.

Few films are ever as enjoyable and endearing as Sing Street. From its five-star cast to its unforgettable soundtrack, Carney's latest musical masterpiece dances around with a jovial charm that's addicting and innocent enough to revisit again and again.

Part drama, part psychosexual thriller, part revenge fantasy, Michael Shannon's latest platform balls up the dark mystery of Polanski, the vivid passion of De Palma, and the razor tension of Hitchcock for a savvy and meticulous 90 mins.
Screenwriters Mark Bianculli and Jeff Richard are too obsessed with driving their freshman thesis home, to the point that they fracture their own storytelling by overstuffing the narrative.
Try to imagine the most disgusting, foul-mouthed, and disturbing Pixar film ever put to celluloid, and you'll probably land somewhere near Sausage Party. But not too close. It's unlike anything else.
Somebody stop Zack Snyder. Somebody save the world.
movie_title: Batman v Superman: Dawn of Justice (2016)

movie_review_blurb: X-Men: Apocalypse huffs and puffs a little, appearing less mutant and more human, but it's still damn fun.

The Nice Guys spends two hours treating Crowe and Gosling like a pair of piñatas, beating them mercilessly and unapologetically, and it's watching them crawl out from underneath and towards some form of redemption that makes the film a genuine smash.

Gone is any realism, washed away by a camera-friendly cast who wrestle with the piss-poor melodrama when they're not mugging the cameras capturing the prized footage, which must have been plopped down on the porch of whoever used to edit MTV's Fear.
In an age of branded films, it's such a relief to stumble upon a film like Hunt for the Wilderpeople. Filmmaking this fresh, this vibrant, and this affecting for all ages is rare these days.
Demon is a smarter, more elegant brand of horror, one that wrestles with complicated, festering cultural conflicts that, in turn, advance the matters at hand.
The Conjuring 2 is slick and stylish to the point of distraction; this isn't horror, this is exaggerated carnival fare.
Elle Fanning is downright stunning here, delivering a mature and nuanced performance as disturbing as it is thrilling.

The much ballyhooed return of Greengrass and Damon has surprisingly warranted a disappointing sequel, an unnecessary chapter that feels written at gunpoint, and the story's curiously transparent about this

Pee-wee's Big Holiday is a spirited blast from the past that doesn't lose focus on what made Reubens such an enigma years ago. It's not exactly the repeat masterpiece of yesteryear, but that was never going to happen.
As an exhilarating challenge to familiar filmmaking, it stands alongside Breathless, Vivre sa vie: Film en douze tableaux, Masculin, féminin, and Weekend, as Godard's finest work.
Trouble in Paradise is full of perfectly executed scenes.
Wings of Desire is the most optimistic of films, finding freedom and potential in the quotidian privileges most of us take for granted.
A truly 'modern' film.
Mercifully, Inception is short on "is-this-a-dream-or-is-this-reality" pseudo-philosophizing, allowing the near-Kubrickian visual stimuli to drive the exposition and action. And it works.
Zombieland succeeds because it doesn't aspire to be anything more than a smart, well-produced action flick with snappy dialogue and memorable characters.
If Bay has one consistent artistic inclination other than the lowest common denominator, it's his obsession with fascistic imagery.
The most cynical and calculating part of it all is that the movie never really finds a justification for its existence; except, that is, as a bald-faced setup for The Avengers.
Like the special effects, the characters are sketched out in tiresome cinematic shorthand, as if to reassure the viewer that this joyride really isn't worth thinking too hard about.
The X-Men is a hit.
Bottom line is Man of Steel is the best Superman to date. For anyone with nostalgic memories of the first Richard Donner Superman movies, watch it again.
Overall, the movie was a bunch of characters, some of them interesting, trying to make the best of a weak, convoluted plot.

If it's action you want, Batman v. Superman: Dawn of Justice will not disappoint. But take away the interminable fight scenes, and the screenplay crashes into plot holes big enough to drive the Batmobile through.
movie_title: Batman v Superman: Dawn of Justice (2016)

movie_review_blurb: This film set the bar very high for superhero movies, something Marvel does with seeming ease.
The standout is Momoa as Aquaman. Now THAT is a character I want to see more of, which is ironic since he has been the butt of media jokes for years.

Director Patty Jenkins displays a deft hand contrasting the gentle beauty of Wonder Woman's paradise island with the horror of the First World War. Her movie is mesmerizing, as she allows the audience to see the world through alien eyes.
Holland was born to play this part, with just the right mixture of seriousness and silliness without ever being corny or cliche.
Mark Mothersbaugh (Devo) does a great job with the musical score, which includes a near-perfect placement of Led Zeppelin's 'The Immigrant Song.'
[Chadwick] Boseman is perfect as the Panther, just the right mixture of royal privilege and humility, in a story that allows for a sense of wonder rarely found in "comic book movies."
The acting is impeccable and the special effects are incredible.
Who can count how many times that high concept has resulted in sheer overkill? But with this sequel, more-is-more works-every over-the-top moment of it.
Because yes, along with a very topical, deeply resonant theme and premise, Elysium has a hurtling momentum, with enough boom-crash-splatter explosiveness to wow even the most hardened action junkie.
Without being preachy about it, Fed Up flat-out tells us that it is indeed past time to be fed up -- to insist that action be taken, and take it ourselves. This film is a bracing wake-up call.
A storyline that couldn't be timelier unfolds with a vintage air of 1970s cynicism in this unusually thoughtful thriller.
In his third and best "chronicle," Vin Diesel's tough, gruff deep-space rogue does what he does best: fighting hordes of hungry aliens in a hostile extraterrestrial environment.

It's not that the filmmakers were just mailing it in...But you can't just force inspiration, or creativity, or a sense of humor. They're either there or they aren't. Too often in Free Birds, they aren't.
It is balanced, full-bodied, heartfelt. Portraying the Mandelas as all-too-human, it is all the more moving during those moments when they soar.

With a crackling script and masterful direction, Russell has made a fiction that is stranger -- and way more fun -- than the truth. He has the help of a dream cast of actors, all at the top of their games.
Taut, tense and riveting, Liam Neeson's latest action vehicle is not just another Liam Neeson action vehicle.
Marching to the same beat as its predecessor, this belated follow-up delivers even more visual excess and brain-deadening bloodshed. Those who will find this fulfilling already know who they are.
The filmmakers have done an admirable job of branching out from Meatballs 1, and making a new and different, and exceedingly entertaining, follow-up.
movie_title: Cloudy with a Chance of Meatballs 2 (2013)

movie_review_blurb: The third time is not the charm in this second sequel, which changes up the franchise formula-and not in a good way.
The music of Mozart seems too big for the "book" of this minor-key romantic roundelay, which nevertheless manages to be increasingly, albeit mildly, engaging.
Dance Me Outside nevertheless stays compelling, thanks to its cast of appealing unknowns. You haven't seen anyone quite like them before -- and that's meant as high praise.
Harsh, gritty-and increasingly grisly-this true-crime story dramatizes the life and bloody career of contract killer Richard Kuklinski: just another suburban dad who never brought his work home.
Just when you thought you'd seen the horror of the Holocaust from every perspective, this somber but ultimately uplifting true story of survival takes you to a whole new place-literally underground.

While sticking to a fairly standard mainstream comedy story arc, this sturdy Steve Carell vehicle still serves up enough dark, edgy humor-most of it involving Jim Carrey-to also appeal to hipper sensibilities.

This visually spectacular travelogue captures memorable images from every corner. The end result is not just a gorgeous picture show, but also a thought-provoking rumination on our complicated relationship with our home planet.
What may surprise all but the most dedicated Python fan is the self-deprecating candor and bittersweet whimsy with which Chapman's memoir lays out his most private joys, hang-ups, foibles and demons.
movie_title: A Liar's Autobiography - The Untrue Story of Monty Python's Graham Chapman (2012)

movie_review_blurb: From its shoestring budget to its familiar tropes, this could have been independent filmmaking at its most generic. But with its off-the-wall premise, snarky wit and heartfelt performances, it's quite the opposite: an inspired original.
This absorbing documentary takes an up-close and intimate look at the musicians' creative process, then zooms out to recall the political turmoil that this landmark album left in its wake.

The creator of TV's "Family Guy" directs his first live-action movie-in which he gets to say and do all the profane, politically incorrect and just plain gross things he can't say or do on television. And a lot of it is pretty funny.
A talented cast shines brightly, but can't carry the weight of this under-inspired sci-fi frolic.
This disturbing documentary takes a revealingly close look at rampant clerical pedophilia--but its sweeping overview of the Catholic Church's willful obliviousness is just as eye-opening.
movie_title: Mea Maxima Culpa: Silence In The House Of God (2012)

movie_review_blurb: This might make an appropriately absurd finale for a series that long ago went over the top. But Paul Kersey's not finished yet!
movie_title: Death Wish V: The Face of Death (1993)

movie_review_blurb: Three eco-activists walk it like they talk it, in a documentary that doesn't have to preach or overload us with statistics to get its message across. Meanwhile, its sobering images of despoiled natural resources vividly speak for themselves.
In every important way, Tammy is the better McCarthy vehicle [than Identity Thief]. It's warmer, wittier, far less slickly contrived, and much more recognizably human, in its emotions and behavior
So yes, Kick-Ass 2 does have its share of winkingly subversive humor. It also takes care to honor the emotional connections that the first Kick-Ass established for anyone who was paying attention

The good news is that The Giver is an assuredly directed, stylistically adventurous parable that does a surprisingly moving job of celebrating the many emotional colors of the human experience - as messy as they can often be.
The man who masterfully navigated Titanic returns to the deepest blue sea - this time in a real-life adventure, starring himself as the protagonist.
A biopic that is not always as compelling nor hard-hitting as it could have been... [T]he experience is something less than memorable.
For all its shortfalls, Rebel does succeed on maybe its most important level. No, it doesn't reveal all the what of Salinger's life, but it does give us the why.
There were ways that The Emoji Movie could have been [...] smart and satisfying, but the filmmakers just didn't find them. Maybe they weren't even looking.
Has all been done before. Again and again.
[Collateral Beauty's] tangle of bright and trite ideas pretty much guarantees that it will not be remembered as a Yuletide classic.
A whole new franchise is off to a positively ripping start.
movie_title: Fantastic Beasts and Where to Find Them (2016)

movie_review_blurb: In the year of Black Lives Matter, this Sundance-heralded slave-rebellion drama arrives as a raging clarion call.
In the midst of another big blockbuster summer, this raffish comedy-adventure provides a breath of fresh air.
James Franco once again shines in an ambitious undertaking that bites off a bit more than it can chew.
Perennially popular children's-book characters come alive with overwhelming effects-to underwhelming effect.
The three last people in the world come together to eke out survival in this thoughtful-and thought-provoking-take on life after Armageddon.
This is what happens when filmmakers throw everything against a wall and see what sticks. A lot of it doesn't stick.
More often than not, it's decidedly bracing-for better or worse.
Yet another unnecessary remake, this suitably scary haunted-house tale is likely to be loved only by those who never saw the original.
Will satisfy its built-in audience while leaving the uninitiated sufficiently amused-even if they don't get every in-joke.

But each unhappy couple is unhappy in its own way - and this couple's way is nothing if not unique. The same could be said of this daringly original film, from first-time feature director Charlie McDowell.
It is what it is: an unusually resonant, well-textured thriller that you can still eat plenty of popcorn to.
A good cast comes and goes and can't quite carry this overly stylized, globetrotting dramedy, about one man who literally searches high and low in his pursuit of true happiness.
movie_title: Hector And The Search For Happiness (2014)

movie_review_blurb: "Low Down" is not the most harrowing portrait of lives slowly lost to addiction. It is, however, among the most saddening.
By the end credits, before the tears even dry, all but the true Sparks faithful will understand that they've just been played. Again.
Kevin Costner continues a quietly incremental comeback with this child-custody drama. It could have been his Kramer vs. Kramer-but doesn't even come close.
While ultimately serving up the expected, The DUFF is fresh and funny throughout, largely thanks to two vibrantly written lead characters.
The imagery of this film will linger in this reviewer's mind long after the monkey names are forgotten.
Don't be surprised if The D Train goes on to become a cult fave.
The filmmakers had a powerful story here. They just didn't know how to tell it.
Sure, some of the puns and in-jokes sound a little dated, but any movie that strings together lines from Shakespeare merely as a throwaway comic riff is, in my book, a film for the ages.
There's nothing terribly complex or original about the movie, but it is distinguished by its clever and innovative use of B-movie staples in a hi-tech setting.
It's a political fairy tale about duplicity and hypocrisy in which everything, including ethics and human flesh, is for sale, and self-esteem and worth is measured only in terms of money.

[A] quickie follow-up that vainly tries to imitate the look of the original on an obviously limited budget, and for the most part, eschews the philosophical, social, and racial subtext of the first film in favor of straightforward shoot-em-up.
movie_title: Beneath The Planet Of The Apes (1970)

movie_review_blurb: Aside from Severn Darden, who relishes his lip-smacking heavy character, the cast seems disinterested; even series stalwart Roddy McDowall looks bored.
movie_title: Battle For The Planet Of The Apes (1973)

movie_review_blurb: [It] has enough hauntingly beautiful images and profound ideas to linger in one's mind.
A wonderful present that's perfect for anytime of the year.
A brilliantly directed and performed psychodrama.
movie_title: Die Bitteren Tränen der Petra von Kant (The Bitter Tears of Petra Von Kant) (1972)

movie_review_blurb: A grim and dirty slice of bleak frontier life rendered with extraordinary beauty.
An uproarious summary of Luis Bunuel's surrealistic concerns in a collection of anecdotes starring Jean-Claude Brialy, Michel Piccoli, and Monica Vitti.
movie_title: Le Fantôme de la Liberté (The Phantom of Liberty) (The Specter of Freedom) (1974)

movie_review_blurb: Most of Cassavetes's cinema verite films as a director are invariably accused (and with some justification) of being rambling, self-indulgent, and unfocused, but it is precisely those elements that make his best work so affecting and memorable.
The most accessible, and endearing example of his very exceptional art.
A stylish example of the doomed-lovers-on-the-run subgenre inspired by real-life outlaws Bonnie Parker and Clyde Barrow, and one of the best B movies ever made.
The explosive outbursts of violence in Yojimbo are superbly choreographed, with Kurosawa's customary use of a telephoto lens creating a hallucinatory feeling.
A delightful puzzle, and [Catherine] Deneuve's finest hour-and-a-half.

The film's main problem is that director Ralph Nelson virtually ignores the philosophical elements of the story and emphasizes its most maudlin aspects, while throwing in a little sci-fi, romance, and spurious social commentary.
Zachary Scott and Bernie Hamilton star as deadly adversaries on an island hell in Luis Bunuel's The Young One, a rarely shown English-language gem about racism and pedophilia.
Strong acting and a string of classic rock and soul tunes make up for a superficial script.
The film is as grim and pitiless as the relentless drill that pounds away at the mountain top.
movie_title: Ace in the Hole (The Big Carnival) (1951)

movie_review_blurb: Excellent animation, marvelous color, and lovely music make Cinderella a delight all the way around.
[It made] more money than any other film from the 1950s except The Ten Commandments and Ben-Hur.
Wholesome Hilary Duff movie has simple, positive messages.
Predictable and utterly unoriginal.
A song-filled family adventure.
Fascinating. But sensitive animal-lovers beware.
Jaunty animation meets jazzy songs in Disney classic.
An amusing but dumbed-down kids' cartoon.
movie_title: The Brave Little Toaster Goes to Mars (1998)

movie_review_blurb: A dumb, offensive movie--a good one to skip.
Amusing but long romp for both adults and kids.
Not nearly as good as the TV show.
Moving and wonderful, but parent preview a good idea.
A tuneful, joyous musical for the family.
Much juvenile humor and tongue-in-cheek.
A mystery with spunk, courage and heart.
movie_title: An American Tail: The Mystery of the Night Monster (2000)

movie_review_blurb: Wholesome and endearing dog movie.
Obviously designed for cynical modern teens.
The race becomes a metaphor for life, in which finishing builds camaraderie and victory is not the ultimate goal.
Even those unfamiliar with the good ship Bebop will enjoy the high-intensity action and witty dialogue.
movie_title: Cowboy Bebop: The Movie (Kaubôi Bibappu: Tengoku no Tobira) (2003)

movie_review_blurb: The undisputed surf-film champion.
Fry up a peanut butter and 'nana sandwich, hop in your Cadillac and take one last ride with the King.
Power, control and fame are not the driving forces in [Bingenheimer's] life. He only wants to share the music he loves with as many people as possible.
The young cast shines, especially Hirsch.
An unflinching and often hilarious look at the humanity of these heavy-metal gods.
A good old-fashioned space opera.
Not so much a coherent story as a string of clichés.
The radiation-altered members of the Fantastic Four don't show their humanity. Rather, the superpowered quartet is little more than a bland collection of four-color caricatures.
McKean's inexperience as a director trips the film. There is so much going on that the viewer can't take in all the imagery, and McKean's devotion to his skewed vision slows the story to a crawl.
As the credits roll, New York Doll transforms from a puff piece about an aging rock star into a moving rumination on a man's final grasp for redemption.

The Devil and Daniel Johnston is an unflinching yet loving look at the outsider musician's life. It's also the most revealing look at genius and mental illness since Terry Zwigoff's 1994 documentary Crumb.
... an enjoyable if incomplete nostalgia trip.
Miss Impossible is as light as cotton candy, but it takes culture seriously.

There is an impressive attention to both the flood-saturated muck and the industrial integrity of the small farm, lending The Levelling a fine sense of space. The film is ultimately a one-track proposition, but keep an eye on Leach.

I think this is a film about a young girl, unfathomably naïve, who did things that girls who look like Olivia Cooke aren't supposed to do, and is severely punished for it. Katie Says Goodbye is a hateful film.
There are significant problems with the film, mostly having to do with a certain tonal confusion.
Karl Marx City is that rarest of objects: an exploration of family history that avoids solipsism and manages to connect the personal to much broader things.
Afternoon is a rare and lovely cinematic expression of gratitude.
Heartstone is the type of debut film that is brimming with good intentions but ultimately doesn't make a strong enough case for its existence.

Bearing an unnervingly derivative resemblance to Shane Carruth's Primer, which did much more with considerably less, the debut feature by TV writer Tony Elliott comes off like a low-budget, low-stakes riff on Edge of Tomorrow.
Kati Kati is a film that draws on tradition (Nollywood, Senegalese counter-cinema, faith-based films) without falling into the stylistic or genre traps of any of those approaches.
Hamaguchi proposes a life-world in which the experiences that are really supposed to rearrange our daily identities actually do.

Hermon Hailay's third feature is a somewhat puzzling melodrama...There is a fundamental inscrutability bedevilling Price of Love that may well pertain to certain constraints on filmmaking in Ethiopia.
The film rallies in its second and third sections, and they retroactively enrich the first.
movie_title: Hong Kong Trilogy: Preschooled Preoccupied Preposterous (Hoeng gong saam bou kuk) (2015)

movie_review_blurb: This movie is so damned muddled there's no telling what its makers even wanted to accomplish, but the end result is a Gordian knot of "complications" for their own sake.
Honor Thy Father, Matti's latest, is as accomplished as its predecessor, and shares much more of a formal kinship with popular Korean cinema than with most recent Filipino exports.
