The comic-surreal atmosphere and rule-governed perversity are satisfying throughout, and Mikkelsen's clueless-asshole deadpan is a hoot.
With his latest, Pereda has achieved a genuine comedy of stasis.
Buy the soundtrack. Avoid this film.

More than once, the relationship between Stella and her sister Katja veers uncomfortably into Catherine Breillat territory, and these are the moments that make My Skinny Sister much more worthwhile than the usual PSA, however noble the cause.
Regardless of where one stands on nuclear power, the OL3 has been such a fiasco...that it stands as a testament to shortsighted hubris, the kind that might just kill us all.
movie_title: The Return Of The Atom (Atomin Paluu) (2015)

movie_review_blurb: Exhibiting a simplicity and intellectual acuity that is far too rare in the field of documentary, Loznitsa has created a film whose cumulative impact will stay with you long after you watch it.
While Francofonia has very little to offer on the subject that's new, Sokurov is spry and chatty and keeps things continually engaging.
Biller is a preternaturally gifted filmmaker whose unique formal approach is thoroughly in service to an intellectual worldview. From the first shot, The Love Witch announces its artifice.
The beginning and end are exceedingly clunky, while the middle feels uniquely organic and atmospheric.

Implicitly defeat cinematic miserablism, Salomé Lamas has shown herself to be one of the few artists sensitive to the lessons of Pedro Costa. She is helping to create a post-liberal progressive cinema.
This is an unusual case, an exceedingly brief (only 76-minute) film that still manages to feel overstuffed and meandering.
Instead of uncovering artifacts from long ago, Homo Sapiens shows us our own relics in the making.

Downbeat, dark, and often genuinely unpleasant, Zucchini is every bit as quintessentially French as Zootopia is American. This is brutal existentialism as observed through the eyes of society's castoffs.
movie_title: My Life as a Zucchini (Ma vie de courgette) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: A Ciambra is a very fine piece of middlebrow cinema, and I fully expect Carpignano to be working in Hollywood before all is said and done.

While it could be said that the last thing the world needs is another zombie movie, Québécois director Robin Aubert has managed to offer a solid and at times even original survey of this well-trod terrain.
By the end, there is a glimmer of hope that situations like Hernan's will be rectified. But there's no letting up on the failed drug war.
This is a film that keeps you on your toes, even as it appears to demand very little of its viewer.
I choose to see it as an allegory for its own subject, a nation disoriented by a strongman intent on punctuating a constant, indistinct dread with sharp jabs of ultraviolence.
movie_title: Dark is the Night (Madilim ang Gabi) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: A film so phony that its makers needed to coin a nonsense word to give it an appropriate title, the irksome Insyriated is the sort of feeble attempt at profundity that crops up in the face of every armed conflict.

We may never get a comprehensive history of what really went down at Lehman Brothers, Bear Stearns, or Countrywide. On the other hand, thanks to Steve James and the Kartemquin group, we know all about Abacus Federal Savings Bank.
This is an imperfect film-some of its secrets are perhaps more apparent than Pallaoro wants them to be-but it is quite good.
All the expected parts are there, but in the end they don't really add up.
movie_title: Marlina the Murderer in Four Acts (2017)

movie_review_blurb: What Occidental offers is a collection of perplexing human relationships reducible to types...it's hard not to feel the auteur working the angles throughout the film.
As political cinema goes, Oblivion Verses is rather dull-edged; in some respects its intent is patently obvious, in others rather oblique.
The combination of brutalism, magic, and kitsch just results in what you'd expect: a pool of blood, milk, and melted popsicle in a gooey mess on the concrete floor.
movie_title: On Body and Soul (A Teströl és Lélekröl) (2018)

movie_review_blurb: I watched Of Sheep and Men with no foreknowledge, and I honestly thought it was a fictional feature. That's because this documentary is so tightly structured in terms of its focus on two protagonists and their gradually shifting milieu.
Sighted Eyes is meticulously researched, well assembled, and has most of the appropriate expert commentary.
You Disappear is the sort of film that recites large passages of the book in voiceover, just in case anyone in the cheap seats might be missing the philosophical subtext to the onscreen plot.
The trajectory is never really convincing. (Ron Burgundy might opine that things escalate a bit too quickly.)

When Bonnetta teams up with Sniadecki to explore the border, he does so by displaying its accumulated meaning, the way that the hope, desperation, racism, and violence of the Mexico/US border is reaffirmed, its historical and spiritual presence thickened.
Barbara Albert's Mademoiselle Paradis is a subtle and intelligent film about the historical crisis of female subjectivity and the various men who attempt to control that emerging identity.

More troubling is Du's narrow focus, which turns an entirely comprehensible social shift within China's younger population into a kind of personal narrative, a set of awakenings in response to one man's broadening perspective.
Fitzmaurice is telling a tale that is not particularly new or interesting, but he seems to be imploring us to enjoy the sensations of the physical self while we can.

While in no way softening the all-encompassing propaganda state of three generations of Great Leader Kims, Songs from the North also displays a rare audacity by showing certain aspects of North Korean life as perfectly normal.

Needless to say, The Keanu hasn't got a patch on either Fincher or Assayas stylistically, and while his casting of himself as the eeeevil villain may have been a bold move, his performance could be a career-worst.
The Strange Little Cat is a film that prioritizes confinement, small movements within that confinement, and the unexpected alleviation of that confinement through imagination and memory.

A Spell finds their styles melding in the most fascinating ways. There has been a more reserved attitude in many of Rivers' films, a desire to hang back with patient curiosity, which is distinct from Russell's more agitated approach.
movie_title: A Spell To Ward Off The Darkness (2014)

movie_review_blurb: The fact that anyone is taking The Hunt seriously as a look at community panic around pedophilia, or the mass psychology of scapegoating, or even as a solid slice of middlebrow realism, is truly confounding.
TDKR is, like the Batman films that have preceded it, an ideological muddle, but none has been so completely devoid of intellectual clarity.

What is interesting about Rey's treatment of reel randomization in Autrement, la Molussie, I think, is that it enfolds the passages of Anders' novel within a filmic time that is "flattened" or relegated to a universally applicable principle.
Davies' films, in their own way, are indicative of the social fissures of our moment.

Sadly, Hazanavicius is so unskilled, so steeped in the empty signposting of parody and stereotype, that he's actually signaling to us throughout The Artist that we're watching a quaint old art form Lindy Hopping its way to the bone yard.

It is not a set of moves within and against the system writ large; it zeroes in on individuals, frames them, looks into their eyes, forges space and community with them, in neighborhoods, through moments.
Closed Curtain enfolds its politics within what I believe will go down as one of cinema's finest, most complex acts of self-portraiture.
Angelica is every bit as concerned with the problems of cinema as Oliveira's more theatrically inclined works, but explores them through more specifically visual means.
Littlerock isn't a film weighed down by symbolism, and to misconstrue it as such would divert us from its small, idiosyncratic pleasures.

This overall orchestration of The Robber as a kind of cinematic device for marking contrastive states of existence is, crucially, mirrored in Rettenberger's own formalistic attitude towards his own existence.
Alexandra is a film made by someone who wants to talk, which is an admirable gesture. It's just not the correct one.

A Separation is one of the year's most accomplished films, and like so many films we might characterize as "accomplished," it hasn't garnered actual detractors. It merely fosters a coterie of skeptics.
At least in part, Wiseman's latest success is the result of upping the spectacle and downplaying those detailed, Zolaesque dimensions for which his great novel is usually vaunted.
movie_title: La Danse -- Le Ballet de l'Opera de Paris (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Part of what makes Reeves' film so thrilling, and so radical from the standpoint of existential/phenomenological politics, is that she doubles down.
As compared to the intensive wandering of the first two films, Ruins is characterized by a kind of stillness, emphasized by an almost musical structure in terms of its visuals.
Russell has initiated a project that taps into the tremulous, potentially self-consuming energy that characterizes a truly open art. With the help of his collaborators, he is going his own way.
movie_title: Let Each One Go Where He May (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Ma is a complex artwork that engages with movement and space to suggest a cinematic form of body-talk, a language of resistant gesture and queer-feminist transformation.
The director finds himself artistically stranded between the allegorical impulse and the will to historicize.
This is the sort of film that you watch with a double consciousness, constantly distracted by the battle between visionary impulse and rank cliché.
The Great Beauty is an alleged condemnation of the decadence of Rome and its high society, but inasmuch as it approaches coherence at all.
The film, frustratingly and a bit offensively, falls very much in line with the "Asperger's chic" that is plaguing art houses and festivals worldwide.
movie_title: Sarah préfère la course (Sarah Would Rather Run) (2013)

movie_review_blurb: Whether or not you've studied piano, or any musical instrument, it is fascinating to observe Bernstein's gentle but rigourous technique in correcting errors, training the musicians' bodies, and helping them to locate their own place within the piece.

This is a complete mess, but I cannot honestly say whether Zanussi constructed Foreign Body to be exactly the film he wanted it to be and thus he's just off his rocker, or if he has simply lost control of the medium.
Antoine Fuqua can't direct, and this is abundantly clear in the opening seconds of The Equalizer.
[Gyeongju] is not a winning combination, and it's difficult to understand how it nabbed a competition slot in Locarno.

Hill of Freedom doesn't rely on linguistic miscues for easy humour. Even in English, it's one of Hong's best films to date, and demonstrates that his jaundiced vision of Korean culture can transcend the specificities of language.

Sadly, the political and bureaucratic hubbub around Arraf's film is far more interesting than the film itself, which takes on a seldom-explored historical topic and extrudes it into bite-size shells of utter cliché.
For a film that strives to be hard as nails, A Hard Day is more like cotton candy, crackling on the tongue and evaporating instantly.

It is impressively clear-eyed about aging, illness and death, from the limits of colleagues' sympathy when major projects are on the line to the mutual effort involved in keeping a sex life going in the face of physical deterioration.
Information and identity are threads that weave in and out, but again, not in an ostentatious way. Alive's mud-caked proletarian realism allows its deeper structures to remain largely submerged.

Child's Pose is the sort of film that foregrounds a major event rather than a plot per se, in the hope that the exploration of said event will allow character nuance and social significance to waft up from cracks in the façade.
Despite Naomi Kawase's claims prior to the film's world premiere at Cannes, Still the Water is not her masterpiece, and it's uncertain she will ever actually make one.
This fairly mediocre period piece is what we might call a double-whammy, given that it practically begs for critics to grade it on a curve.

Part of what makes Theeb such a breath of fresh air is that it narrows its focus, examining a group of individuals (and one in particular) rather than getting stuck in well-meaning liberal "typicality."
It's difficult to evaluate a film as aggressively unusual as The Owners. Despite its grating quirks and featherweight jabs at social commentary, it cannot be summarily dismissed. This
First things first: this is a pretty good film.
A Girl at My Door is well-acted and crisply shot, a highly assured debut from Jung who should have a bright future as she grows beyond Lee's tutelage and develops her own voice.
Nymphomaniac is Von Trier's most timid film in years. But paradoxically, it's also his most unguarded, the most palpably human.
Camille Claudel 1915 is the first Dumont film I would truly consider boring. Everything it works so hard to convince us of, we have heard so many times before.
Taken on its own merits, Sacro GRA suffers from a structural slackness, as though Rosi's expansive manoeuvre was a bridge too far for the filmmaker.
How many filmmakers wallow in the self-indulgent excesses of autobiography? So few are capable of accomplishing what Taïa does here, which is to regard his own story with relative objectivity.
The self-reflexivity, the bone-dry salaryman foibles, the sudden appearance of Office-style interviews among the assorted dominatrices-are attenuated by a hopelessly tedious A-plot.
Graziosi probably could have made a much more successful documentary or an essay film, and one wonders why he didn't.
It might be trash, but for those willing to forgive the bland narrative, Wrath Of The Titans is a relatively fun and spectacular adventure.

Though The Sorcerer and the White Snake is excessive and at times jumbled, younger viewers will surely respond to the colourful characters and settings, and the bold vision on display is charming... for the most part.
movie_title: Bai she chuan shuo (The Sorcerer and the White Snake) (2013)

movie_review_blurb: Though far-fetched, this celebration of storytelling is an exhilarating and visually lavish thrill ride.
Revisiting Titanic on the big screen, this time in impressive 3D, is a welcome reminder of solid blockbuster movie magic.
This belated sequel squanders comic potential with unimaginative gags, but Rowan Atkinson's engaging screen presence ensures it's still an entertaining ride.
It doesn't hit the heights of its lauded animated counterparts, but the visuals are vibrant, the laughs are steady, and the voice cast is ace.
Alex Cross wasn't conceived as spoof, but such poorly written and executed dross is laughable.
A visually dazzling, wickedly humoured and richly characterised epic that has Sam Raimi's magic touch all over it.
an unwieldy and unfunny farce that's robbed of comic potential through its reliance on shrill mayhem over wit.
It might not deliver the timely and razor sharp political satire it could have, but it remains a solid mainstream comedy with an edge.
Ultimately, the intimate scope of the story and impressive commitment to the truth of its characters makes for a satisfying finish.
This is a Rapunzel story that really knows how to let its hair down.
Frozen combines cute characters, soaring songs and clever comedy to create a Disney animated winner that tries too hard on some accounts, but that won't stop it from charming audiences.
The Princess and the Frog is a striking film, old-fashioned and original at the same time.
Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows, Part 2 is a fine finish to a franchise that most, including myself, wish would never end.
movie_title: Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows - Part 2 (2011)

movie_review_blurb: The film is this year's best horror due to Smit-McPhee and Moretz displaying a vulnerability and a skill in characterization that belies their tender ages.
Zany, brainy and drop-dead funny, Zombieland is a marvel that might be this year's best horror film as well as its best comedy, rolled into one ooey, gooey mess.
Gunn has done a marvelous job of character development with a large cast of unknown comic-book roles.

For all its mythic, metaphorical weight, The Return of the King and its two predecessors finally speak to the dignity and humanity of the smallest among us. And the best movie masterpieces have always been made of such common stuff.
movie_title: The Lord of the Rings: The Return of the King (2003)

movie_review_blurb: District 9 made me think, and it made me jump. This cool science-fiction thriller pumps up the tension to wow-factor levels.
For all who have hotly fan-ticipated this all-star collection of Marvel's superheroes, you have reason to be excited. You can officially geek out now.
Horror films are supposed to be scary, but not very smart. The Cabin in the Woods is both. It's about as clever as you can imagine a film of this type being that is also this wicked and this brutal.
The comedy works. But there's not much to the characters that proves memorable. It's not a bad movie, but...

If you include two stand-alone Wolverine films, this is the seventh X-Men-related movie, and any series' movie No. 7 isn't supposed to be as good as this genre film that is full of both grandeur and fun.
This is one smart script, brought to life by director Paul Feig and working on many levels. Where it sometimes works best is in the gutter.
A cool summer movie full of action, suspense, moral ambiguities, cryptic clues and villains who just won't die.

Those like myself who admire auteur-driven filmmaking can celebrate with the release of "The Grand Budapest Hotel," the best movie of 2014 at this early stage, and perhaps likely to remain so for some time to come.
It's rare that a film can succeed on so many levels, but Birdman soars.
The storyline is wonderfully subversive, and the jokes come so fast and furious that it's a challenge to keep up with the humor of The Lego Movie.
The look of the film is so impressive, in fact, that it makes one think that the filmmakers decided to let everything else more or less take care of itself.
movie_title: Dawn Of The Planet Of The Apes (2014)

movie_review_blurb: Gone Girl is a greatly entertaining film that seems a likely candidate for multiple Oscar nominations, and it is Flynn's script that seems like a sure thing.
Jake Gyllenhaal plays Louis, and he delivers a devil of a performance in one of the best movies of 2014.

The race for the Academy Award for best supporting actor is probably over, with J.K. Simmons nearly guaranteed to take home this year's crown with a performance that is both electric and unforgettable.

The Winter Soldier is all-American entertainment, with a hero enlightened to the fact that while he may not be able to trust his American government's leaders, he ultimately represents not them but the American ideals of truth and justice.
The Imitation Game is a great story that's well-told, about a man who was different from many of us -- which is to say that he was exceptional at a time when the world needed such a man most.
We do learn a little about ourselves by the conclusion, but when it came to holding my attention for the duration of a feature-length film, I found the experience far too alien.
These moments are almost cliches, but only because so many of us have lived these scenes in the course of our own lives, and that's what makes them so powerful.
A pretty good war movie that is audacious, occasionally fun and too in love with its own voice.
It has such a nihilistic nature and lack of resolution that rather than high stakes, there's nothing at stake.

Transgender jokes, fat jokes (always James, happy to look stupid), homeliness jokes, mama's boy jokes -- the picture was made by people who like to put down people, and it was made for people who like to tease others or watch others be insulted.
Wild is a movie that I'll find hard to forget because of its powerful imagery and how it works on the senses.
What would Jay Silverheels say? Tonto laugh at bad movie, cannot fix with editing, much money wasted.
What makes this another winner is that there are more than enough subversive chuckles to balance out the sugar. It is almost impossible to not smile through the duration of the movie.
There is a difference between dumb fun and dumb. The new White House-under-attack movie celebrates all that is red, white and stupid.
It takes a special kind of talent to make the prime player from the X-Men movies a bore.
The film is both personal and universal. Jordan can be so touching, and his intimidating ferocity is palpable. This is an important picture with a breakout performance.
Raunchy for the sake of being raunchy. Poignancy, a key element in making any sex comedy something more important, is lacking.
The lasting legacy of an exceptional thriller is to not only be surprised on the first viewing, but also to realize the picture offers qualities to be enjoyed on repeat screenings.

By the end of the film, we really don't much about the men on board, or the hijackers, or even Phillips himself. He's simply an ordinary guy in an extraordinary situation, but perhaps more ordinary than most.
Cloudy With a Chance of Meatballs 2 is a fun romp rooted in the idea that "goofy is good," especially when it's a tasty treat done with a knowing wink and a smile.
movie_title: Cloudy with a Chance of Meatballs 2 (2013)

movie_review_blurb: A surprising lack of passion in this movie, as someone apparently mistook Dark World to mean Brooding, Lethargic World.
Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows, Part 1 isn't close to being a bad movie, but it is arguably the weakest among the seven films in the series.
movie_title: Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows - Part 1 (2010)

movie_review_blurb: All is Lost is superior craftsmanship on the part of the filmmaker and his star, making a late-in-life "coming of age" story that transitions into a man's twilight and burns bright.
The movie is a solid example of "the book on film" in spirit, and Lawrence is brilliant in a performance far beyond blockbuster-level acting.

Philomena is a marvelous little movie, a heartwarming drama with plenty of comedic pathos that features Judi Dench, an incredibly bright, quickwitted woman, playing a simple Irish woman who doesn't get the jokes of her traveling companion.
Excess for the sake of excess on the part of Scorsese, and it's a bore.
It may be too much slow-burning style for those looking for true-crime substance only, but a cool patience is what drives Blue Caprice.

12 Years a Slave remains an important film, if nothing else for the fact that these are not anonymous characters created for Hollywood storytelling, but one man's remarkable story that puts a face on history.
Go beyond the particular sins, and you find something universal: the pain that has touched many families, and which has resonated with audiences around the world who have seen Tracy Letts' play.
In his most accessible and romantic film yet, Jonze's unique premise is relatable, prescient and may be coming soon to a relationship near you.
More blood. More guts. More men with six-packs than a Quik-Trip on a Friday night.
I have a hard time believing the movie had a script that included dialogue. The movie has no character development. It's an embarrassment.
How refreshing it is to find a summer sequel that's not simply louder or wackier than its predecessor, but rather feels like an extension of its first film and all of its best qualities.

It features all the best qualities of memorable summer-movie thrillers - it's clever, cool and quirky to the point of almost being a bit silly - and when you leave, you may consider re-living the experience all over again.
movie_title: Live Die Repeat: Edge of Tomorrow (2014)

movie_review_blurb: A movie musical with mediocre musical moments and meandering melodrama. It's not headed for No. 1 with a bullet.
This vibrant romantic drama is directed by a former Tulsan whose film seems to indicate that his hometown is still his first love.
The road to that realization makes for a super-fun path, especially with the Baymax character, who constantly issues health updates and who works to adapt to teen expressions and figures of speech.
The movie is also missing the subversive chuckles this series is known for, and sight gags are all that's left. There are only so many ways to dress up a Minion to build a movie around.
Locke is different, but it's an art-film experiment that works.
Director Joe Johnston re-confirms his mastery of special effects, but he doesn't let them get in the way of his telling a story.
Despite a story that sometimes strains under cliches, several supporting characters shine and the action-humor combinations will leave you smiling always and laughing often.
On all accounts, the simplest deduction here is that McKellen is magnificent as Mr. Holmes.
Trainwreck can be so funny, but there is disappointment here where there should have been so much potential.

Perhaps the one thing you don't see coming in Southpaw is the manner in which Gyllenhaal bulked up to play the role. Forget the six-pack, he went for the 12-pack. His physique is impressive. His movie is down for the count.
Testament of Youth is a woman's vision of war, which is one we've rarely seen.
Bleeping awful. Really bleeping awful.
The story may seem lightweight to anyone in search of blockbusters during the summer, but it's a welcome bit of personal storytelling in which the only thing at stake for this family is everything.
You should consider the overall brilliance of Nolan's series of "Dark Knight" films and wonder whether the next filmmaker willing to take on the caped crusader's story is batty.
A Poem is a Naked Person is a trippy time-capsule celebration of Russell and his music and of Oklahoma and its people.
movie_title: A Poem Is A Naked Person (2015)

movie_review_blurb: Phoenix works harder than he needs to in trying to inject some life into Allen's writing. Even when things heat up, as Abe attempts to plot the perfect murder, it's less than memorable.
There is true talent among the Fantastic Four crew of actors, but the real villain here is dullness.

There's a level of middling comfort in watching Streep in even the most mediocre film because she brings her best. But we should expect more from Ricki and the Flash, and she deserves better than this out-of-tune snore.
The Man From U.N.C.L.E. isn't about much, but it made me smile for a while. It's harmless fun.
Good Kill is essential viewing for those with an interest in how the war on terror continues to be waged, and in considering the moral conundrums of the situation.
It is a gorgeous, thought-provoking story and a triumph in every way for Garland, who casts three rising stars to make a small film full of big ideas.
There's a story to tell here. But in the hands of stars Jonah Hill and James Franco, it's not a great story.
You know that your Victorian England period piece is not working when the most interesting thing on screen is the clothes-horse fashion sense of your leading lady.
It's a fun concept but also a bit ridiculous in its staging.
But for those who want to see The Interview because their curiosity has been piqued, many will exit realizing that all the hubbub was much ado about nothing.
The End of the Tour makes it look effortless to tell a difficult story about two souls making a connection, which is a difficult enough achievement in this world.
Darn No Escape for being such a guilty pleasure.
This is one of Moore's defining performances, and it is a brave one.
I enjoyed the film to the degree that comfort food extends to frozen pizza: It's warm; it's cheesy; it's not as fresh as I had hoped for.
What makes Mistress America so annoying is having to watch everyone talk at each other. Not to each other. At each other.
The Amazing Spider-Man is frequently amazing. It's an even better experience than the first Spider-Man, and it's so far superior to Spider-Man 3 as to almost erase that lousy film from our memory.
The Amazing Spider-Man 2 is as lost and confused as its lead character, and without the first film's characters played by Denis Leary and Martin Sheen, there's no conscience to the picture.

The good news is that McCarthy and Bullock are often hilarious together, so you don't have to worry about the story. The filmmakers didn't.
The movie is smart and it is very funny.
Watching Nolan's latest attempt to create something artistic, intelligent and entertaining on such a massive scale, I couldn't help but think that with "Interstellar," he's outsmarted himself.
For all of the backstory and the marginal characters, A Walk Among the Tombstones feels too much like a week spent watching CBS crime procedurals that take themselves way too seriously.

Although it's advertised on the movie poster as being the work of " 'Notting Hill' Director Roger Michell," let there be no confusion between that marvelous, sometimes bittersweet romp and this bitter pill to swallow.
It handles life's big issues with honesty through its gritty lead character, Hazel. The other characters are brave and easy to empathize with.

The Hobbit: The Battle of the Five Armies feels more like a film made for those with a deep, vested interest in arguing about what was left out from the book, or what was added in and shouldn't have been.
movie_title: The Hobbit: The Battle of the Five Armies (2014)

movie_review_blurb: There's a lot of tough talk from tough men in this testosterone-fueled thriller, as the thin blue line disintegrates amid gritty give-and-take in William Monahan's excellent script.
I have seen more heat and more skin in late-night offerings on Cinemax. I've seen more realistic romance in young-adult movies, and I've seen better acting by furniture.
What's old is new again in this dreamy romance. What's antiquated seems innovative.
This is prestige-moviemaking at a high level.
It is neither an anti-war film nor a pro-war film. It is, simply, a great war film about courageous men working in chaotic situations, and the collateral damage that comes with the job.
All Good Things is a crackerjack crime thriller.
The film is focused on a marriage to the degree that this is a melodrama with too many paint-by-numbers cliches of the biography film formula.
When a film is this exciting in its action set pieces and this meaningful in its quiet moments, the filmmakers are getting it right.
The action is fast and furious and totally bonkers. And yet the style is totally original: Old West showdowns meets funk mayhem meets feminist drama. Seriously.
It Follows is a classy, scary horror show: Pass it on.
What elevates American Sniper is that we feel what Chris and his fellow soldiers feel in more ways than simple revenge. We feel their pain, their confusion and their weariness.

The new movie starring Melissa McCarthy, the reigning queen of profane, physical film comedy, is also smart, heartfelt and full of female empowerment. It lampoons the James Bond genre and asks: Why should the guys have all the fun?
Jurassic World is taut and terrifying, and for the uninitiated to these films, it just might rock your world.
The Pixar craftsmanship is as brilliant as always, and the emotions that it will bring out in adults, if not the children, are as powerful and as surprising as ever from an animated film.
Avengers: Age of Ultron is a pure popcorn-powered blast to begin the blockbuster season but nothing deeper this time.
As a family film mixed with adventure-film intensity, it's something to woof home about.

I realize there are those who don't care so much about the story or creating a distinct plot. But I thought the filmmakers might care, including star-and-producer Channing Tatum, about more than dropping trou. About more than the party.
Me and Earl and the Dying Girl is smart and funny and meaningful, the kind of movie that you may not be familiar with yet, but which you might watch many times in the years to come.
movie_title: Me and Earl and the Dying Girl (2015)

movie_review_blurb: More than anything, Ahnuld is a reminder of better days.
There's too much of an "Are we all at fault for Amy's death?" argument being posed that doesn't hold up.
I didn't even know I'd missed the Entourage posse until they got back together. I'm still trying to wipe that smile off my face.

There's less blood and more brains (put to use in the making of the film, rather than being munched on...), and it feels more streamlined than some of this summer's more bloated entries.
A knockoff of a knockoff, with fresh young stars to take the movie money out of the pockets of fresh young moviegoers.
The Disney-created automatons have none of the charisma that Miley Cyrus showed in her 3-D concert film, and the lame 3-D effects make this flick priced for rip-offs at $15.

I am strong, I am invincible, I am woman takes on a whole new meaning at 50 feet tall.
Mottola's script perfectly captures man's lifelong pursuit of often-unattainable coolness. And cool girls.
Desperately quirky, with desperately quirky characters. There are no characters in this film who aren't quirky. That's a problem.
There was a time when car movies used to be about the cars. The star of this picture is a computer, creating CGI car crashes. The picture is a phony.
Featuring edited moments from the popular Planet Earth as seen on Discovery Channel, apparently Disney's idea of going green is to recycle film footage for theaters.
The Informers is grimy, nasty and graphic in its depictions of excess, and those are its good points.
Deliciously twisty and featuring a fiercely fun performance from Russell Crowe at its core, the picture is a welcome addition to the conspiracy-mad thriller genre.
A colorful portrayal of friendship, the transformative power of music and an examination of Los Angeles homelessness that entertains as well as it informs.
Set phasers for fun. May this Trek live long and prosper.
It's neither a clever comic-book flick nor an explosive summer blockbuster above the most pedestrian computer-generated level of destruction.
The kind of issue-oriented film that will make you angry, mostly because it eschews any thought of serious debate in favor of liberal dogma.
The film's power in capturing some of the seemingly banal moments of everyday life punctuate with bang-bang fervor the human loss that accumulates later.
Yes, the film is a helluva lot more entertaining than The Da Vinci Code. Yes, Tom Hanks and Robert Langdon have been to the barber.
There's a lot to like about Shall We Kiss? once it really gets going, which is about one-third of the way into the picture.
movie_title: Un Baiser s'il vous plaît (Shall We Kiss?) (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Great Terminator movies feature brains as well as entertainment value, brawn as well as fun, and James Cameron's innovations. Salvation has none of these things.
Director James Cameron has once again reminded us why we go to the movies and why screens the size of the stories-tall Imax are still necessary.
Jason Reitman is America's smartest young filmmaker.
The delight of Downey and Law in combination proves you don't have to feature a great villain or a complete story if you've got two super heroes.
A toothless nostalgia trip, awash in name-dropping and only occasionally charming as a coming-of-age story.
The designer with a style of combining new trends with classic elements of the past takes that theme to the cinema with dynamic effect.
Michael Cera can't forever play a teenage boy in search of lust. That's a shame, because there are a lot of lousy movies in this genre, and he's in the good ones.
The 2010 version is a creature of its time, unfortunately. It has little idea how to create tension, a liability that director Joe Johnston conceals with a high gross-out factor.
Oh, to have my brain wiped of Push. The smell of desperation on the part of filmmakers to create their own superhero franchise is rancid.
Realized by Tykwer as a convoluted roman a clef that, without much heart, seems to have been pumped up with action scenes.
The visuals are intimate and startling, comparable only to viewing a fantastic aquarium, and the aquarium is sitting in your lap.
Thomas and Zylberstein are exceptional beyond the film itself, which demands deliberation and made me wish that it delivered a more memorable payoff for that patience.
Quantum of Solace is a fantastic ride, but here's hoping that when James Bond returns, he can stir us while enjoying a shaken martini or two.
Demme's capturing of the communal spirit of weddings and harsh reunions creates something quite honest and refreshing, with an unusual energy that more films could use.
The film is a lasting document on the subjects of Hurricane Katrina, tragedy and bureaucratic incompetence.

A beautifully photographed film that hammers home its point (people are essentially good, Nazis are evil) repeatedly and simplistically.
movie_title: The Boy in the Striped Pajamas (The Boy in the Striped Pyjamas) (2008)

movie_review_blurb: An old-fashioned, screen-filling picture that is at times as rousing and untamed as the continent that it depicts.

movie_title: The Day the Earth Stood Still (2008)

movie_review_blurb: At turns wonderfully entertaining, powerfully heartfelt and downright chilling as it delivers its message: Pay attention, life will tell you all you need to know.

Fincher's achievement is, in both quality and spirit, a film of great beauty, and it touched me deeply.
movie_title: The Curious Case of Benjamin Button (2008)

movie_review_blurb: For people who find that movies that are full of sentimentality and sympathy set off their gag reflex, this is the holiday movie for you.
movie_title: Un Conte de Noël (A Christmas Tale) (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Kate Winslet is the sheer force that lifts a film with a provocative concept, but uneven execution, to become an absorbing drama about reconciling a nation's past.

Constantly brutal and consistently terrifying. The acting, that is.

An interesting story with handsome production values, but full of romantic contrivances and blockbuster conceits. This is the Holocaust at its action-hero worst.
There is great anguish and great artistry in this showcase by Winslet. This is a film that hurts so good.

A fantasy film intended as an adventure flick that requires this disclaimer: Do not operate heavy machinery after viewing.

A crackling good political thriller, made in the spirit of some of the best espionage films, and with themes like eco-terrorism and whistleblowers that make it feel immediate like few recent dramas.
By the time this twisty mystery unfolds its ideas of how the past haunts people, how guilt consumes and how memories shape our mind's machinery, the result is elegant, creepy, fantastic cinema.

It has a better chance of boring you to death than inducing fear.

This is murky stuff plot-wise, but there's something odd and original about the relationship between Farrell's and Rapace's characters, in their mutual vengeance and shared pain.

As a baseball movie, in its period look, in delivering its message: This entertaining picture is a solid double off the warning-track wall.
It's a movie that makes you think -- if not outright say -- You're a good guy. You don't have to do something this stupid. Oh, now look what you've gone and done.
Deliciously twisty, until it has too many twists.
It delivers its message of hope and healing in a manner that is honest, entertaining and authentic, in a film that can reach audiences both religious and secular.
Of all of the qualities that Cruise brings to a film, an unfortunate one is inevitability. To alter that perception, and truly surprise us, would really be a Maverick move.
We can trust in Tony Stark, even when he's falling apart and can't trust himself.
No one looks more lost in the movie than Washington, its biggest right-this-moment star.
Too specific when it should be open to interpretation, and too concerned with style, it looks lavish -- but looks aren't everything.

The international ensemble might resemble a bad beer commercial if these people didn't work together so seamlessly and have actual conversations and laughs about their pasts, their futures, life, love and, of course, cars.

Rude, crude and socially unacceptable, and in all of those ways, it is hilarious.

The film is about finding your inner child and acceptance and maturing into something greater. This is what gives me hope for the inevitable sequel.
The picture is very funny, and the animation is beautiful, and yet it's all a bit forgettable, by Pixar standards. That's the price of success.
Amour is a pure depiction of love, in all its many forms.

The poster-child for the big, dumb action movie, but Bruce Willis as John McClane makes everything better.
movie_title: A Good Day To Die Hard (2013)

movie_review_blurb: Unlike much of early 2013's dead-on-arrival movie fare, this picture has a pulse, and a brain, and a heart that beats strong.
It shows a maturing in Perry's work from the pandering of his men-are-all-dogs films.
movie_title: Why Did I Get Married Too (2010)

A head trip into blunderland.
The kind of remake that I wish Hollywood would make more of: Take an old film that had great ideas but wasn't a great film, and get it right the second time.

Is the movie over-thought? Sometimes, yes. But challenging material is rarely as satisfying as in this blockbuster from one of the dream factory's most gifted artisans.
A safe, bland, test-marketed product made for tween mass consumption. Like most films arriving with ampersands and colons in the title, it's a bore.
movie_title: Percy Jackson & the Olympians: The Lightning Thief (2010)

movie_review_blurb: This thin slice of so-called history is both so narrow in focus and out of focus that even the most devoted fans are likely to be disappointed.
I should have been spending time considering why the defector would lie and why Salt would run, but I couldn't get past wondering why there are so many ponderous flashbacks.

This is Tim Blake Nelson's affectionate and curious vision of his native Oklahoma, and what he sees makes for a uniquely restless, ribald motion picture.

Depp disappears into the character to create a cold-blooded killer who can create empathy when tragedy befalls his family, and he shows us a level-headed businessman who can strangle a woman to death and then take a nap before a dinner meeting.

Disappointment reigns when you consider the gifts of this filmmaker.

While Logan finds a mature tone to carry this final chapter of Wolverine's story, it doesn't come to a conclusion with any more meaning to it than this: People, in general, don't change; more violence will be necessary.
Kong: Skull Island works on a pure-adrenaline level of excitement, fully aware that the audience isn't here for a story, or the actors, but for the monsters and the destruction.
Very solid and safe, but still sure to charm audiences of all ages, like those kids who fell in love with this story more than 25 years ago and who now will treat their own children.
The worst crime that CHIPS commits: It's not funny.
There's not much that's original about Life -- almost nothing -- but there is some fun to be had in wondering whether a trip to Mars is worth all this trouble.
The intelligent choices of the director and the nuanced performance of Jessica Chastain make this important story one worth watching.
It is a sweet-but-average movie saved only by the sheer on-screen magic of its three Oscar-winning stars.

We've all seen this it-means-well movie before, and Gifted does have a pretty high sweetness factor, but if nothing else, it's an introduction to a young new talent to watch for -- if not an example of Evans as being able to broaden his path.

We all have moments in life in which we feel like a monster... That high concept resonates in this fantasy-meets-black comedy gem, an art-house curiosity about personal failings, redemption and giant monsters that seems destined for cult status.
Don't walk, don't run....Walkman your way to this out-of-this-world blast of entertainment.
I'm conflicted about Patriots Day, a new drama based on the events of the Boston Marathon bombing, which I wanted to like more than I did.
There's never a dull moment in the latest film based on the Arthurian legend, and there aren't many moments that make much sense, either.
movie_title: King Arthur: Legend Of The Sword (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Hidden Figures is triumphant in a way that can restore your faith in the dreams we can achieve in this nation if we all are willing to work together as one.
This is awards-season bait aimed straight at your sentimental side that loves a good tearjerker and one which earns most of the tears that it jerks.

Emily Blunt... is wonderful in a mediocre movie.

American Honey is a beautifully crafted film, and a good film, that possibly could have been a great film with the right editing.
Jack Reacher: Never Go Back isn't the worst movie of the year. But it might be the most unnecessary, for multiple reasons.
Do they catch Langdon here? Please. Langdon's historical knowledge allows him to know a secret passageway to take. Every. Single. Time.
It's difficult to grade a film when the subject matter, and the subjects, feel so incomplete.
"Trolls" is a rainbow-sprinkled nightmare.
Hacksaw Ridge is beautiful and brutal, and that's a potent combination for a movie about a man determined to serve his country, as well as his soul.
Arrival is a first-rate story about first contact because it meets that great science-fiction movie test: It's less about who they are and more about who we are.
While lacking in surprises, it's full of charm, thanks to an ensemble that makes it look like they had a blast making this movie.
It's enchanting, romantic, dark and retains that Potter-like spirit.
movie_title: Fantastic Beasts and Where to Find Them (2016)

movie_review_blurb: One of the year's most provocative and sensitive films. And one of the best.
The two lead performances are this good: They made the Lovings real people to me, and this couple, and their abiding affection, may have been the perfect case to prove that all love is created equal.
Allied just might be the most disappointing film of the year. It's certainly one of the most boring.

[It's] is the very definition of a movie that "has its moments," not that they necessarily add up to something that makes sense. But Beatty has for a half-century been an exception to many rules, and even when he misses, it's still sort of interesting.

Steinfeld's presence, and great writing, make this a movie in which most of us can see our own teen experiences relived.

The thing about a Kenneth Lonergan movie is that it feels like you're watching people, not actors. You're watching a world unfold, and not some form of fiction.
Sing isn't about much, and there are zero surprises, outside of just how many songs can be sandwiched into one movie.
There's no denying Portman's depiction of class and grace under pressure, capturing the emotions of that time and showing people who were scared and confused a way to heal.
La La Land has the best opening scene of the year. It has the best closing scene of the year. What's in between those scenes is merely incredible entertainment and expert filmmaking.
Denzel Washington and Viola Davis are go-at-it, toe-to-toe heavyweight champions. They are incredible, and Fences is special.

In showing us understanding with how to cope with the greatest loss, and how the human connection can continue, the filmmakers behind A Monster Calls have shown us one thing more than any other: the truth.
There is fun to be had, despite the characters making the same dumb mistakes that were made in the last movie...and the one before that...and so on.

If you don't feel more connected to your fellow man after Wonder, check your pulse.

This is bravura filmmaking, steeped in rich storytelling and tense moments that I will never forget.

If The Room is the "Citizen Kane of bad movies," as it has notoriously been tagged, then The Disaster Artist, the story of the making of that film, is the shaggy-dog redemption story that it deserves.
Darkest Hour is a fine film about Winston Churchill and his decision-making as Hitler swept through Europe that will ultimately be remembered for one thing: Gary Oldman is Churchill.

The sensuousness of Lemon Tree is its glory.
The new players can't generate the grimy elan of the old film.

Fable, emotion and psychology merge in a fairy-tale brew that will hold children rapt and engage the better angels of adults.

It's a nightmare that starts like a normal daytime drive and ends in a vortex-like sinkhole.
A refreshingly unpredictable and fizzy comic fantasy.

You never completely lose their feeling for the little guy, but by the end you feel a bit like Max's mom. Once you know he's safe, you're more than ready to drift into deep sleep.
Klapisch's movie boasts passages of genuine magic.
Every time the performers insinuate some fresh response, the concepts close in on them. I began to dread even the funny bits, because I knew director Peter Billingsley would milk them to death.
A surprisingly calm documentary about the history of American ecological activism. But it's good calm, not dead calm.

If you're looking for good company, you'll get it.

Moore has always stood proudly for progressivism, and that works in his favor now.
An exciting, infuriating, combative experience.
movie_title: Der Baader Meinhof Komplex (The Baader Meinhof Complex) (2008)

Keenly observed, good-natured and funny.

...everything about the movie is a little out-of-it, and not just because it's been lying on the studio shelf for a couple of years.

[Director] Klore's grasp of his characters give this movie depth.

movie_title: Pirates of the Caribbean: At Worlds End (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Moore's simple triumph in Sicko is to pump fresh air into the discussion.
These filmmakers boast a tactile command of lower-case depression humor. And Kingsley and Leoni master it with rare cool glee.
Director/writer Olivier Dahan renders Piaf's biography as a soft-serve twirl of gutter spunk and pathos, skating back and forth across the line that separates emotion from sentimentality.

...if you're familiar with the story, the movie whizzes by without leaving you with fresh revelation or insight. If you don't know it, all Winterbottom presents is a series of facts leavened with small, tight emotions.

...the less said about this film the better. It's that good.
Across the Universe is disarming, discombobulating and disappointing.

From the opening sequence of suicide attackers, to the daringly prolonged ambush, chase and shoot out that closes the film, [director] Berg doesn't let up on the tension, even when the action is bloodless.

movie_title: The King of Kong: A Fistful of Quarters (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Fundamentally insane.

movie_title: Eternal Sunshine Of The Spotless Mind (2004)

movie_review_blurb: As the final chapter of, essentially, a single 10-hour movie, it has a narrative beauty and a sublime ensemble performance that put it in a class by itself.

movie_review_blurb: Tamahori's visceral instincts can't guide him through a fantasy-land where agents outrace avalanches and swim unharmed through Arctic waters.

movie_title: Harry Potter and the Chamber of Secrets (2002)

movie_title: Harry Potter and the Goblet of Fire (2005)

The movie is scaled too big visually and too small emotionally.

Ponderous tale of intrigue in Japanese-controlled Shanghai during the Second World War.

movie_review_blurb: Opening against Sex and the City, it's counterprogramming that runs counter to any sane notion of art or entertainment.

Prince Caspian, the second entry in the Chronicles of Narnia series, is a glorious medieval war movie.
movie_title: The Chronicles of Narnia: Prince Caspian (2008)

It is a trip, but it's a bad trip.

What Happens in Vegas is the kind of terrible mistake performers as big as Cameron Diaz and Ashton Kutcher usually make at the beginning of their careers, when they're anxious to break into the movies, or at the end, when they're struggling for a comeback

Girls Rock! is scrappy, but at its best, it shows you humans blooming with the speed of flowers in time-lapse photography.

Williams has no chance to create a character, and McGregor's is one big -- no, slender -- cliche. And if it's fun at first to see Jackman acting urbane instead of all Wolverine-like, by the end he's just another brute in a suit.
By the time it reaches its supposedly crowd-pleasing finale, Baby Mama may have self-respecting comedy fans (and even Tina Fey fans) crying uncle.

movie_title: Where in the World Is Osama Bin Laden? (2008)

Less like a party than a long night at a friendly saloon. Still, it's replete with wayward charms.
Kate Beckinsale is too good for any of the guys in Snow Angels and too good for this movie.

movie_review_blurb: The year's big dramatic gambling hit, 21, is all plot, no personality; The Grand, a comedy that follows six contenders into the finals of a poker tournament, is all personality, no plot. I'll take personality.

[A] superb film about the eternal pull of family.

movie_review_blurb: Step Brothers is outrageous enough to acquire a cult. Complete with male nudity and dog poop, it's like a midnight movie you can catch at a matinee.

movie_title: The X-Files: I Want to Believe (The X Files 2) (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Canny, refreshingly emotional and intuitive thriller.
movie_title: Ne le Dis à Personne (Tell No One) (2006)

movie_review_blurb: A party where everyone is so desperate to have a good time that it makes you miserable.
It's the standard-bearer for the school of comic-book movies that confuses pompousness with seriousness and popular mechanics for drama.

movie_title: For the Bible Tells Me So (2007)

movie_review_blurb: The main problem is the movie hems in Murphy.

Up the Yangtze provides a devastating view of top-down, broad-stroke social programs.

The film pulls you by the scruff of the neck and makes you thankful for it. It releases every ounce of pent-up frustration and rage in your body.
A semi-hilarious nonformula movie that makes you realize why formulas are born.

With so much ground to cover, Carroll's own story must hold everything together. And it just about does, because it's inherently fascinating.
This movie will give true believers their money's worth. It's hit or miss -- yet when a legendary figure like the Hulk hits, the impact is startling, and even when he fans, he generates gale force.

The details... are often sharp and funny.
The filmmakers both pillory the tourism industry and lambaste families just out for a good time -- the same audience, I would think, for their movie.

Slapstick and romantic tragedy slam into each other -- and, almost unique in a period piece, the characters become so 'real' they're magical.
