The Lego Batman Movie mostly proves that this franchise has already descended into a disappointing formula. These movies flash a subversive hook, then straighten it out as they streak along.
Dark Night is an extraordinarily accomplished mood piece saddled with a shallow condemnation of middle-American culture. The whole movie is like an extended art-house PSA.
My Life as a Zucchini has grace and charm, but what breaks your heart is its mental toughness.
movie_title: My Life as a Zucchini (Ma vie de courgette) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: ...by staying faithful to its characters-women who make, break, and alter an intimate connection-it expresses a refreshing freedom from sexual-identity dogma and narrative formula.
You don't have to be gloating over a wasted generation to embrace T2 Trainspotting, a confident, quirky comedy-drama that skillfully alternates bangs and whimpers.
Wind River ultimately aims to be an existential survival movie, but that aim is rarely true.

[Darren] Aronofsky wants mother! to have the intensity and inner logic of a sweaty nightmare. But it's a fake cinematic fever dream-the kind made by a director so self-conscious that he's always checking his own temperature.
The two actors' timing is marvelous. They salvage the force of the play's splintered dialogue.
In Darkest Hour, Wright's charged, blustery framework pulls the audience into a distant political landscape. But his approach here is also limiting and nearly wearying.

The plot and the structure undercut the affection Allen has for his salt-of-the-seaside characters. The writer-director falls in love with a tidy narrative arc that ends up more like a vicious circle.
Foxtrot comes together as a complex plea for honesty, openness, frankness, and forgiveness. The movie is also, incidentally, a spectacularly effective antiwar film...
Star Wars: The Last Jedi may not be perfect, but the need to accept imperfection and keep going becomes one of the movie's themes...It's about mentorship that's invigorating rather than smothering.
The performances and the staging have a risky, improvisatory edge; Bergman even cuts away to interviews with his four lead actors.
The suspense squeezes us like a clamp.
movie_title: All the Money in the World (2017)

movie_review_blurb: With these performers milking every moment for "feeling" and "meaning," the emotional dynamics become stunningly obvious.
Is anything as improbable as a "feel-good" movie that actually leaves us feeling terrific? How about two of them in the same series?
[Director Wes Ball] wisely bookends that introductory sequence with a bittersweet, meditative coda that allows Thomas, and the audience, to measure his losses.
Here as in Ex Machina (2015), Garland's creative élan comes from his merging of sleek conceptual art and messy, juicy drama.
By homing in on her character, the filmmakers stay true to her part of the book, but they cut away too much of what gives this kind of entertainment its charm and variety.

Clint Eastwood's The 15:17 to Paris takes a taut, engrossing, and surprising nonfiction book-the most complete and genuine account of an act of real-life heroism that enthralled the whole free world-and turns it into a flaccid, bewildering docudrama.
Black Panther gives off a contemporary crackle while staying true to its roots, both African and Marvel.
So ingeniously acted out by its puppet cast that it tickles you even when it makes you squirm.
[Denzel] Washington tops himself as the title character.
This film devolves into single-minded scare tactics and reduces its actors to mannequins or torture toys. It drains all personality away.
movie_title: The Killing of a Sacred Deer (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Chris Hemsworth releases a comic daredevil spirit comparable to that other dashing Australian swashbuckler, Errol Flynn.
Andrew Garfield gives his most spirited, expansive performance to date.

In the showiest sequence, Lucy's body starts exploding into bursts of confetti. Even then, Johannson holds everything together. She's the rare actress who brings conviction and clarity to flights of fancy.
A near-classic of postadolescent confusion and longing.
Martin Scorsese's début feature has just the slightest bit of story line, but the movie is a fascinating portfolio piece: a black-and-white blueprint for "Mean Streets."
movie_title: Who's That Knocking at My Door? (1967)

movie_review_blurb: The Dark Horse is a rough beauty of a picture.
Garrone makes you feel as if you've stepped into a world where fickle gods play crack-the-whip with man's-and woman's-fate.
movie_title: Tale of Tales (Il racconto dei racconti) (2016)

movie_review_blurb: But defects and all, navels or not, Viktoria remains a distinctive, trenchant social-political mock epic about a little big girl.
Although Green Room has more scope and technical ambition than Blue Ruin, artistically it takes a giant step back.
Demolition lacks the substance to be genuinely poetic.
The plot twists are hokey, but the atmosphere is bleak and tense, and the men's performances nuanced.

The magic of Hawke's performance is that, without whitewashing Baker, he never stops locating the innocence within his crude behavior. His simplicity and honesty are disarming, especially as Jane batters him with questions.
Farhadi has a terrific sense of touch. He knows how to use visual and dramatic means to make a milieu palpable to an audience.
In Hood's Eye in the Sky, Aaron Paul's conscience-stricken pilot is affecting, and you cheer him on when he challenges an order that he considers inhumane and precipitate.
These filmmakers cross-fertilize social satire with burlesque, parody, and self-parody.
This movie rescues the concept of "the fog of war" from cliché and overuse.
By now, the Coen Brothers are reflexively called "quirky." The only perverse thing about this movie, though, is that it salutes a company man.
A powerful, swooning visualization of a wilderness childhood.
Over Caesar's corpse Brando begins to mix grief, rage, cunning, and ferocity; his reading of the funeral oration is so quakingly angry you understand why it would rouse the rabble.
13 Hours is one combat movie that doesn't blink-and it doesn't gloat, either. Even when the men take pleasure in "kicking the ass" of the enemy, they express relief more than triumph.
movie_title: 13 Hours: The Secret Soldiers Of Benghazi (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Director Pablo Trapero, who also co-wrote the script, pulls off his share of show-off sequences without succumbing to empty virtuosity.

Mizoguchi's harmonious yet unexpected compositions, his andante tempo and long takes, and his pellucid blocking produce sequences that resonate throughout the movie, often with material as mundane as the slicing of a watermelon.
movie_title: Zangiku monogatari (The Story of the Last Chrysanthemums) (1979)

movie_review_blurb: Defenders of this movie will talk about its "sense of place." But this film has only a sense of things framed in a world of wonders, like the patched-up keelboat of the trappers, or even Glass's banged-up anatomy itself.
But the movie can't sustain its playfulness-or its tension, either. Abrams is too busy trying to roll the original Star Wars and The Empire Strikes Back into one two-hour-and-15-minute movie.
movie_title: Star Wars: Episode VII - The Force Awakens (2015)

movie_review_blurb: The Big Short functions as a real-life Kafka farce.

Stripped of rhythm, nuance, and grandeur, the verse functions as a prosaic device for delivering the plot. Macbeth becomes the simple story of a war hero egged on by his ambitious wife to attain the monarchy via regicide.
At his best, his new film is both visually striking and expressive: those lightning opening vignettes, for example, convey the volatile, claustrophobic tensions of juvie in mere seconds.
The Hunger Games: Mockingjay Part 2 draws on a well of feeling, imagination, and, yes, sensibility that extends beyond the movie screen.

The latest entry in George Lucas' transgalactic saga of the moral rise and fall of Anakin Skywalker and the deterioration of democracy into despotism has an electric visual majesty and boasts Lucas' best direction since American Graffiti.
movie_title: Star Wars: Episode II - Attack of the Clones (2002)

movie_review_blurb: Douglas Fairbanks's first great acrobatic epic, from 1920, set the standard for zesty swashbucklers.

The supporting miners are as caricatured as the most famous miners in movie history-Snow White's seven dwarves-though the pastor, the drinker, and the ladies' man are not as engaging as Doc, Happy, and Bashful.

McCarthy is just as shrewd at evaluating the practical morality of attorneys: white collars as well as clerical collars fall into patterns that perpetuate evil. McCarthy has cast his legal roles with actors who can sound psychological depths on the run.
In A Bigger Splash, Fiennes uses all his showmanship, imagination, and empathy to vitalize a character who is both the life of the party-and, in one uncanny twist, the death of it.
Fonda, touching as an actor, proves astonishing as a director, using a fluid, tactile style to conjure a life lived close to the elements and to sudden death.
The "civil war" that erupts among Avengers foments filmmaking invention, not anarchy. It harks back to a comic-book tradition that predates the Avengers.

Bobin, who can do low-key, as in TV's Flight of the Conchords, and keyed-up, as in Muppets Most Wanted, goes no-key in Alice Through the Looking Glass. He directs so anonymously, it's as if he's imitating Burton on a bad day.
Bayona's actors connect and disconnect with heartfelt veracity and unexpected sophistication.
Melfi never loses sight of his heroines' dual struggle, as women and as black people. He encourages his actors to play on that duality with wisdom, anger, and a nuanced sort of farce.
[Chazelle's] filmmaking exuberance and the energy and sweetness of his two stars give this thin soup considerable tang.
Tudyk's K-2S0 has in miniature what Edwards's movie lacks overall: the soul of a new machine.
movie_title: Rogue One: A Star Wars Story (2016)

movie_review_blurb: The film ends with that contemporary movie rarity-an authentic and overwhelming display of gratitude.
Vincente Minnelli makes use of the wide screen with graceful, fluid movement, and he helps Martin anchor his usual breeziness with just the right amount of anxiety.
The second effort by fashion designer turned writer-director Tom Ford (A Single Man) is a roadside horror film wrapped inside a chichi relationship movie.
Loving is a dogged work, not a great or inspired one, but it gets to you nonetheless.
The movie conveys her rage, rejection, and isolation, but unfortunately doubles down on the confusion.
Tampopo creates a culinary empire of the senses while entertaining an audience like crazy.
Denial deftly establishes how the moral relativism of contemporary academics and the journalistic belief in giving all viewpoints equal time lead to intellectual bankruptcy.
The ensemble is seamless.
Sully may be just want the mass audience wants in the 21st century: a disaster film with a happy ending.
Stone's own presence as a director is oppressive. It's as if he's phoning it in from O'Brian's video-call system, with big, obvious touches that might be confused with mastery.
Cianfrance is so committed to Thomas and Isabel's perspectives that his movie becomes claustrophobic without ever being particularly revealing (or convincing).
Some amusing stuff about sports agentry drowns in the emotional shallows of Jerry Maguire.

Thanks to Walter Murch's keen, intuitive sound montage and Hackman's clammy, subtle performance, the movie captures [an] elusive and universal fear-that of losing the power to respond, emotionally and morally, to the evidence of one's own senses.
To borrow the tagline of Superman I, you'll believe a dragon can fly. You'll even believe he can feel.

Even the most garish escapism requires a director who has the mental discipline to hold out for a fecund idea and the inventive power to build on it. In Suicide Squad, as in Sabotage, the only time brains enter the picture is when heads explode.

The blinding, brain-smacking mayhem can't wipe out the movie's core of good feeling. Even after the action goes bust, the film's gifted stars continue to radiate their own nuclear-powered, Amazonian brand of bonhomie.
Though Owen's achievements are extraordinary, the film demonstrates that there are things Disney cartoons can't teach: full self-sufficiency and satisfying adult sexual relationships.
Generally, Spielberg packs the frame with so much amusing clutter that he detracts from Rylance's witty, emotional line readings.
Gibney is surely right in calling for open and informed debate about cyber warfare, but his own movie lacks transparency and persuasiveness. What a terrible moment for this director to go unclear.
We know we're in good hands from the opening moments, when the New Zealand greenery undulates across the screen while an otherworldly choral chant fills the soundtrack.
Stanton is a born comic-fantasy director.

In the best moments of Kandahar, Makhmalbaf conveyed every twist of irony in these savage juxtapositions. In The President, the weight of his preaching tends to flatten out the ironies and the epiphanies.
De Palma has the best kind of ending for a director documentary: it leaves us wondering what's yet to come from this protean and multifaceted filmmaker.

It wants to be a responsible topical thriller, but the change in focus from the fed-up prole to the battle-hardened broadcast virtuosos is so misjudged that the movie comes off as socially unconscious.
The pieces of this would-be feel-good movie sink into place with a depressing thud.
Terminator Genisys fails to provide what this series has needed for a full quarter-century: the soul of a new machine.
Boyhood, at its best, boasts qualities that are usually under-valued in avant-garde work: tingling observations, unforced comedy and quirky, enduring charm.
This holiday movie about a man of God who regains his faith thanks to a miraculous candle is as picturesque as a snow globe and just about as full of human life.
Katniss Everdeen's quandaries and director Francis Lawrence builds suspense through cunning shifts of character in this spiffy second chapter of the trilogy.
It's got storytelling vigor and clarity, bright, eclectic animation, and a frisky musical wit.
Jeunet and Caro have distinctive signatures like nobody else's.
movie_title: The City of Lost Children (La Cité des Enfants Perdus) (1995)

movie_review_blurb: What makes this animated feature such intense, giddy fun is the eruption of uninhibited parody that Robin Williams provides as the voice of the Genie in Aladdin's lamp.
The Fellowship of the Ring is a movie masterpiece thrilling, passionate and wise.
movie_title: The Lord of the Rings: The Fellowship of the Ring (2001)

movie_review_blurb: This movie about a Belgian bluegrass banjo-player and his family is filled with dazzling lyrical heights and deflating melodramatic lows.
The Armstrong Lie is one of the best batches of lemonade ever made from a severely bruised lemon.
The sequel to a deft romantic ensemble hit tries too hard to add heartbreak, uplift and religious, family values messages to the comedy-drama.
This swift, gorgeous, uneven production captures the scope, flavor and drive, if not the depth, of Dickens' greatest novel.
A trio of terrific performers imbues a riveting AIDS drama with heart and mind as well as pertinence.
This near-end-of-the-world movie for teenagers, set mostly in the English countryside, is too vague and shaky for its own good, but it generates a haunting ambiance and develops a cumulative power.

It's like a smorgasbord designed to give fans all they can eat -- or a roadside 24-hour buffet that clocks in, blessedly, at a mere two hours. Its welcoming air and variety can't fully disguise its lack of top-notch ingredients.
A hilarious knockdown of corporate culture.
A lot of agreeable kookiness compensates for the ramshackle script in this tale of turkeys traveling back in time to prevent becoming an essential part of Thanksgiving dinner.
This exploration of tumultuous romance is rare in its scope and frankness.
It's a bit like what The Godfather would have been if it had been set in "The Bank of Evil" from Despicable Me -- and if its antihero were a cipher instead of Michael Corleone.
Keanu Reeves makes his directorial debut in a cartoonish kung fu movie with splashy fight scenes and an underdeveloped wit.
The latest sprawling romcom/family drama from Richard Curtis way outlasts its charm.
The movie ends up specializing in a kind of dynamic ambivalence. It makes you distrust military triumph and hope for a stable peace.
This oater with shades of Weird West comic books has a plot too easy to foretell and a thrill level that dips with the rising of the body count.
Remarkably, The Summit achieves some of the same dizzying impact as Gravity -- by philosophical and psychological means, rather than special effects.
[Weigert] and Passon team up to create an indelible portrait of a woman who may always be a work in progress.
It's a relief that writer-director Le-Van Kiet relies more on powers of suggestion than on digital flimflam for instigating thrills. The gore is all the more jolting for being used so sparingly.
The movie is both a star vehicle and an ensemble piece; the other actors revolve around Newman yet give off more than just his reflected light.
One of the finest historical movies ever made.
Robert Redford's true grit and some wizardly images, not the script, are what make this one-man survival epic ineluctably compelling.
Alexander Payne has crafted an ornery American comedy with a brusque Midwestern edge and a core of authentic feeling. It provokes wise, wary laughter even as it makes you choke back tears.
[A] gaudy pseudo-existential crime drama.
A a computer-animated burlesque fairy tale that generates more belly laughs than any live-action comedy since Best in Show.

The chemistry between Steve Coogan as a snooty journalist and Judi Dench as a retired nurse searching for her son brings humor and warmth to a harrowing tale of the plight of unwed Irish Catholic mothers in the 1950s.
The actors push too hard to flesh out this whimsical, clichéd blend of campus comedy and midlife rom-com.
In this transfixing documentary about a Baltimore boy striving to join illegal urban dirt bikers, first-time filmmaker Lofty Nathan conjures a unique journalistic excitement.
The result is awkward, hyped propaganda for faith-based initiatives and against abortion.
This hostage drama swiftly degenerates into a gauzy wish fulfillment about two outsiders finding each other in a love that must overcome boundaries, separation and time.
Writer-director Alain Guiraudie has an imagistic talent for suspense and erotic byplay.
Part of its problem is infantilism.
It's a particularly heartless, mindless and soulless example of the buddy movie -- really more just a frenemy burlesque of a buddy movie.
The cast brings welcome personality to a competent, energetic reboot before the uninspired action scenes pile up in a standard time-bomb climax.
Grotesquely wrongheaded.
[A] melodramatic attack on America's family law system.
Offers a nightmare vision of what happens when gaudy histrionics poison a powerhouse ensemble.
In the scenes of Dickens acting on stage or delivering a public reading, Fiennes' bravura transcends itself; it becomes something magnificently real, a sort of divine extroversion.
A virtuoso, brutal rendering of a SEAL team's fight for life in a forbidding patch of Afghanistan.
This sprawling mock epic about a sleazy penny stock whiz contains scenes of astonishing black-comic brilliance, but it's also solipsistic and exhausting.
The Secret Life of Walter Mitty creates an escapist world that grows out of and enriches the real world -- and it does so with revitalizing confidence and ease.
movie_title: The Secret Life Of Walter Mitty (2013)

movie_review_blurb: At its best, McKay and Ferrell's brand of homegrown American Dada can make you collapse laughing in your seat and cry uncle.
The source of this movie's galvanizing intrigue is that the characters remain in play -- they never settle into place
The sad-funny story of a stubborn, talented Greenwich Village folk singer becomes a stunning, tragicomic paradigm of an artist's struggle in America.
It's enthralling fun to watch Walt Disney (Tom Hanks) focus his charm and instinct on flinty British novelist P.L. Travers (Emma Thompson) as he campaigns to film her Mary Poppins.
8 Women is meant to be a sampler with the likes of Deneuve, Darrieux, Huppert, Ardant and Beart as its treats. But the confectioner has arrived at pretty poison.
Tim Allen's talent for dry regular-guyness fails to kindle Disney's sappy big-screen Yule log.
This haunting documentary contrasts songs saluting Mexican drug lords as heroic bandits with the harrowing reality of life in murder-stained Juarez.
A scintillating, sincere and empathetic portrait of the pinup queen who attained her greatest influence as an icon of female sexuality decades after she retired.
It's so determined to be haunting that it gives up the ghost.
No one does erupting instinct better than Robert Downey Jr.... No one does calculated outrageousness better than Val Kilmer... They're itchy-funny and potent together.
The melding of a modern family saga with the Nativity is too awkward and hectic to let audiences sit back and appreciate some powerhouse singers and music.
The splashy humor and dazzling set pieces of this erratic animated mélange compensate for putting a pallid female Mr. Freeze at the center of a paean to sisterly love.
Spike Lee turns Josh Brolin into a full-bodied antihero in this all-American remake of a Korean cult movie, but the story remains a bloody bag of tricks.
This vibrant portrait of a legendary New York bohemia in the 1940s transcends its flaws by evoking genuine feeling for poets in their youth.
Escape Plan is set in an ultra-modern prison, but it's fossilized entertainment.
Kimberly Peirce's remake of Brian De Palma's Carrie isn't a total fiasco like Gus Van Sant's remake of Alfred Hitchcock's Psycho, but it's equally gratuitous.

This engaging documentary about Jewish-American comedians pays homage to the Borscht Belt masters of disrespect who brought their tumultuous, irreverent clowning into the American mainstream during the early days of network television.
The flaws of this acutely self-conscious 1970 road picture grow more obvious with every passing year, but so does its passion and eloquence.
Even the novelty of a deadly, blasphemous Hit-Girl wears off, and all that's left is over-the-top violence and under-the-belt humor.
The film is all thunderous clichés.
Whiny, listless and repetitive.
The baseline for American movie humor sinks once again in this sentimentally cynical and cynically sentimental farce.
The movie's blue-collar aesthetic, impressive in its vision and kinetics, lacks emotional variety and humor.
A zippy little programmer designed to exploit the same vehicles-as-people formula as the Cars franchise.
The Spectacular Now is zesty, funny, sad, and wise beyond its characters' years.
Too much of Minority Report is facile, albeit at a very high level.
Brad Bird fills the CinemaScope screen with wit and beauty in this modern fairy tale.
When the cast and their director are really cooking, they conjure a bipolar sense of high school-age emotion -- and use it to fuel outrageous fantasy.
Blue Jasmine ranks with Vicky Cristina Barcelona and Midnight in Paris at the top of Woody Allen's recent movies.
This riveting documentary about political mass murder in Indonesia incorporates the killers' own movie fantasies about their massacres and deepens our understanding of the fascist brain.
Not since the schmaltzy Bucket List has there been a more blatant example of checklist comedy than the ultra-raunchy The To Do List.

2 Guns slops over with instantly over-familiar ingredients like bantering criminal and/or crime-fighting buddies, a loathsome Mexican drug lord, and a femme vitale and femme fatale rolled into one comely dame.
It's as if the moviemakers were trying to cook up a New Age Yorkshire pudding, without meat drippings -- what's missing is Burnett's robust optimism and animistic energy.

Theaters showing Storm Surfers 3D ought to create a splash zone. This exuberant documentary about the perennially stoked team of big-wave stalkers Tom Carroll and Ross Clarke-Jones takes audiences right into the barrel of the beast.
Springsteen & I captures rock-star and rock-fan power and resolve at its funniest, grittiest and most profound.
It has a more absorbing story and intriguing sensibility than Iron Man 3 or Man of Steel, and even when its action falters, this film is more original and exotic.
Empathy and authenticity keep you on the edge of your seat at Fruitvale Station.
Mads Mikkelsen displays remarkable range as a subdued kindergarten teacher confronting sex-abuse charges in a small Danish town.
[An] energetic, funny cartoon about a plucky garden snail.
[Evidence] tries to camouflage a standard serial-killer story with digital flimflam and intellectual pretensions.

This sequel to the action comedy about veteran espionage agents charging back into action lacks elegance and wit and is devoid of thrills, except for those brought by Byung-hun Lee as a Korean contract killer.
[Wan] cuts The Conjuring into two halves -- an exhilarating haunted-house thriller and a grueling post-Exorcist horror film -- but they don't come back together in a living, breathing whole.
The sometimes airy, sometimes claustrophobic ambiance fills you with the same bittersweet feeling as spinning a half-forgotten Golden Oldie at a backyard cookout.
[A] turbulent, emotionally overpowering movie.
Every fantasy creature except zombies get a workout in this overstuffed spectacle about a teenage girl who discovers she has angelic blood in her veins.
movie_title: The Mortal Instruments: City of Bones (2013)

movie_review_blurb: This uninhibited slasher movie has sick-joke humor and variety -- it's more of a hack, chop, slice, dice and purée film.
It's a piquant idea, but the execution is intolerably clumsy.
Benedict Cumberbatch restores mystery to the personality of WikiLeaks' founder, Julian Assange, and fascination to his role as a global crusader for free speech.
This is the Teen Vogue version of the ultimate young love story.
Is this satire or parasitism?
No one working in movies today does fervid, visceral realism better than director Paul Greengrass.
You may find that images from this movie clamber back into your memory weeks after you see it, and give your spine a chill.
movie_title: The Devil's Backbone (El Espinazo del diablo) (2001)

movie_review_blurb: This enthralling tale of survival in space will open up young audiences' eyes to the excitement of out-of-this-world exploration -- and make older audiences remember the wonder they felt at 2001: A Space Odyssey.
This documentary would be a rousing David and Goliath story even if its hero weren't the diminutive Robert B. Reich.

This star-studded docudrama about President Kennedy's assassination and its aftermath focuses on fascinating, relatively obscure stories, but fails to organize them into effective and revealing drama.
The movie is like a set-up to a set-up.
What a concept -- an adult romantic comedy that's equally wise and playful, with mold-breaking performances by James Gandolfini and Julia Louis-Dreyfus.
Joseph Gordon-Levitt's debut as a writer-director-actor resembles a porn addict's Groundhog Day, and not in a good way.

Stripped-down characters and skeletal dramaturgy limit this movie about the real-life Formula 1 racing rivalry of James Hunt and Niki Lauda, but harrowing track scenes and an affecting second half provide some vivid compensation.
The arduous trail to recovery from sex addiction gets cushioned with soap opera suds and romantic comedy shtick in Thanks for Sharing.
Teller, the quiet half of the iconoclastic magic act Penn and Teller, crafts a captivating documentary portrait of the artist as a tinkerer.

The treatment of J.D. Salinger's writing in this overwrought documentary is so inflated and pompous it comes as a relief when Judd Apatow shows up to describe The Catcher in the Rye as a funny book filled with great lines.
The greatest American movie fantasy.
This biopic is part hagiography, part expose, and gravely incoherent.
This sequel to the horror hit about a boy lost in the demon-infested netherworld called The Further adds the element of time travel to its paranormal expeditions -- and sinks in its own murk.
An all-star cast fails to rise above bloody japes and heavy-handed humor in this tale of a renegade Mob family hiding in a small French town.
This story of two dynamite Australian moms falling in love with each other's surfer-god sons is sensuous and gorgeous but also strained and opaque.
Funny and trenchant, it isn't a shapely farce. It's a comedy of confusion that dares to be unlikable -- and somehow, that makes it more lovable.
The scenes have a raw, newsreel poetry.
This movie has the dash and esprit of service comedies like MASH and the harrowing emotions of misunderstood youth films like The 400 Blows.
A lyrical modern Western that casts a contemporary but un-jaded eye on the romantic mythology of outlaw couples.
The fights that dot this erratically told story of kung fu grandmaster Ip Man can leave you giddy with excitement.
This nonstop chase film could make a critic feel guilty for calling other movies "empty."
Inch'Allah, filmed in Jordan and the West Bank, undercuts formidable graphic textures with a shallow would-be heroine.
It's a tragedy streaked with nightmare farce.
Prisoners is an overblown missing-children mystery that wants to comment on the dysfunctional soul of America.

This movie about Live Action Role Players (or LARPers) -- men and women who act out Dungeons and Dragons in real settings, in costumes -- is so haphazard it might have been thought up during a game of Mad Libs.
This comedy about a gawky female voice-over artist is disarmingly graceful, generous, even life enhancing.
The movie is so predictable that it might have played better as a domestic comedy about an odd couple of dads.
It's an excuse for the latest crop of media-spawned personalities -- the male equivalent of starlets -- to invade the heavy-duty genre of the gangster film. They don't come up to Cagney's spats.
I can't think of another actor today who could vitalize the character of a virtuous, wronged woman as vividly and unsentimentally as Marion Cotillard does in The Immigrant.
The Retrieval's potency transcends its scope. It shows you, in microcosm, the sacrifices that forge the conscience not only of a boy, but of a nation.
Director Gareth Edwards bloats the film with human figures that never spring to life and sabotage the primal story.
Hamm doesn't embarrass himself as Bernstein, but the role is hollow -- a savvy guy who needs to learn how nice and lovable he can be.
Goodman should have been perfect for the title role: like Ruth, he's a regular Joe of hugely irregular proportions in appetite and accomplishment. Too bad Hiller and Fusco cut him down to size.
Stephanie Soechtig's attack on Big Food for sweetening us to death goes down like a tart, stiff drink.

Franco's stories, sometimes coarse and flimsy on the page, operate like launch pads for a slew of fresh, frisky performers. But the delicacy of the movie's narrative and its almost mystical thread of yearning come from Coppola.
As a director, Favreau keeps his music and his palette bold; the grass-roots American food and road views look inviting.
God's Pocket, despite its tiptop cast, fails to sustain its comedy or drama. It becomes, at best, a piece of sardonic anthropology.
A movie about the unexamined and excruciating phenomenon of "neighbor noise" turns out to be mostly about party envy (and, yes, the other kind of envy, too).

For Love of the Game asks whether the same qualities that make an athlete a champion don't also destroy his happiness. The answer, unfortunately, is long-winded and redundant... But some of the baseball scenes are good.
There's a snappy change-of-pace gag involving a little guy and a nubile lifeguard, but the screams and barks and fraudulent emotions grow wearying.
Griffith's artless embodiment of the script's deranged idea of tough-gal gumption isn't as amusing as it should be. She's a B-picture heroine stuck in an absurdly self-conscious prestige project.
Steven E. de Souza's script has Foley following a trail of murder and deception into an L. A. amusement park called WonderWorld. The director, John Landis, fails to exploit the possibilities.

The new Spider-Man series has managed to do in two films what the previous Spider-Man series did in three: transform an engrossing comic-book coming-of-age epic into an overstuffed and off-putting battle royale.
The performances are beyond reproach. As Wanda, Agata Kulesza is mournfully magnetic. As Ida, Agata Trzebuchowska expresses a complex consciousness budding up from behind her sweet blank slate.
